column2: A proposed law that would allow speedier demolition of certain sizes of vacant buildings as part of the city's campaign against arson in the South Bronx and other areas has been submitted to the City Council by Mayor Beame.

CAPE MAY--An interesting array of special activities will be offered during Cape May's annual Victorian Weekend, which gets under way next Saturday. The three-day event is co-sponsored by the city and the id-Atlantic Center for the Arts.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 4-- Westchester County is preparing to lift the burden of road maintenance and construction costs from its municipalities, but opponents of the change say it will create more problems that it will solve.
BYRAM--Instead of hiring a builder, the Chapin brothers have made the completion of their rustic retreat here a family project.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 4--Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. says he has decided to appoint a special force of lawyers and investigators in an attempt to "unclog quickly" the machinery of California's new farm labor election law.

DUBLIN, Oct. 4--Thousands of people marched in the provincial city of Limerick today demanding the safe return of Tiede Herrema, a factory manager from the Netherlands who was kidnapped yesterday on his way to work. The marchers were led by 1,200 workers from his factory here and by the Mayor of Limerick, Thady Coughlan.

MONTREAL, Oct. 4--Canada today formally opened her new Mirabel International Airport, billed as the world's largest and designed to protect the environment and provide for the nation's air travel needs well into the next century.

TRENTON--In Somerville, Detective Willie Akins has waited almost a year for some action on his employment complaint; in Basking Ridge, Caroline Hebard has waited 28 months for resolution of her complaint against the Basking Ridge Fire Department.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 4 --Reveling in unaccustomed success, New Hampshire Democrats were courted here last night by a half dozen Presidential hopefuls.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The United States and Spain announced today that they had reached agreement in principle on a new, wide-ranging accord including provisions for the continued use by American air and naval forces of Spanish military bases.

Ruth Woodward Robinson Urban, a legal assistant with the firm of Hogan Hartson in Washington, plans to be married next month to Carleton Craig Smith of Washington, who is on the financial staff of the President Ford Committee, the Republican campaign group for the President's nomination.

There is no disguise like nakedness. This, among other things, cripples Jean Francois Davy's two-hour documentary about a French porno-film star and the emotional transactions that take place in the making of dirty movies.

WASHINGTON, oct. 4 (AP)-- The cereal stem moth, which has heavily damaged winter wheat and rye crops in the southwestern part of the Soviet Union, has turned up in the United States, the Smithsonian Institution says.
King Olav V of Norway flew to New York yesterday to begin a 26-day tour of the United States commemorating the 150th anniversary of the first organized Norwegian emigration to this country.

A new series of stamped envelopes of varying denominations, devoted to the celebration of facets of Americana related to the Bicentennial, is being launched by the United States Postal Service, beginning with a 10-cent envelope coming out a week from tomorrow.

Ezekiel Jacob, of Brooklyn, has what he hopes will soon be a patented solution to the stubborn problem of how to reproduce, cheaply and legibly, the three-dimensional white-on--white of braille literature--through photocopying.

TRENTON--As New Jersey prepares for what could be a major shortage of natural gas this winter, a member of the state's Board of Public Utility Commissioners urged Congress last week to maintain price controls on the fuel.

DUBOIS, Wyo--As our horses scrambled through Shoshone Pass at sunset, nearly 10,000 feet above sea level, I was grateful that our outfitter Bob Jacob, had told me to lash a heavy wool shirt or jacket behind my saddle, for with the arrival of twilight the high, thin air was suddenly cold.

Hours before the arrival here yesterday of Emperor Hirohito of Japan, United States Secret Service agents raided a Brooklyn apartment where they seized a cache of arms that they believed might have been intended for use in an assasination attempt on the Emperor.
BATH, self-styled "Queen City of the West" (the West of England, that is), lies 107 miles from Lon don on a meandering loop of the River Avon, in a natural amphitheater of wooded hills.

Early in the summer the police arrested a youth after he allegedly hit a man on the head with a golf club and stole his radio. The youth was booked and brought to the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street, where a felony complaint was drawn up.

Remember the ballyhoo that accompanied Richard Nixon's preparations to visit China in 1972? Even his reading list stirred speculation. Which books would shape the President's image of revolutionary China? Pundits pontificated on the implications of choosing one author over another.
Marybeth Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Ryan of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Edward Frederick Heuer, son of Mrs. John H. Heuer of Tamarac, Fla., and the late Mr. Heuer.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4 (AP)--The Young Americans for Freedom have shifted their support from President Ford to Ronald Reagan, former Governor of California, the group's national chairman, Jeffrey Kane of Portland, announced Thursday.

The specter of a monumental--and perhaps permanent --traffic jam where Queens Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway intersect has been raised by opponents of a proposed $150-million complex of stores, offices and condominium housing in Rego Park, Queens.

WESTPORT, Conn. The back lots of Hollywood are salted down with the bones of performers who crashed through as stars in their first movie after a nation-wide talent search only to be forgotten. Has anyone heard from Rudolph Valentino's look alike, Anthony Dexter, lately? And what ever happened to May Wynn since "The Caine Munity"?

Sandwiched between Peru to the south, with its spectacular Inca heritage, and Mesoamerica to the north, with its Aztec, Mayan and other monuments, Ecuador has seemed a curiously sterile region in America's pre-Hispanic history. But "sterile" is exactly the wrong word.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 4 --Tyrone Wilson's 76-yard burst set up Levi Jackson's 4-yard touchdown run with 3 minutes 50 seconds left, as Michigan State upset eighthranked Notre Dame, 10-3, today.
The $550-million-a-year United States gun industry was having a good year until last month. Sales were high, profits were satisfactory, and the industry's myriad critics were reasonably quiet.

WASHINGTON--President Ford has made it clear, during his "nonpolitical" travels of the last few months, that he intends to present himself to the American electorate as the apostle of fiscal sanity, the President who will finally bring Government spending under control and ease the burden on the taxpayers. He has also pictured himself as the prototypical Middle Westerner, open, affable, free of specious sophistication.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The bitter labor-management trouble at The Washington Post, which briefly silenced the nation's seventh largest newspaper this week, is part of a general struggle for survival in the publishing industry, according to officials on both sides of the dispute here.

NEWARK--The first class in the permanent diaconate program of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark was formally accepted as candidates for ordination last night in ceremonies held at St. Joseph's Church, 221 West Market Street. The 94 men in the class will be ordained at Sacred Heart Cathedral on Dec. 14.
An exhibition of 70 old waterfront photographs opened yesterday under the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn Bridge. The pictures, dating from 1880 to 1930 and ...
WARSAW, Oct. 2--Many Roman Catholic priests in Poland feel that a growing friendship of the Vatican toward Communist governments has undermined the priests' position in this country.

CHATHAM TOWNSHIP-- When the store owner is a bona fide chef too, there is no telling what special treat might be cooking in the back-of-the-store kettles. It might be the day for poached salmon, or steakand-kidney pie or perhaps even the chicken Havaland, boned chicken that is stuffed with creamed mushrooms and water chestnuts and baked in a homemade puff pastry.

Mrs. Joseph E. Evans of Pelham Manor, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elisabeth Jane Marie Evans, to Peter V. Foukal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaroslav Foukal of Montreal. A wedding in December is planned.
Final city approval was given last week to a special zoning district intended to preserve the balance between industrial buildings and private homes in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON--Some 70 per cent of the milk and, very roughly, one-third of the grain, cotton, fruits and vegetables produced by the nation's farmers are sold through cooperatives these days.
NICOSIA, Cyprus--The polit- ical problems of Cyprus in the last year have not stopped archeologists from exploring the island's rich past.
WASHINGTON--In late 1975, Congress passed without any fanfare a seemingly technical piece of legislation establishing a Federal Financing Bank to operate under the control of the Treasury.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 4--A group of four armed men attacked Beirut's international airport early today in what was believed to have been an attempt to hijack an airliner and take Egyptian passengers as hostages to protest President Anwar-el-Sadat's Middle East policies.

The A.S.P.C.A. shelter at l58th Street in Jamaica, Queens which has provided a refuge for thousands of the city's homeless and hungry eats and dogs, closed its doors last week after 40 years of service.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4-- Jack Ford, the President's 23year-old son, was reported today as saying that he had smoked marijuana and believed the law should treat the substance as it does beer and wine.

JERSEY CITY--A plan that would more than double the size of Lincoln County Park here has been unveiled by the rejuvenated Hudson County Park Commission as part of the agency's first effort in 12 years to improve the seven county-operated preserves.

ROME, Oct. 4--A visit to Washington by the leader of the Italian neo-Fascist party and his meeting with American Government officials has touched off a political storm here, embarrassed the American Embassy and left many Italians wondering whether the United States was now backing the extreme right in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) --A House subcommittee says some electric utility companies double-charge customers by abusing fuel adjustment clauses that are designed only to let the utilities quickly recover incrased fuel costs.

Indrani's regular visits here began in 1961, and she has quite thoroughly captivated her audiences each time. A climax of official recognition was reached when she received the key to the city on a visit two years ago. This time she scheduled two performances for Hunter College on Friday and yesterday and presented her mixture of styles and dances with assurance and flair.

MINEOLA--A $20-million law suit has been filed against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Long Island Rail Road, the Budd Company, the General Electric Company and two other defendants in the death last year of a physician after he was caught in the door of a train leaving the Huntington station.
MUNSTER, West Germany, Oct. 4 (Reuters)--Motorists in West Germany can qualify for a driving license without being able to read or write, a Munster court has ruled.
STILLWATER--Economists, biologists, energy consultants and environmental lawyers are among those expected to attend the Billion Dollar Beaver Conference in Delaware Water Gap, Pa., next weekend.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 4--A $5-million gift has been made to the University of Virginia to establish a center for the study of public policy, Dr. Frank L. Hereford Jr., the university president, announced.

CORNWELL HEIGHTS, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP)--Heavily favored fifth straight stakes victory and 11th of the season today, capturing the $27,525 Penn Treaty Stakes at Keystone Race Track. Carrying 119 pounds and jockey Garland Gallitano, Robert P. Horton's Gallant Bob finished two lengths ahead of Tinton Falls Stable's Talc. Daybreak Farm's Real Value finished third, another two lengths back.

The NCR Corporation will more than double its space at Rockefeller Center as a result of a lease it has signed for more than 30,000 square feet of office space for about 19 years at an approximate aggregate rent of $6-million.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 4--Brett Lunger, as expected, did not win the pole position today for the Grand Prix of the Unite dStates. In fact, he came dangerously close to crashing his way out of tomorrow's $350,000 event, the richest auto race in the world with right-hand turns.
Croton-Harmon took a big step toward repeating as Interscholastic Conference C North League champion by handing Pleasantville a stunning 40-0 defeat yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4--A novel new system of sewage treatment, in which some components are used to purify the rest, is going to get a full-scale trial here.

Construction on three housing developments for the elderly, which are financed through the Housing Finance Agency, will halt on Oct. 14, housing officials say, unless the state is able to devise some means of pumping money into the financially ailing agency.

Skyrocketing construction costs and puzzling patterns in the use of electricity have slowed the development of nuclear energy in the United States in a way that the opponents of nuclear power probably never imagined, in their wildest dreams.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 4 (AP)--Colenzo Hubbard and Grag Montgomery, middle guards, recovered fumbles and ninth-ranked Alabama turned them into two scores in 41 seconds in defeating Mississippi, 32-6, in a Southeastern Conference football game today.

LUDWIGS CORNER, Pa. Oct. 4--Ch. Jo-Ni's Red Baron of Crafton, the topwinning dog of all breeds in America last year and the greatest winning terrier in history in this country, triumphed again today. He gained his 63d best-in-show award at the 63d Devon Dog Show Association fixtures on the Horse Show grounds.

KIEV, U.S.S.R.--A monument is being built at Babi Yar. Past the thin woods, in the ravine where tens of thousands of Jews were slaughtered by the Nazis, a bulldozer works. A truck brings in new earth. A wood- en form for concrete stands on a small rise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The Ford Administration will soon propose legislation that would enable New York and other large cities to petition for bankruptcy and surrender fiscal control to a Federal referee, high Administration officials said today.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 4 (UPI) --An inquiry into an alleged violation of Wisconsin antitrust laws by two major supplemental news services will begin Friday, according to Bronson C. La Follette, the state attorney general.
New York City's cold-weather task of keeping fuel flowing to apartment houses whose owners have run out of credit appears likely to be compounded this season.
Football is one of my favorite games. I was, in fact, a high school football coach for 15 years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4-- A survey by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization has found home ownership more extensive among union members than is the average for American households.

In the Golden Age of Steam the chuffing of the locomotive, the sight of a steam plume wafting against the prairie landscape, a forlorn whistle in the dead of night, and the trainman's reassuring wave were all part of the American scene.

ELKINS, W.Va., Oct. 4-- Thousands of West Virginians cheered and applauded President Ford today as he rode and walked more than a mile through this small mountain town as the grand marshal of an annual festival.

The Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Carol Fontaine Humstone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Millard Humstone of Douglaston, Queens, to Robert Vincent Cosel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cosel of Pelham, N.Y.
The look and the approach are different; often vastly different, but the goal is the same: small shopping centers --mostly without department stores or other large "anchor" units.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4(UPI) --Nearly half the drugs withdrawn from stocks in nine Veterans Administration hospitals in a two-week period disappeared, according to an audit last year by the General Accounting Office.
The Washington International Horse Show, the first of the three events on the North American indoor fall circuit, will be held at the new Capital Centre in Land- ...
FRANKLIN LAKES-- Should falconry, the old "sport of kings," be permitted in New Jersey, as it is in some other states?
Angelo Dundee, Muhammad Ali's trainer, on the heavyweight champion's late round rally to beat Joe Frazier. "My guy sucked it up when he looked completely out of gas, he put on another gas tank."

Christ Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church in Buffalo was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Robin B. Adam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Borthwick Adam, to Leonard Parke Hall 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall Jr. Both families reside in Buffalo.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4--It might have been coincidental, but the two formally declared candidates in the race for Illinois Governor each made his announcement of candidacy the day after a Muhammad Ali fight--one this summer and one this week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The Central Intelligence Agency made actual attempts to kill Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba in the Administrations of three Presidents, Senator Frank Church said today.

Buffalo turned "The Juice," O. J. Simpson, loose again yesterday, and he became the first National Football League player to gain more than 500 yards rushing through three consecutive games as the Bills routed the visiting Denver Broncos in Rich Stadium, 38-14. Simpson gained 138 yards to go with the 400 yards rushing in his two previous games.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 In the 16 years since Charles A. McManus founded Americans for Constitutional Action, the organization has...
DEATH VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 5 Time moves slowly in the air-bending heat that rises in waves from the saltencrusted flats and sun- blasted dunes of Death Valley National Monument.

Igor Stravinsky's ballet "Jeu de Cartes" was one of the very few works the composer actualy composed for his long-time collaborator, George Baanchine. Ironically, it failed dismally. Called various names, it was last revived in 1951, as "Card Game," by New York City Ballet, and it was pretty much a disaster. Perhaps Mr. Balanchine never really understood poker, on which the ballet is based.
Coolly, with the arrogance of a card player who knows everyone's hand, Joe Namath directed the Jets' offense to a crushing 36-7 victory over the New England Patriots yesterday.

David Elmendorf has two cars, his own small business and enough money to buy gasoline even at today's prices. But there he was in the Califoraia sun, standing alongside the Pacific Coast Highway at Malibu, his thumb in the air and San Francisco on his mind.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 5 When the earthquake of 1906 struck northern California, it virtually destroyed the city of San Francisco. But here across the bay in Oakland its deadly tremors were hardly felt.
Dr. Sandra Jane Hicks, a resident in psychiatry at St. Luke's Hospital here, was married yesterday afternoon to James Stephen Wulach, a doctoral candidate in psychology at City College.

A crowd of 24,860 at Belmont Park saw what probably was the last race of the prominent Rice Stable yesterday. And it was a winner for the stable as Ada L. Rice's Proud Delta triumphed in the $46,275 Suffolk County Handicap.

Federal prisoners are entitled to a hearing before they can be classified as "special offenders" and deprived of prison privileges, according to a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission issued a consent order today prohibiting Peoples Drug Stores, Inc., one of the largest drug-store chains in the East, from signing anticompetitive shopping center leases.

St. Francis Prep failed to win the Catholic Schools Football League title last season after two consecutive titles, but with two victories in two games this season, it seems the Little Terriers have no intention of missing out again.

MADRID, Oct. 5 Ascension Lopesino Alvarez, 50 years old, has been beaten, fined, imprisoned and indicted for aiding subversion because she objected to a group of young demonstrators roaming the streets after a rally in support of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

Susan Jill Lager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Lager of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Kenneth Peter Jaffe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Jaffe of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed at the Lager home by Rabbi Sol Roth of the Atlantic Beach Jewish Center.
The freedom of peaceable assembly is not only a right but it is also a pleasure, and New Yorkers have always been among the best assemblers there are.

All serious pianists play Beethoven's "Hammerklavier" Sonata. Some even play it in public. And a few grand masters of the keyboard reach the point where they are able to transcend the work's technical demands and make it a musical experience. For the most part, Richard Goode's performance at Hunter College yesterday afternoon was strong enough to put him in the company of the blessed few.

Vice President Rockefeller says that Congress should consider whether there should be some temporary Federal help for New York City. He says this should be considered after the city acts to restore "fiscal integrity" by moving to balance its budget and trim its $3-billion short-term debt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 At the urging of its new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, the Ford Administration has agreed to continue to endorse the program to support the operation of medical and dental schools rather than phase it out.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 5 The recent increase in crude oil prices, which is expected to make insecticides more costly, has seriously jeopardized India's chances of controlling a growing epidemic of malaria, according to Indian and World Health Organization experts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Robert A. Goldwin describes himself as a teacher with a vocation for bringing men of affairs and thinkers togethers in useful discussions of broad public issues. It takes a special tact and talent, he explains in patient, teacherly fashion, to find the chemistry of persons, topic and atmosphere that turns such gatherings into real encounters.

Janice Meryl Sloan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Sloan, was married yesterday aftenoon to Steven Jay Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Mann. Both families live in East Meadow, L.I., where Rabbi Israel Nobel performed the ceremony in the East Meadow Jewish Center.
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Sept. 30 The anniversary of the assassination of Prime Minister S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike is normally an occasion of mourning and prayer in Sri Lanka.

Ronald Reagan, who is expected to announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination within the month, will make three major appearances in the metropolitan area Vice President Rockeller's "turf" later this month.
Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

The Fair Lawn (N.J.) Jewish Community Center was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Dr. Margaret Sue Ravits, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Everett C. Ravits of Hackensack, N.J., to Dr. Mark Goldfarb. He is the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. William Goldfarb of Paramus, N.J. Rabbi John Gotlieb performed the ceremony.
VIENNA, Monday, Oct. 6 Austrian voters apparently increased the majority of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's Socialist party in parliamentary elections yesterday.
A father and his three children died when fire swept their apartment early yesterday in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

A high official of the Ford Administration proposed yesterday a change in the tax exempt status of municipal bonds that could lead to a basic restructuring of the nation's system of municipal finance and perhaps help cities raise money.

Emperor Hirohito took tea in lacquered cups with Vice President Rockefeller at Mr. Rockefeller's Japanese house in Pocantico Hills yesterday and then savored a different dimension of leisure America a raucous football game at Shea Stadium.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 A leading Soviet authority on American affairs, Georgi A. Arbatov, recently deplored violations of human rights in the United States. He told the readers of Izvestia that Americans suffer such abuses as wiretapping, the keeping of Government dossiers on individuals and "shameful court reprisals against dissidents."

Most professional estateplanning analyses concentrate on the problems normally faced by married persons. But single individuals, particularly working women, are likely to encounter special difficulties in developing estate plans.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 1 The Communist-led Pathet Lao, having seized and closed the once vast United States aid mission here during the summer, is now reportedly angry with the United States for having cut off further economic assistance, including a promised $5-million contribution to a large dam project.

Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, has reluctantly abandoned a novel kind of undercover work that he says is essential to prosecuting corrupt judges and that his critics say is illegal.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 5 A victory in the exhibition season does not count for much, but the New York Rangers' 2-1 victory over the New York Islanders tonight in Nassau Coliseum was worth something to them. The previous time the clubs met was last April, when the Islanders knocked the Rangers out of the National Hockey League playoffs.

Victor Muscat, an unpredictable businessman who once headed a financial empire with controlling or large interests in 28 companies, including four banks, six steel concerns and five bus companies, died yesterday of a heart attack in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 56 years old.
QUEBEC, Oct. 5 American forces attacked Quebec yesterday for the second time in 200 years and lost again, as planned, but this time Canadian crowds applauded the invaders.

Joan Cooper, a clinical psychologist, and Walter Richard Uhrman, a professor of theater arts at the State University of New York College at Brockport, were married here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Fredric S. Dworkin performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Cooper.

HACKENSACK, Oct. 5 A prominent New Jersey physician who successfully challenged the state's antiabortion laws is now the target of a Bergen County grand jury investigation into charges that he is illegally arranging the adoption of unwanted babies that he delivers.
KENTWOOD, La., Oct. 5 (UPI) United States District Judge Herbert W. Christenberry of New Orleans died of a heart attack today while en route to Jackson, Miss., on court business. He was 77 years old.
The kids in the neighborhood around Millie's candy store are spending a lot more time these days over egg creams because school hasn't really started yet.

Nearly 1,100 teachers and other school personnel were told by their union to strike the 23 public schools in Elizabeth today as negotiations over a 10 per cent pay increase dragged on yesterday with no signs of progress.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 Delegates from a number of countries flew to Vermont in a charter plane over the weekend for a glimpse of New England in the fall, others were stewing in saunas here to get the toxins of too much diplomatic conviviality out of their systems, and a European ambassador said ruefully: "In four years in New York I haven't yet managed to visit Brooklyn."
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 5 (AP) Richard Petty beat David Pearson by an eyelash today in winning the National 500 stock car race for his second straight victory at what was once called his jinx track.
Many Wall Street analysts expect the government and corporate bond markets to improve sharply in the next few weeks after months of sliding prices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The Central Intelligence Agency made actual attempts to kill Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba in the Administrations of three Presidents, Senator Frank Church said today.

As the musicians' strike against Broadway moves toward its fourth week, annoyance is turning to bitterness. As brief vacations turn into long enforced unemployment, those who are not part of the negotiating teams (the union, Local 802 and the League of New York Theaters) do not know where to turn.

In about two hours, Hirohito, the Emperor of Japan, would be scouting the New York Jets and the New England Patriots as potential sumo wrestlers. But now in the elevator ascending to the Diamond Club at Shea Stadium, Pete Rozelle, the Czar of Pigskin, was discussing with Howard Cosell, the Vicar of Vitriol and Variety, the protocol of the occasion.

The swift cancellation of television series by NBC-TV this fall was deplored by a competitor, Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, as "unfair to the people producing the shows and performing in them."

Laurie Oestreicher Haussamen of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to J. Laurence Lowenstein, an assistant professor of theater and direction at Brookdale Community College in Lincroft, N.J. Rabbi Sidney Schulman performed the ceremony at the Hollywood Golf Club in Deal, N.J.

BONN, Oct. 5 Two buses carrying 82 prisoners from East German jails arrived recently at the West German border in the Thuringian hills at Wartha. A police escort left the convoy before the final five-mile passage to the heavily guarded customs and police checkpoint next to the railroad track. A few minutes later the group was in Herleshausen, in the West, and on its way to freedom.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 5 Three American oil technicians arrived at Sudr in Israeli-occupied territory on the Gulf of Suez today to inspect installations in the oilfield there in preparation for the return of the field to Egypt under the interim accord on Sinai.

Arthur Miller does it. John N. Mitchell does it. Angela Davis does it. Cass Canfield too, not to mention Gerald R. Ford. And so does Judy O'Neil of the White House staff, Alger Hiss and Alexander Gerschenkron and Georges Simenon. Likewise Charles Silberman and Matthew J. Bruccoli, the writers, and Dennis Potvin, the hockey star for the Islanders, and Representative Millicent Fenwick. Sherlock Holmes also was famous for it.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 At least 26 people were killed tonight when leftist guerrillas attacked an army regimental headquarters in the northern Argentine city of Formosa, army headquarters announced.

State and city elected officials expressed some puzzlement and some pleasure yesterday over Treasury Secretary William E. Simon's three-step plan to extricate New York City from a fiscal morass and the threat of default.

A reckless, gambling approach enabled previously unbeaten Colorado to get within one play of ending Oklahoma's winning streak, the longest in the nation, on Saturday. Then, with 79 seconds to go, the Buffaloes' coach, Bill Mallory, turned conservative and Colorado lost the big opportunity for an upset and the game as well, 21-20, as Oklahoma in- creased its victory streak to 24 games.

Long distance calls from more than half the nation's 115 million Bell System telephones now are assisted by operators using a little-known type of electronic switchboard that was installed first in Morristown, N.J., in January, 1969.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The Federal Bureau of Investigation continued to employ at least one of the techniques that characterized a controversial counterintelligence operation for two and a half years after April, 1971, the date the bureau gave for formally terminating the program, according to previously classified documents made public today.

In the theater, growth is everything. Institutions are always either on their way up or on their way down. It is one of those life patterns that everyone notices, but few people want to talk about. The CSC Repertory has been around for eight years. It has infested lofts and basements, and once found a home in a shoe factory. The shoes had left.
DAVIS, Calif., Oct. 5 The Davis City Council is ready to approve a novel building code that is designed to save the owners of new homes close to 50 per cent on their heating and cooling bills.

Under a sun that wove in and out of the clouds and in a wind that sometimes blew heartily but more often did not, members of the Central Park Model Yacht Club yesterday took the top 10 spots in a national championship race for the "International 10-Rater" class of model sailboats.

A high official of the Ford Administration proposed yesterday a change in the tax exempt status of municipal bonds that could lead to a basic restructuring of the nation's system of municipal finance and perhaps help cities raise money.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 The story of a young woman who was held prisoner, mistreated, threatened and forced to take part in a bank robbery rests in the Federal District Court files here.

Janet Edna Meyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton G. Meyer of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon, to Joseph Joshua Greenberg, son of Mrs. Abner Greenberg of New York, and the late Mr. Greenberg.
King Olav V of Norway blew out 150 candles and charmed hundreds of Norwegian-Americans at a church coffee hour yesterday by asking to shake hands with every one of them.

Vice President Rockefeller and former Attorney General John N. Mitchell are among those scheduled to testify at hearings into financial prob lems of the Urban Development Corporation and other state financing agencies.

They are kicked and spat upon. They are yelled at, cursed and sometimes slugged, all in the course of their business. They are possibly the city's most unpopular public servants, the parking enforcement agents, colloquially known as meter maids, even though there are men among their ranks.
Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor has reluctantly abandoned a novel kind of undercover work that he says is essential to prosecuting corrupt judges and that his critics say is illegal.

Somber World War II veterans in faded uniforms with red "Poland" shoulder patches marched amid swirling dancers, polka bands and briskly stepping fife-and-drum corps yesterday at the 39th annual Pulaski Day parade.

As surprising as it may seem, open pit mining may soon begin to desecrate one of the most scenic and popular parts of Death Valley National Monument in California. The Interior Department has ruled that the National Park Service is powerless to prevent the private exploitation of this extremely fragile desert landscape.

The Boston Red Sox and the Cincinnati Reds took 2-0 leads in baseball's league championship playoffs yesterday. The Red Sox rallied to defeat the Oakland A's, 6-3, in Boston as Carl Yastrzemski and Rico Petrocelli hit home runs. The Reds downed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-1, in Cincinnati with the aid of seven stolen bases.

NEWARK, Oct. 5 Members of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra voted yesterday to reject a one-year contract offered by management. The vote, by members of Local 16 of the American Federation of Musicians, was 51 to 11.

President Ford's tax program combining tax cuts with a ceiling on spending received only lukewarm approval from business leaders yesterday. Many felt it was pure politics.

The opening of a new office of a financial institution particularly of a savings and loan association or savings bank has long occasioned promotional hoopla. Extensive advertising, circus-like decorations at the branch and particularly gifts of merchandise are often featured to lure additional customers.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8 The Bunge Corporation, one of the world's largest grain companies, was judged guilty today after pleading nolo contendere, or no contest, to two Federal counts of conspiracy in systematic thefts of grain and in a cover-up of the thefts and was required to spend more than $2-million over the next three years on procedures to guard against corruption.

Leaders of the city's municipal labor unions said yesterday that they would consider a general strike to protest the three-year wage freeze and potential layoffs called for in the financial plan Mayor Beame has proposed to the Emergency Financial Control Board.
Soybean futures advanced yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid a spate of rumors and confusing news.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 8 (Reuters) The Indian Government today cut off the telex and telephone lines of the Reuters office in New Delhi and the home telephones of its three correspondents.

ATLANTA, Oct. 8 It has been 40 years since Franklin D. Roosevelt declared the South to be "the nation's No. One economic problem" and Erskine Caldwell teamed up with Margaret Bourke-White to portray that problem poignantly in a book entitled, "You Have Seen Their Faces."

"It's the answer to my prayer," a very large woman sighed yesterday as she rode serenely up to street level in 36 seconds on one of the two parallel escalators just put into service at the Columbus Circle subway station.
The state's top mediator called negotiators for both sides in the Broadway musicians' strike to a meeting at the Americana Hotel yesterday in an effort to settle the dispute.
Prices for Government bonds opened lower yesterday reflecting the suprisingly high yields for the Treasury's new $2.5billion 38-month notes.
BONN, Oct. 8 The European Common Market has recently made dramatic use of its economic and political power in an attempt to move Spain and Portugal toward democratic rule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The Council on Wage and Price Stability challenged as unjustified today a price increase of 67 cents a gallon for antifreeze announced by the leading manufacturer, the Union Carbide Corporation, to take effect Nov. 1.
French and Polyclinic Hospital, which has cared for hundreds of actors and actresses over the years, got a shot in the arm yesterday from one of Broadway's most famous lights Ethel Merman.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 8 (AP) A Federal judge has reprimanded former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark for commenting on the civil damages trial stemming from the Kent State University shootings, but the judge dropped contempt of court charges against Mr. Clark.

NEWARK, Oct. 8 The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has postponed indefinitely its opening concert of the season because of a breakdown in talks on a new contract with Local 16 of the American Federation of Musicians. The New Jersey State Council on the Arts formed a special committee to assist in seeking a resolution of the dispute.

The last time that Rick Wakeman appeared at Madison Square Garden he surrounded himself with a choir and orchestra all the trappings of of a rock 'n' roll event. But on Tuesday in the same hall, it was a slimmed-down Mr. Wakeman, just himself and seven other musicians, although he has not quite given up on excess-playing a total of 14 keyboards throughout the evening.

As if the Hills and Kleppe appointments were not sufficient cause for concern, President Ford has chosen two other nominees for significant posts whose qualifications or lack of them are even more disturbing.
The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

Critics of efforts by Dominion Textile, Ltd., to merge with DHJ Industries, Inc., say they are baffled by a $5.6-million DHJ loss for the fourth fiscal quarter ended May 31 reported to shareholders in materials concerning the merger plan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The chiefs of police of some of the nation's largest cities told a Senate committee today that they would prefer no new guncontrol law to one that did not ban the manufacture, sale and private possession of handguns.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 From beginning to end, the man in charge of the justconcluded A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention was George Meany, the only president the labor federation has ever had. At 81 years old, he was still in absolute control.

PARAMUS, Oct. 8 A warning to consumers to be aware of the influence that professional boards, ranging from physicians to morticians, have on the lives of most people has been voiced by Virginia Long Annich, director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs.

LISBON, Oct. 8 (Reuters) Rebel troops and loyal units faced each other with armored cars in the northern city of Oporto tonight after clashes between rival civilian demonstrators left at least 45 people injured.

The W.T. Grant Company has set next Wednesday as the date for the first formal meeting with creditors since the giant retail chain entered bankruptcy proceedings Oct. 2. Grant also reported yesterday a 17 per cent sales drop for the month through last Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) Four New York mail order houses have been deceiving consumers across the country, the Federal Trade Commission charged today.

Last Thursday was gloomy at the Metropolitan Opera House. On the stage, "Boris Godunov" was being rehearsed. The peasants were in revolt. In the pit, drowned out by the clashing brasses and thundering drums, the musicians were crying for more bread.

Sergio Segre, head of the Italian Communist party's foreign affairs section, inquired discreetly of the American Embassy in Rome last month about obtaining a visa to attend an international conference and speak at a dinner given by the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. He was given a "signal" that a visa application would be rejected.

The Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks began their 50th year in the National Hockey League last night by skating to a 2-2 tie. To nearly everybody but the raucous sellout crowd of 17,500 at Madison Square Garden, it was poetic justice.

EUREKA, Ill., Oct. 6 It was hard, dusty stoop labor, but the line of college students moved cheerfully through the cornfield today, kicking up the flattened stalks and occasionally stuffing an ear of corn in their gunnysacks.

Roy M. Cohn yesterday challenged plea-bargaining accepted by the Manhattan District Attorney and the city's Criminal Court judges, who allowed a New Zealand seaman, who had allegedly confessed to felony charges of extortion and grand larceny, to plead guilty to a misdemeanor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) The House and Means Committee voted today to eliminate the Federal income-tax deduction for state and local gasoline taxes, now a savings totaling more than half a billion dollars for those who itemize deductions.

PARIS, Oct. 8 The executive board of UNESCO voted overwhelmingly today in favor of softening the anti-Israeli action that the organization took last November. The board decided to recommend to the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that it adopt procedures that would make it more difficult for Arabs to keep Israel out of the agency's European regional group.

CENTER FIELD A free outdoor community festival of the arts, with entertainment, dancing and food, will be held tonight from 6 to 11 o'clock on the eve of the dedication of the Henry Street Settlement Arts for Living Center, 466 Grand Street.
Two women of River Edge, N.J., drowned in Greenwood Lake near Warwick, N.Y., yesterday when a cabin cruiser carrying a group of elderly people swerved suddenly and capsized.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 Back in 1971, when Israel's best friend in Africa was Uganda's Idi Amin, an Israeli-built passenger jet was put at the disposal of the new leader, piloted by two Israelis.

ATLANTA, Oct. 8 It has been 40 years since Franklin D. Roosevelt declared the South to be "the nation's NoOne economic problem" and Erskine Caldwell teamed up with Margaret Bourke-White to portray that problem poignantly in a book entitled, "You Have Seen Their Faces."

Roderick M. Hills is an experienced and personable lawyer. He has served for the last several months as counsel to President Ford, and he is also the husband of Carla A. Hills, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. By his own admission, he knows very little about the securities industry or about the day-today work of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Yet President Ford has nominated Mr. Hills to be chairman of the S.E.C.

Eight members of what Federal officials have called the largest drug ring in the country selling to blacks were found guilty yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn of conspiring to import, distribute and sell millions of dollars worth of cocaine and heroin.

At first impression, the films of Kenneth Anger seem unlikely candidates for the New American Filmmakers Series at the Whitney Museum of American Art. After all, the four films that opened there yesterday for a run through next Tuesday are scarcely the work of a film maker who is new in the sense of emergent.
Dr. Philip E. Taylor, professor emeritus of economics at the University of Connecticut, died Tuesday at his home in Storrs, Conn. at the age of 67.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) A Federal Trade Commission administrative law judge ruled today that exclusive bottlers' licenses issued by the nation's top two soft-drink manufacturers, the Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico, Inc., increase competition and do not represent an illegal restraint of trade. Joseph P. Dufresne, the administrative law judge, recommended dropping the F.T.C. antitrust complaints issued against the two companies on July 15, 1971.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8 The scoreboard at Kemper Arena held a warning for the visitors: "Islanders a tidal wave is coming your way." The Kansas City Scouts were not as all-enveloping as that, but they did cover the New York Islanders like a wet blanket tonight and held them to a 1-1 tie.

TOPSHAM, Me. It's been a poor year for fishermen on Casco Bay. The striped bass never made their migratory arrival in late May, June went by as quietly as if the winter ice had never left, and the balance of the year has run its arid course, leaving me bereft of the bass and blues that formerly fattened the menu.

Two state legislators labeled yesterday as extravagant the plan of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to spend $20-million to outfit new restaurants at the World Trade Center, including $6-million for a private club.
MADRID, Oct. 8 (AP) Guillermo Vilas of Argentina beat a countryman, Ricardo Cano, 6-3. 6-4, in the third round of the $75,000 Madrid Open tennis tournament today.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 8 (AP) A man who served five years for threatening to kill President Nixon got another five-year term today for threatening the life of President Ford on Aug. 15.
FORT CARSON, Colo., Oct. 8 (UPI) An HU-1-H Army helicopter crashed into a steep ravine on a routine training mission yesterday, killing four soldiers and injuring six others.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct 8 (AP) Harvey T.D. Gillespie, athletic director at Moravian College for 36 years, died last night at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 A Senate subcommittee heard sharply divergent testimony today on the proposed F-18 lightweight Navy fighter from admirals backing the project and the Grumman Aerospace Corporation, struggling against heavy odds for increased F-14 orders.

After a 21-month impasse, Earl J. Silbert was confirmed by the Senate yesterday as United States Attorney for the District, of Columbia. The 84 to 12 vote came on a nomination that was first submitted by Richard M. Nixon and resubmitted three times by President Ford. Mr. Silbert has held the job on an acting basis since 1974.
Crude oil imports climbed to a high level in the week ended Oct. 3 as the oil companies moved to import oil before the price increase by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
WARSAW, Oct. 1 Poland's Communist leaders expect to have to perform some unpopular belt-tightening for their country soon and they are worried about the possible political consequences.

The American Broadcasting Company is involved in a dispute with its former White House correspondent over whether the network kept too close liaison with the White House during the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon.
CHATHAM, Mass., Oct. 8 (AP) Basil Brewer, former publisher of The New Bedford Standard-Times and other newspapers, died Sunday evening at his summer home here. He was 92 years old.
From Louisville to Baltimore to Denver, Dan Issel, the five-time All-Star forward of the American Basketball Association, hopes that's the end of his travels.

U.S. Pioneer Electronics, which spends more than $4million a year to advertise its high-fidelity components, has just named Scali, McCabe, Sloves as its agency. It is the seventh piece of new business to come into the agency this year and Marvin Sloves estimates that the shop, which ended 1974 with $28.2-million in billing, is now billing at an annual rate of $41-million.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 Last summer Fidel Castro was asked by James Reston of The New York Times about efforts to export his revolution to the rest of Latin America. He answered that he was doing no exporting it was the United States that was exporting counterrevolution.
I cannot say just why you did it, you and all the others. The hunger for soil, yes, but there must have been deeper hungers the eternal craving of man for rebirth, for the second chance.

Middle America is not exactly the fastest-moving target in the world. You don't have to be a sharpshooter to hit it. It just sits there like someone on a giant billboard, wearing an ear-toear grin, the eyes sparkling in anticipation of achieving some new plateau of pleasure, waiting to be defaced by anyone who has the price of a can of spray paint.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today softened his opposition to Federal intervention to ease New York City's fiscal crisis and proposed five guidelines for Congressional action.

Stock prices showed a slight upturn on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, moving up 0.36 to 84.07 as measured by the exchange's index. Volume was 1,588,000 shares, up from 1,352,000. In the over-the-counter market the NASDAQ industrial index closed at 81.23, up 0.80.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The Defense Department is circulating an intelligence estimate asserting that the Soviet Union is using the policy of detente to gain dominance over the west in all fields, Administration officials said today.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 8 The Knicks and the Nets played 48 minutes of basketball tonight to find out which players won't be around when the regular season opens. The Knicks have to cut three players and the Nets six.

HAWORTH, Oct. 8 (AP) The police paid today that they were seeking clues in the disappearance of a British engineer's 28-year-old wife. She was last seen two days ago in the garden of her home in this Bergen County community.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The flation's current $30.2-billion Federal general revenue-sharing program was praised and denounced at two Congressional hearings today, with municipal officials calling for its extension and representatives of civil-rights groups charging that it ignored antidiscrimination laws.
MADRID, Oct 8 Five persons were killed in Barcelona today when they were caught in an exchange of gunfire, according to an official police account.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (Reuters) The House of Representatives tonight approved a $3.8-billion military construction appropriations bill including funds for facilities on the British-owned island of Diego Garcia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) President Ford signed defense bills today authorizing spending of $34.6-billion for new weapons and military construction and authorizing women for the first time to enter military service academies.

A sense of urgency finally appears to be developing in Congress on the need for swift Federal action to head off default by New York City, with all its disastrous consequences for the national economy.
Four youths are being sought in the alleged rape of five young women in their West Side apartment early last Sunday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 8 (UPI) National Maritime Union pickets prevented the loading and unloading of a Puerto Rican container ship at the Blount Island container terminal today.
Two Democratic Presidential contenders and seven Democratic Senate prospects will share the dais at the annual Liberal party dinner tonight.

"It's the answer to my prayer," a very large woman sighed yesterday as she rode serenely up to street level in 36 seconds on one of the two parallel escalators just put into service at the Columbus Circle subway station.
A monument to the President who led the country out of the great Depression of the nineteen-thirties may become a victim of the recession of the seventies.

Chinese geologists, after scaling Mount Everest and roaming remote regions of Central Asia, have concluded as have American scientists "looking down" from space that Asia is the product of the collisions of at least three small continents. Cleanup operations continued yesterday at an East River pier where a barge lost about 35,000 gallons of No. 4 heating oil after striking a submerged object near North Brother Island.

A Japanese acupuncturist, a Dutch music critic, an Israeli author who had fought in the Soviet Army and a young American ex-convict were among a group of writers who received $1,000 prizes yesterday afternoon as winners of an unusual literary contest.

Outflows from the nation's savings institutions, which began in August, apparently accelerated in September as depositors continued to move their money into higher interest-earning investments elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 Key Ford Administration spokesmen made it clear today that President Ford expected his new tax and budget proposals to be a major issue in his campaign to retain the Presidency in 1976.

CALCUTTA, India The pavement dwellers of Calcutta, who are widely regarded as among the most destitute people in the world, lead a much more stable life than previously believed, according to a study sponsored by the World Health Organization.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 A defense attorney moved today for a dismissal of charges against Frank DeMarco Jr. on the ground of "prosecutorial misconduct" during the fourth week of Mr. DeMarco's trial here in Federal District Court.

TRENTON, Oct. 8 (AP) The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that law-enforcement officials using evidence in such cases must be able to show they had had the consent of an individual to conduct a warrantless search.
The suggested retail prices on 1976 Volkswagens will be going up by an average of $186, or 4.2 per cent, over comparably equipped 1975 models, Volkswagen of America...

HOUSTON, Oct. 8 Federal Energy Administrator Frank G. Zarb told skeptical natural gas utility executives today that Federal policy makers will give increased attention to natural gas utilities in mapping an energy program for the nation. Natural gas accounts for about one-third of the nation's energy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 Fred R. Harris, the former Oklahoma Senator who calls his campaign "a people's movement," moved today onto the lengthening list of Democratic Presidential candidates who report they have raised enough money to qualify for Federal subsidies for the primary campaign.

Roger Starr the city's Housing ahd Development Administrator . said yesterday that he doubted the effectiveness of proposed legislation that would permit foreclosure by the city of any property owner delinquent in real-estate taxes for one year.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., (AP) The San Antonio Wings of the World Football League voted today to take a reduction in pay ranging from 25 to 40 per cent.

Predicting a 21 per cent increase of industrywide car and truck sales in 1976 from this year, Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that he was "not willing to rule out" price increases during the new car model year.
There was some movement in all four of New Jersey's school strikes yesterday as negotiators began bargaining or scheduled meetings.

Leaders of the city's municipal labor unions said yesterday that they would consider a general strike to protest the three-year wage freeze and potential layoffs called for in the financial plan Mayor Beame has proposed to the Emergency Financial Control Board.

Prices advanced in more active trading in the stock market yesterday, with glamour and blue-chip issues leading the upturn.

OLDTOWN, Md., Oct. 8 (AP) Fred W. Morrison, a former radio and television newsman and director of public relations for the Republican National Committee, died today at his home here. He was 69 years old.

Buckley, Conservative, Republican of New York, said today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 (AP) Chilean refugees protesting against their living conditions in Argentina seized 14 hostages in the offices of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees here, then gradually released nine of them.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 8 (UPI) The dollar reversed a downward trend on most European money markets today, recovering part of the losses it has suffered this week. The price of gold fell to $139.25 an ounce, down from yesterday's $143.25 in Zurich and $143 in London.

Susan Brandeis Gilbert, a lawyer and daughter of the late Associate Justice Louis D. Brandeis of the Supreme Court, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 82 years old, lived at 404 Riverside Drive and was the widow of Jacob H. Gilbert, also a lawyer.
BOSTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) Two busloads of black students, protesting a lack of black teachers and policemen, refused to enter South Boston High School today, school officials said.

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 8 Supporters of Ronald Reagan for President opened New Hampshire headquarters today for the former California Governor to start his expected early primary challenge agains President Ford.

The American Paper Institute reported yesterday that paper and paperboard capacity by the end of 1975 would be 1.4 million tons lower than it had estimated a year ago. Norma Pace, senior vice president of the trade association, said that the annual survey now placed total capacity of 67.4 million tons, down from the 68.8 million tons.

Paul W. McCracken, a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Richard M. Nixon, suggested yesterday that the Federal Government should play a role in helping New York City escape from its fiscal crisis.
Franklin and Marshall of Lancaster, Pa., has won 15 consecutive football games for the longest small-college winning streak extant and second only to Oaklahoma's.
The man who leads the Minnesota Vikings in sacks of opposing quarterbacks said yesterday it would be "sort of like an honor" to dump Joe Namath on Sunday.
ATLANTA, Oct. 8 (AP) Bob Murdoch capped a threegoal second-period outburst tonight which helped the California Golden Seals defeat the Atlanta Flames 4-3, in a season opener.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 A delegation of mostly black politicians from the obscure and long-disputed territory of South-West Africa came to Washington this week to explain their conservative point of view and found that almost nobody would talk to them.

WASHINGON, Oct. 8 Millions of the nation's poorest households those with children and with incomes of $5,000, a year or less would be worse off under President Ford's proposed new tax program than they are now.
PARIS, Oct. 8 (Reuters) Spain's deputy military attache here was shot and seriously wounded today outside his apartment in a Paris suburb.

MOSCOW, Oct. 8 The Government newspaper Izvestia charged today that Washington cynically withheld criticism of Spain's executions of terrorists last week to obtain an agreement on American military bases there.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 Charging that Federal regulations force American travelers to pay unnecessarily high prices for their tickets, President Ford asked Congress today to reduce Government economic controls over domestic airlines.
Eugene V. Mori, a promoter who parlayed racetrack revenues into a multimillion-dollar business empire, died yesterday after a long illness at a nursing home in Medford, N.J. He was 77 years old.

Earnings of the Allied Chemical Corporation in the third quarter dropped 48.7 49 per cent from the year-earlier level, bringing the nine-month net 34 per cent below the 1974 period, the company reported yesterday. The diversified chemical producer, which has growing interests in oil, gas, coal and nuclear fuels, showed higher interest and other financial charges, and sharply reduced nonoperatng income for the nine-months.
Lay teachers voted last night to end their five-week walkout against five high schools in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and return to work this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The former general manager of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's Venezuelan subsidiary has charged in a suit that Armand Hammer, the corporation's chairman, caused Occidental to pay more than $3million in bribes and campaign contributions to Venezuelan Government officials and political candidates.

MORRISTOWN, Oct. 8 A Superior Court jury began deliberations late this afternoon to determine whether Donald A. Farinella and Edward Gola, two Passaic County Freeholders, accepted $7,000 in bribes to vote for the purchase of a commercial garage last year from Albert Scalettl.

MONTREAL, Oct. 8 (UPI) Guy LaFleur, Jacques LeMaire, Jim Roberts and Bob Gainey scored twice apiece tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 9-0 victory over the Los Angeles Kings. It was the season opener for both teams.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 After a 10-year decline into the pits of discarded fads, the skateboard is roaring back upon clear plastic wheels in a revival as unmistakable as a skinned elbow.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 8 The United States Department of Interior filed a trespassing suit today against 126 companies, including Alyeska Pipeline Service Company and a dozen other major oil companies, that could result in millions of dollars of settlement to Alaska's Eskimos on the North Slope.

Sylva Zalmanson, a 30-yearold woman who had been on a hunger strike and a daily vigil near the United Nations since Sept. 23, collapsed yesterday, sympathizers said, after receiving word that the Soviet Embassy had turned down her plea to visit her husband in a Soviet prison.
State officials yesterday were putting the final detail on a plan to enable the Housing Finance Agency to avoid default for another month.

Third-quarter merger announcements declined 19 per cent to 527 from 654 last year, according to a report yesterday of W.T. Grimm Co., Chicago-based merger consultant. In the first two quarters of this year respective drops of 34 per cent and 21 per cent were recorded.

NORTH PLAINFIELD, Oct. 9 A 19-year-old Plainfield youth was charged today with the murder of a 38-year-old mother of four children.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9 (AP) Jack Nicklaus defeated Tom Weiskopf, 2 and 1, to win the $117,500 International All-Star golf tournament today. The victory pushed Nicklaus's unofficial earnings this year past $300,000.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, Oct. 10 Christian and Moslem gunmen battled through the day here yesterday as Premier Rashid Karami sought help in neighboring Syria to end the sixmonth Lebanese crisis.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 When F. Emmett Fitzpatrick walked into Courtroom 2 in the old Federal Building here this morning, it was not as a man entering unfamiliar territory.

Stocks closed slightly higher on balance yesterday, with the list giving up some wider gains registered in early trading.
Paul O'Dwyer wore a tuxedo and a determined air of low-key amiability.
MOUNT PALOMAR Calif., Oct. 9 (UPI) The astronomer who discovered the 13th moon of Jupiter last year says he has found a 14th that is the smallest moon known.

Vito P. Battista, the former State Assemblyman who is running for a City Council seat from Brooklyn on the Republican and Conservative tickets, won support yesterday from the nonpartisan Citizens Union.

Bespectacled Sam Friedman, bundled up in anticipation of a chilly evening, sat inside his newsstand at the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 45th Street and talked about how the 23-day-old musicians' strike had affected his business.
