Nixon emerged from his seclusion at San Clemente today to play golf in a tournament that has drawn the high command of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and some men indentified by law enforcement sources as linked to organized crime.

PARIS, Oct. 9 Official Israeli sources said today that the attempt yesterday by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to modify its previous anti-Israeli actions was a "modest step in the right direction."

What do ballets like "Kettentanz," "As Times Goes By" and Interplay" have an common? Nothing. This range, of course, is one reason for the appeal of the City Center Joffrey Ballet, which presented all three works for the first time this season Wednesday night at the City Center.

Public buses lost one eighth of their passengers far more than the subways during the first full month of the new 50-cent fare compared with the same period in 1974, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 Democratic Governors from as far away as Colorado agreed with New York's Governor Carey today that New York City's financial crisis was a national problem in need of a federally aided solution.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 A five-month struggle between the District of Columbia Board of Education and Barbara A. Sizemore, the School Superintendent, ended here today with the dismissal of Mrs.Sizemore.
The American Telephone Telegraph Company disclosed yesterday that it had acquired for $18-million a site on Madison Avenue on which it is considering building a new corporate headquarters.
MADRID, Oct. 10 The Spanish Government announced the appointment of a tough new commander for the nation's paramilitary civil guard as part of increased efforts to suppress terrorist violence.
OLD BETHPAGE, L.I., Oct 9 People still make things with their hands. People still grow vegetables in their gardens. People still cook specialties from recipes handed down from their ancestors.

Nearly two years of intermittent and frustrating negotiations have now come to fruition in the Sinai peninsula. For the first time in three decades, Egypt and Israel are implementing a contract for co-existence dictated by their respective national interests rather than by any immediate military pressures.

Two managers of Times Square bookstores who had been arrested previously for dealing in pornographic material were among five men seized yesterday in raids by the Police Department's public morals division.
Monday is Columbus Day, marking the 483d anniversary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 New York state farmers suffered a 23 per cent drop in net income in 1974 and the downward trend is continuing in 1975, according to figures released here today by the New York Crop Reporting Service.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10 The award of a Nobel Peace Prize to Andrei D. Sakharov has given his crusade for democratic reform new impetus, cheered his embattled fellow dissidents and presented the Kremlin with a headache unlike any since Aleksandr 1. Solzhenitsyn was expelled 20 months ago.

BLAIRSVILLE, Ga. The ancient Chinese believed that ginseng, the man-root, was born one summer night when lightning struck a mountain stream, transforming it into heavenly fire in the form of a man, and that the stream then burst from the ground to serve as a cure for all mankind's illness.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 10 Ed Swicklas, the quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed for a third tonight as Southern Connecticut College scored a 21-6 victory over Western Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Air Force has told the mother of a pilot shot down over North Vietnam that she must pay $14.25 for documents relating to his disappearance, Representative Patricia Schroeder said today.

Three members of the Board of Estimate last night blocked a complicated state plan to save the Housing Finance Agency from default, saying that they wanted concessions from the state for the striking tenants of Co-op City before they would allow $20-million in state money to be channeled through Co-op City to the finance agency.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Financial pressures on the large field of Democratic Presidential candidates are threatening to narrow the competition even before the election year opens.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Retail sales rose very slightly in September, and revised figures also showed a small increase in August, the Commerce Department reported today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 10 (AP) The nation's recovery from recession will continue through 1976, the Business Council forecast today, but corporate leaders said a major economic shock such as the bankruptcy of New York City could upset the comeback.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 10 Gunmen continued to control the entrances and exits of this Lebanese capital today while Government officials and Palestinian guerrilla leaders exerted fresh efforts to bring about what Interior Minister Camille Chamoun described as a "decisive end to the crisis."

DETRIOT, Oct. 10 (UPI) President Ford called the disappearance of James R. Hoffa "a very strange case," today, but said he was optimistic on prospects that the Federal authorities would solve the mystery.

Upstate New York welfare caseloads soared 16.5 per cent in number of recipients and 33.4 per cent in costs for the first half of this year compared with a year ago. The rate of increase far surpassed New York City's rise of 3.5 per cent in numbers and 9.7 per cent in costs.
Philip M. Dearborn, author of a report on city financial emergencies, said yesterday that if New York City defaulted he did not foresee any other major cities "having problems as a result."

When is a balk not a balk? When Luis Tiant pitches, the American League insists. Millions of television viewers will have an opportunity to make their own judgments today when Tiant starts the World Series for the Red Sox. In making his pitch, Tiant covers the ball with the glove, his two hands together, and makes a kind of stuttering movement toward his belt.

OTTAWA, Oct. 10 The Canadian Government is planning a far-reaching economic recovery program that is expected to include steps to restrain wage and price increases and cut back on government spending.

Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, asserted yesterday that some judges had made "outright payment" as well as contributions to political parties to obtain nomination to the Queens judiciary.
ATLANTA, Oct. 10 Mark it down, Ranger fans: Tonight the Rangers took first place in the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League.
The inexperienced bridge player thinks of deals as being "exciting" in direct proportion to the level of the contract. Grand slams, they feel, are more exciting than small slams, and so on.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 An attempt to force New York City rapidly toward a balanced budget would hasten the exodus of businesses and middleand upper-income families from the city and make it harder for the city to support even a reduced level of public services, the Congressional Budget Office said today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (Reuters) The Soviet Union and Syria declared tonight that they were in complete agreement on the Middle East conflict.

Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach, Fla., was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Marie Brenda Lee to A.W.J. van der Mije of New York. The Rev. John G. Macort Jr. performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Roy F. Layton, who served as national president of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America from 1951 to 1957, died Wednesday in Arlington, Va. She was 77 years old and lived in Arlington.
While the Knickerbockers wait for the Wilt Chamberlain trial balloon to burst or take off in California, Neal Walk is tending to basketball business in New York.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10 (AP) Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf each won $8,000, Johnny Miller $5,000 and Lee Trevino drew a blank today in a $1,000-ahole exhibition among four of pro golf's leading career money-winners.

On the basis of the latest estimate of the total cost to the city of buying and rehabilitating Yankee Stadium, the Budget Bureau yesterday put the price tag at $66.4-million or $42.4-million more than the original estimate in 1971 by Mayor John V. Lindsay and almost $10-million more than has already been spent.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 The Oakland A's were absent for a change, but the Great Wall and baseball's balk rule were present today with intrigue and controversy as the Cincinnati Reds and Boston Red Sox braced to open the World Series tomorrow in 63-year-old Fenway Park.
VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 10 (AP) Hale Irwin and Al Geiberger staged strong finishes today and set up an all-American final in the Piccadilly world match play golf tournament.

President Ford's news conference Thursday night had an audience of approximately 2.5 million in the New York area, according to the Nielsen overnight ratings for this area. The national ratings will not be available for several days, but projections by Marvin Mord, vice president of research for ABC-TV, are that the televised news conference reached a total audience of around 46 million viewers nationally.
MORRISTOWN, Oct. 10 Opposing legal briefs were filed in Superior Court here today in the fight over the life of Karen Anne Quinlan, the young woman in a coma.
DETROIT, Oct. 10 (Reuters) President Ford today suggested that New Yorkers should be more careful in the future in choosing their representatives in city government.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 10 (AP) Did this resort get cheated when it paid $85,000 for a model of a 19th-century ship?

Savers withdrew money from the nation's mutual savings banks at an accelerated pace in September, according to a preliminary report released yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 10 The free lunch continued its decline as a Westchester institution today with an announcement that jurors, begining Nov. 3, will pay for their ow midday meal.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10? Emily and William Harris, members of the self-styled Symbionese Liberation Army who were captured on Sept. 18, were arraigned in Superior Court here today. However, their pleas to an 11-count indictment were postponed a week so that their lawyers could review the grand jury transcript that has just became available.
BOSTON, Oct. 10 Near the batting cage at Fenway Park today, Johnny Bench looked up at The Wall in left field.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 10 Israel today signed the protocol of the new Sinai accord with Egypt and set in motion the process that will lead to her withdrawal from some 1,900 square miles of occupied Egyptian territory over the next five months.

Finding a backgammon board to your taste shouldn't pose a problem at the Gammon Shop. Raymond Tekosky, owner of the emporium devoted exclusively to the ancient game of chance and skill reckons he has some 75 different styles of boards, and that's not taking into account differences of color within any one category.

Concern over the outlook for the securities of New York State, once a proud triple-A that commanded the unquestioned respect of investors, has intensified as the result of the state's growing involvement in New York City's fiscal crisis.

Samuel Greene, a businessman who in his 70's started the Penny Foundation, a loan program to improve the living conditions of the improvished in rural Guatemala, died Tuesday evening at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J., and Guatemala.

Wheat, corn and soybean futures continued to show little change yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders awaited the important Department of Agriculture crop report dus after the close of trading. Most guessed correctly that crop estimates would be raised from September levels.

Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, asserted yesterday that some judges had made "outright payment" as well as contributions to political parties to obtain nomination to the Queens judiciary.

CPC International, Inc., the world's largest corn refiner, reported yesterday profit in creases of 23 per cent for the quarter and 22 per cent for the nine months on sales rises of 10 and 11 per cent, respectively.
As many as 150,000 people will troop up Fifth Avenue tomorrow and Monday in honor of Christopher Columbus, and the prospect has rekindled protests from residents along the parade route.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 10 Margaret Thatcher, leader of the Conservative party today termed Prime Minister Harold Wilson's policies a "disaster" and pledged to reverse the Labor party's economic program.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 10 Gov. George C. Wallace is scheduled to head for Western Europe late tomorrow on a two-week trip that he hopes will convince voters that he is healthy enough to run for President and well informed not only on national but also on international issues.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) Undersecretary of Commerce, James A. Baker 3d, said today a joint United States-Iranian commission has tentatively agreed to increase by 73 per cent over the next five years the volume of nonmilitary, non-oil trade between the two nations.

The rabbinic organization of American Reform Judaism yesterday announced the publication of its first new prayer book in 80 years. The book, issued by the Central Conference of American Rabbis, has more Hebrew prayers than its predecessor and takes cognizance of the Holocaust and the establishment of the State of Israel.

A state trooper was charged yesterday with having recklessly discharged a shotgun creating "a grave risk of death to another person" during the retaking of Attica prison from rebelling inmates in 1971.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange weakened in quiet trading yesterday, while prices in the over-the-counter market finished mixed as volume there also fell.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 President Ford sent Congress today a plan for a $100-billion Government corporation to help finance projects to make the United States independent of foreign sources of energy by 1985.

Frederick Delius's "A Village Romeo and Juliet," that strange dreamlike pastoral tragedy, was never destined to become a popular work. It is dramatically too fragile and musically too undulant and ruminative to stir the average listener. It had to wait almost three-quarters of a century after it was composed to get a staging here, two years ago by the New York City Opera.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 10 Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, ordered last night an immediate halt to talks on nationalization compensation between the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Government until reports about an alleged bribery of Venezuelan officials were clarified.

Bruce E. Mather, director of training for customer services for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Williamsburg, Va., where he was attending a business conference. He was 49 years old and lived in New Providence, N.J.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 10 A parliamentary committee of South Korea's National Assembly today approved a motion seeking to oust an opposition legislator who criticized president Park Chung Hee and his policies on the assembly floor early this week.

MADRID, Oct. 10 (AP) Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, Manuel Orantes of Spain and Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the three top-seeded players, were defeated today in the quarterfinals of the Madrid Grand Prix tennis tournament.
The stock market yesterday went through what might best be described as a "nothing day."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 10 Opposing legal briefs were filed in Superior Court here today in the fight over the life of Karen Anne Quinlan, the young woman in a coma.

MADRID, Oct. 10 (Reuters) Manuel Orantes of Spain, the United States Open tennis champion, signed today to meet Jimmy Connors, America's top-ranked player, in Las Vegas, Nev., next Feb. 28 in a challenge match worth at least $250,000 to the winner and $100,000 to the loser.
TOKYO, Oct. 10 Young men go West. At the ago of 83, the master French fashion illustrator Erte has gone East.

On the basis of the latest estimate of the total cost to the city of buying and rehabilitating Yankee Stadium, the Budget Bureau yesterday put the price tag at $66.4-million or $42.4-million more than the original estimate in 1971 by Mayor John V. Lindsay and almost $10-million more than has already been spent.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10 (AP) Dr. Norman Levinson, a mathematics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for 38 years, died today at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 63 years old.

The question of whether New York's pending Equal Rights Amendment represents better Opportunities and justice for all or a threat to privileges long enjoyed by American women was debated last night by State Senator Carol Bellamy, a proponent, and Barbara Ann Keating of the Conservative Party.
LISBON, Saturday, Oct. 11 Portugal's coalition Government warned yesterday that it would punish "those responsible for the escalation of violence, especially by members of minority political groups."

Long before the sale opened yesterday morning, it was standing room only in the auction tent behind Giraldo, the turn-of-the-century chateau in Madison, N.J., that was the late Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge's home for 62 years.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 10 The Islamic Conference, a group of 42 countries with a common religious and cultural heritage, gained permanent observer status in the United Nations today.

Elmar Oliveira, a 25-year-old violinist, was named winner of the string competition conducted by the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation in Carnegie Hall yesterday. His prize includes $1,500, two recitals in Alice Tully Hall and a management contract with the Judd Concert Artist Bureau. He has been a pupil of Raphael Bronstein at the Manhattan School of Music.
A meeting of the American Basketball Association board of trustees here broke up yesterday without any clear indiction that accord had been reached on the Dan Issel trade.
Bloomingdale's will, very soon, make the act of spending money a virtue.

COIMBRA, Portugal, Oct. 10 At the end of a long, frenetic day Wednesday, the Socialist leader, Mario Soares, and a carload of aides pulled into the one roadside restaurant that was still open on the way back to Lisbon.
MIAMI, Oct. 10 (AP) Dave Williams, a quarterback, scored on a one-yard sneak tonight that gave Colorado a 7-3 half-time lead, then guided the Buffaloes to a 23-10 football victory over Miami.

One certain result of banking legislation now before both houses of Congress would be a widening of consumer choice and institutional competition in personal banking habits. Less certain, but worth anticipating all the same, is a potential enlargement of the pool of funds available for mortgage lending in the nation's cities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it would make a new attempt to find out whether Red No. 2, the country's most widely used food coloring, causes cancer.
A trial on contempt charges against four negotiators for the Elizabeth Education Association was recessed yesterday until next Tuesday by Judge Harry Osborne Jr., in Union County Superior Court.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 10 Clifford Allen, the 69-year-old Nashville-Davidson County tax assessor and former State Senator, won easily the House nomination yesterday to fill the Fifth District House vacancy caused by the resignation of Richard Fulton.

The tradition of two separate Columbus Day parades with the Hispanic organizations marching on Sunday and the Italian groups on the official holiday, has never done much to enhance the idea of "one nation indivisible...."

The Beame administration obtained an oral commitment from the regional office of the United States Department of Labor yesterday for Federal funds to rehire more than 2,000 municipal employes who were laid off in the city's fiscal crisis.

DALLAS, Oct. 10 (AP) A freshman safety, David Hill, tipped away a 2-point conversion pass and returned an intercepted pass for a touchdown late in the fourth period tonight, carrying Southern Methodist to a 2813 Southwest Conference victory. It was Texas Christian's 15th consecutive loss.

ATHENS Constantine Caramanlis readily acknowledges to friends that the most impressive man he ever met was Charles de Gaulle. The first time he saw the general when the Greek statesman was Premier and not yet a political exile in Paris de Gaulle guided him to a chair, sat across from him, hands folded across his stomach, and said: "I am listening. What do you want?"
At latest count, the village of Lucas in the central Kansas grain belt had 595 citizens. One of them was J. Rex Duwe, who as president of the Farmers State Bank there is a leading local businessman.

Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, called yesterday for "a sustained Federal policy effort to achieve greater equality" for black economic and other minority enterprises.
In early celebration of the Navy's 200th birthday Monday, a precision drill team performed on the steps of City Hall yesterday before 200 noontime strollers.

Myra Francis is no longer the guidance counselor at Public School 87. The void she left with her unexpected departure last month makes tangible the ways that the city's fiscal crisis affects children.
The 3,500 pilots for financially pressed Trans World Airlines have won a 7 per cent wage increase but they will wait a year before collecting it.

The Beame administration obtained an oral commitment from the regional office of the United States Department of Labor yesterday for Federal funds to rehire more than 2,000 municipal employes who were laid off in the city's fiscal crisis.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

The National Council of Churches took a major step yesterday toward categorical opposition to large-scale future use of plutonium in nuclear power plants as "morally indefensible and technically objectionable."

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 10 A black candidate for Governor has demanded an investigation of what he called "selling of degrees" by the recently resigned director of records at the largely black Jackson State University.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 Simone Weil is not in the calendar of saints, and nothing save the example of her life seems likely to put her there.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 10 The police chief of suburban Jefferson County said today that he had made a "strong recommendation" to the Secret Service last week that a planned visit to Louisville by President Ford be canceled because of possible security risks posed by crowds of antibusing demonstrators.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10 The Agriculture Department released today a new estimate of record corn and wheat harvests that appeared to be large enough to accommodate resumed grain sales to the Soviet Union.

The deadline for the city's 32 community school districts to comply with the central Board of Education's orders for them to cut two class sessions a week passed yesterday, but the central board refused to disclose how many districts had failed to meet the 3 P.M. deadline.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said today that Federal aid to New York was gaining support in the Senate.
Gerry Wright, a freshman, scored two touchdowns tonight in the leading Brooklyn College to a 41-22 victory over Manhattan, in a Met Eight Conference game at the winner's field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 A key element of the plan of Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon for meeting New York City's financial problem a moratorium, of stretching out of the city's debt would require a change in the country's bankruptcy law Mr. Simon has said.

PARIS, Oct. 10 President Ford and the leaders of several other major Western nations will hold a three-day economic summit conference in the Paris area Nov. 15 through 17, it was announced today in Paris and Washington.

BLAIRSVILLE, Ga. The ancient Chinese believed that ginseng, the man-root, was born one summer night when lightning struck a mountain stream, transforming it into heavenly fire in the form of a man, and that the stream then burst from the ground to serve as a cure for all mankind's illness.

Sara Murphy, widow of Gerald Murphy and the model for Nicole in F. Scott Fitzgerald's "Tender Is the Night," died yesterday of pneumonia in the Arlingiton (Va.) Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived at 1113 Basil Road, McLean, Va.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, announced today that President Ford had agreed to meet with "antibusing leaders in Congress to discuss how to stop the courts from ordering the busing of school children to achieve racial balance.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 10 (UPI) A superior court judge has dismissed eight felony charges against Representative Andrew J. Hinshaw, Republican of California, but ordered Mr. Hinshaw to stand trial next month on three remaining bribery counts.

"I hope my enthusiasm will rub off, it always did everywhere else I managed," said Dave Bristol yesterday after he became the eighth manager of the Atlanta Braves since they moved south from Milwaukee in 1966. Bristol, 42 years old, managed at Cincinnati from 1966 to 1969 and at Milwaukee from 1970 until May, 1972. He signed a one-year contract.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 The White House and the State Department today announced an $85-million package of emergency economic aid for Portugal after Foreign Minister Ernesto Melo Antunes met with President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger at the White House and later separately with Mr. Kissinger.

DETROIT, Oct. 10 President Ford, accelerating his attack on what he called a "can't-do Congress," said here tonight that his plan to cut both taxes and Government spending next year would offer special help to lower-and middle-income Americans."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 10 Gov. George C. Wallace is scheduled to head for Western Europe late tomorrow on a two-week trip that he hopes will convince voters that he is healthy enough to run for President and well informed not only on national but also on international issues.
TRENTON, Oct. 10 (AP) Capt. Clinton L. Pagano of Milford was named by Governor Byrne to be the superintendent of the New Jersey state police. He is 47 years old and a 23year veteran of the force.

With a police helicopter overhead and police sharpshooters patrolling rooftops, Emperor Hirohito and Empress Nagako took a fast tour of rain-drenched San Francisco yesterday just like any tourists with an 18car motorcade. JapaneseAmerican speakers recalled that the first 12 Japanese immigrants to this country arrived there in 1867, and one stop for the visitors was the city's new Nihon-Machi, or Japan Center, a high-rise housing and commercial complex with a peace pagoda.

Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, yesterday requested that both sides in the Broadway musicians' strike meet today at noon at Gracie Mansion, where the mediator is scheduled "to make a statement."

The strongest inhibitions in the past five weeks of Congressional deliberation have stemmed from Congressional distrust of executive branch intentions. HAWORTH, Oct. 10 (UPI) The police say the missing 28year-old wife of a British engineer apparently was looking for a job before she disappeared Monday.

Warning that default by New York City would have "an almost disastrous impact on all the countries of the world," former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally called yesterday for creation of a new Federal agency to channel funds here to avoid it.

RADISSON, N.Y. Frank Williams, a black construction contractor, is angry. Not because of an inability to obtain contracts now, but because of fear of what will happen in the future.

Clifford O'Sullivan, who as a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit at Cincinnati figured in a number of major desegregation decisions, died Tuesday in a Detroit hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Port Huron, Mich.
DETROIT, Oct. 10 The mysterious disappearance of James R. Hoffa has spawned another mystery.

PARIS, Oct. 10 President Ford and the leaders of several other major Western nations will hold a three-day economic summit conference in the Paris area Nov. 15 through 17, it was announced today in Paris and Washington.
Nissan U.S.A. has raised the price of its 1976 Datsuns, which will go on sale next week, an average of 4.9 per cent, or $179, above the price of the 1975 Datsuns, the company announced yesterday.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 10 A microphone dangled from a firetruck ladder beside the black slate church steeple, and on the street below a mobile noisetesting laboratory from the State Department of Environmental Protection was poised to record the sounds.
Foolish Pleasure became a millionaire yesterday at Belmont Park, but not the way the horseplayers had hoped.
Erich Baer, a research chemist who had achieved many advances in synthetics, died Sept. 23 in Toronto, where he had lived. He was 74 years old.

Emanuel Davis, a pioneer in animated cartoons, who was long associated with the late Paul H. Terry in creating Terrytoons, with Mighty Mouse and the crows Heckle and Jeckle, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in the Benjamin Franklin Hotel.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 10 (UPI) Lynette Alice Fromme was given a new cocounsel today, but a Federal judge denied her request to visit the Federal Bureau of Investigation office to look at news film of her allegedly trying to assassinate President Ford.

HOUSTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) Three gunmen and officers of an elite police team fought a two-hour gun battle today at a frame house near the Houston Ship Channel. The three gunmen and one policemen were killed and another officer was wounded.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 10? With an ear-shattering display of locally produced jet fighters, helicopters, tanks and artillery, Taiwan celebrated today its first national day without its long-time leader. President Chiang Kai-shek.

Peter Serkin not only is one of our more gifted younger pianists but has long been a leader in protesting the stale traditions and customs of modern concert life. When he appeared as soloist with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night, for instance, he typically wore his hair tied back, Sioux-fashion, and he sported an outsized, multicolored necktie. The orchestra and Pierre Boulez look pretty stuffy in their black ties and drab dinner jackets.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 10 (AP) The Wilmington Federation of Teachers ratified a new contract tonight, ending a 28day strike, the longest by public employes in the state's history.

Its ziggurat profile bristles with slowly twirling radar antennas and thick coils of barbed wire. In the distance, the apartment towers of Port Fuad and Port Said poke into the midday haze.

A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a motion to shift the bankruptcy proceedings of the W.T. Grant Company from the voluntary Chapter XI provisions to Chapter X, in which a court-appointed trustee would administer the company's affairs.

Randolph H. Newman, a New York lawyer who specialized in reparation cases, died Thursday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1 Gracie Terrace.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday as many traders appeared confused over the economic situation. However, prices advanced in the over-the-counter market in heavy trading.

The Fairtree Gallery, the largest gallery in New York devoted exclusively to the exhibition and sale of crafts, will close its doors permanently on Jan. 31. Steady losses and lack of further funding were given as the reasons.

Sylvia Marlowe is an honored veteran among harpsichordists, above all for the new works she has commissioned and her performing collaborations with other artists. REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 15 (Reuters) Iceland proclaimed new fishing limits in effect today, extending them from 50 to 200 miles off her coasts and becoming the first European country to claim so wide a zone.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Several authoritative Administration officials say the talks with the Soviet Union on strategic arms limitations are in trouble.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Oct. 15 Yesterday's disclosure that the late John M. Bailey had allegedly accepted a $200,000 cash payment to help a Bridgeport jai alai fronton obtain a state gaming license sent waves of disbelief through this state's political community today.

Honeywell, Inc., and the Xerox Corporation announced yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement on the assumption by Honeywell of responsibility for the worldwide servicing and marketing support for the mainframe computer business of Xerox.

About 1,000 severely emotionally disturbed children who entered special private schools Sept. 4 will be forced to leave them tomorrow, destined for public-school programs that city education official admit will not be ready for up to six weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 From 2,000 to 3,000 more Indochinese refugees are expected to arrive in the United States in the next two weeks, bringing the total destined for resettlement here to about 134,000 by Christmas, Administration officials said today.

The Federal Government's Office for Civil Rights has begun an "intensive on-site investigation" of six city community school districts here to determine whether school children have been discriminated against because of race, national origin or physical handicaps.

Nearly 60 per cent of the city's $12.3-billion budget goes to pay for the 300,000 or so public employes who do everything from putting out fires to selecting the music on WNYC. This year's price tag for them will be $7.3-billion because each worker costs the city a lot individually and because there are so many of them.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15 Hamilton Shirley Amerasinghe, Sri Lanka's chief delegate, was chosen today by the Asian regional group for the presidency of the next General Assembly, which is slated by rotation to go to an Asian candidate. The group is made up of 35 members, including China.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 Between drinks at the World Series, where memories invariably lengthen in direct proportion to the reduction of whisky in the glass, two oldtimers were arguing the identity of baseball's most celebrated slave dealer.

"Family Portrait Sittings" is an album of reminiscences that is as much about the processes of remembering as it is about the things remembered. The featurelength documentary, which opened a week's engagement at the Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday, is the work of Alfred Guzzetti, currently visiting associate professor of film at the State University of New York at Purchase.
Gladys M. Wrigley, editor for 29 years of the American Geographical Society's quarterly, The Geographical Review, died last Thursday in New Milford, Conn. She was 90 years old.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 15 President Isabel Martinez de Peron returned here today from a five-week leave of absence despite efforts by most political factions to persuade her to step down.

TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 15 (UPI) Tony Trabert, captain of the United State Davis Cup tennis team, has selected Jimmy Connors and Roscoe Tanner for the singles and Dick Stockton and Erik van Dillen for the doubles in the second-round series with Venezuela beginning tomorrow at the Racquet Club Ranch.

A campaign to bring courtesy and chivalry back to America in is Bicentennial year has just been begun by the almanac editor who persuaded the United States Postal Service to restore place names to postmarks.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 14 Muhammad Ali and his own story, "The Greatest," has taken on the 1975 Frankfurt Book Fair and won. The German publisher Willy Droemer, looking groggy at 4 A.M. after an all-night session the other day with Random House, Ali's American publishers, emerged to tell reporters at the Frankfurter Hof Hotel that he had bought Germanlanguage rights for $200,000.
ATLANTA Chef Franz Victor Eichenauer does not fear the French. It is the Japanese.

HONOLULU, Oct, 15 (AP) Former President Lon Nol of Cambodia says he does not blieve reports that his brother, Gen. Lop Non, was killed by an angry mob when Phnom Penh fell to the Communists last April.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Students as a group are not given to enthusiasms these days. They are romantic about neither existing institutions nor imagined substitutes law students, one might think, least of all. So there was, something surprising, and possibly significant, in the reaction of a group of law students who visited the Supreme Court the other day to hear a case argued.
A man named Jones set a world record by buying a horse for $730,000 at Belmont Park yesterday, and then said in all earnestness, "I'm obviously very pleased with the price."

Newspaper, television and radio advertisements by some savings banks in recent weeks have focused the attention of many New Yorkers on a relatively new type of "checking" account. They have also renewed the long running battle between savings institutions and commercial banks over these accounts.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 15 The city of Elizabeth moved to enjoin its firemen from continuing an allegedly illegal "sick-out" today, and then withdrew its suit when the Union County Superior Court Judge, Harold A. Ackerman, refused to grant an immediate injunction.

A 34-year-old police officer was slightly injured yesterday as he sought to rescue three black youths from a crowd of 150 white youths who had been pursuing them in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. One of the pursuers, a 15-yearold, was arrested.
Danny Murtaugh, the cigarsmoking, rocking-chair manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, said yesterday in Cincinnati that he would return to his job for the 1976 National League season.
President Ford will answer questions from newsmen on a special one-hour anniversary edition of "Meet the Press," Sunday morning, Nov. 9, on NBC-TV.

New and Newer Music, a series that has been presented in Alice Tully Hall by Lincoln Center, will be moved this season to the small auditorium in the Lincoln Center Library. It will be presented on four Thursday evenings at 7:30 P.M.
HACKENSACK, Oct. 15 (AP) A Superior Court judge here sentenced 26 teachers and a custodian to 10 days in jail for contempt today as teachers' strikes continued in Elizabeth and Bergen County.

George C. Miles, an Islamic scholar and a former director of the American Numismatic Society, died yesterday of cancer at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Ardsleyon-Hudson, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Vice President Rockefeller met today with President Ford and described as "minimal" their differences over Federal aid to New York, saying that their relationship had "never been better."

Two police officers were shot in the hallway of a Brooklyn apartment building last night by a youth who fired a single shotgun blast moments after the policemen had taken a weapon at gunpoint from another teen-ager, according to the police.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The Federal Reserve Board announced today a reduction in reserve requirements against long-term time and savings deposits at member banks.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 (UPI) Joao Oliveira of Brazil, benefitting from Mexico City's altitude and rarified air in much the same way Bob Beamon did seven years ago, triple jumped an unbelievable 58 feet 8 inches today to set the first world record at the Pan-American Games.
Mayor Beame is scheduled to lay the cornerstone today for the New York Sports Center, described by its developer as the largest facility in the world for participant sports.

A Federal grand jury has indicted eight persons, including two reputed underworld figures, two union officials and two leaders of a trucking association, on charges of conspiracy and extortion in an alleged shakedown operation in the garment district.

The Northrop Corporation, the West Coast-based aerospace and electronics producer, reported yesterday profit increases of 44 per cent in the third quarter and 42.6 per cent in the first nine months, both setting records. Sales increased 16.8 and 15.8 per cent in the third quarter and nine months.
The Reynolds Metals Company reported yesterday that's its third-quarter net income had fallen by 64.8 per cent as sales dropped by 17.7 per cent.
Marie-Louise Valentin Bousquet, Paris editor of Harper's Bazaar for 50 years and a longtime force in the Parisian fashion and literary scene, died Monday in her Paris home. She was 88 years old.

City fiscal officials won a partial commitment from savings banks yesterday to make up a shortfall on immediate borrowing requirements, but they found themselves $56-million short as they faced a deadline tomorrow for producing the needed cash.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 When Robert Meola, of Grosse Pointe, Mich., applied to Peoples College of Law in Los Angeles, he listed qualifications that he knew would win points with the admissions committee. At Michigan State University, he had bean a member of the Students for a Democratic Society, and, after graduating, had worked in child care for two years in Pontiac, Mich.

PHILADELPHIA In Stanley Kubrick's film "2001," an unusually transparent and memorable scene depicts a corporate-executive type who (as I recall) approaches a mirrored communicator and utters his complex message, which is then instantaneously translated into Russian, presumably by a hidden computer, and transmitted miles away to an interlocutor.

The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the rule-making body for the accounting profession adopted yesterday accounting rules for companies to follow in translating foreign currencies into United States dollars as well as rules covering intangible dilling and development costs.

QUEBEC In mid-1974 the government of predominantly French-speaking Quebec made French its official language, giving it precedence over English for virtually all governmental, commercial and legal purposes in this huge eastern province, Canada's largest.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 15 (Reuters) Australia headed for a constitutional crisis tonight after Prime Minister Gough Whitlam defied an Opposition ultimatum that it would stop the supply of money to his Labor Government until he called a general election.
Kenneth D. McCormick, the senior consultant editor at Doubleday, hates big parties, but yesterday he went to one anyway. He had to; the party was for him.

Governor Byrne agreed, yesterday to waive a time eligibility requirement that could have prevented Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis from applying for pardons of their triple-murder convictions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 A behind-the-scenes effort by the State Department to shore up the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire with an emergency infusion of $60million has so far failed to win Congressional backing.

At the recently ended New York Film Festival, one movie not reviewed by the press was a five-minute short from Canada called "Thanks Giving." Directed by Ken Wallace, "Thanks Giving" was filmed from the point of view of a turkey plucked and ready for the oven, with two sad, knowing eyes inserted into its hindquarters.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 With one of the liveliest disputes in the 72-year history of the World Series in the background, Luis Tiant took center stage tonight and pitched Boston to a 5-4 triumph over Cincinnati that put the Red Sox on even terms with the Reds after four games.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 Larry Barnett, the umpire involved in last night's controversial 10th-inning bunt play, said tonight it was the toughest call he has ever had to make but he would make it the same way again.
Prices of wheat, corn and soybeans declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders awaited news on further Soviet grain deals.

Political attacks on school busing are smothering the real issues of school integration under a blanket of misleading oratory on both sides. The basic questions remain: how to put an end to discriminatory policies which condemn minority children to attend inferior schools and how to enlist public education more effectively in the creation of an integrated society.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Watergate prosecutors argued today that Richard M. Nixon's inability to testify at the trial of four officials in his administration who were convicted in the cover-up of the incident did not give the defendants a right to a new trial.

Nearly 60 per cent of the city's $12.3-billion budget goes to pay for the 300,000 or so public employes who do everything from putting out fires to selecting the music on WNYC. This year's price tag for them will be $7.3-billion because each worker costs the city a lot individually and because there are so many of them.

It should always be remembered that impressions of British television in this country tend to be severely distorted. Program imports are generally limited to the best available. Actually, anyone sitting through a full average day of TV in Britain is likely to be confronted with as much mediocrity as can be found in the American counterpart. It's simply that the British high spots tend to be a bit higher with admirable consistency.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The White House directed the Secret Service today to submit a full report explaining why President Ford's limousine was struck broadside by another vehicle last night in Hartford.
Turtle! Rabbit! the children call out, even though on stage the characters are properly referred to as the Tortoise and Hare of the play's title.

With bitter complaint and a caution to city residents to retain their "grace under pressure," Mayor Beame submitted yesterday to a state austerity mandate and proposed fresh budget cuts totaling $200.7million that, he said, would further shrink city services and force additional layoffs "in the thousands."

JEFFERSON, Iowa, Oct. 13 All day long and long after dark, Middlewestern farmers were rushing this week to gather in their share of a bumper corn and soybean crop. But, while they did so, they were angrily waiting for the Russians.

A mud-hut village in a Botswana game preserve was chosen by Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton for their remarriage last Friday, it was confirmed yesterday by the district commissioner who officiates, Ambrose Masalila, a member of the Tswana tribe. The small country in southern Africa was formerly the British territory of Bechuanaland.

Whoever first said, "The thought is stronger than its execution," really knew what he was talking about. Countless games are lost because of overestimating a threat that, at most, required a minor concession or worse, none at all.

A Federal grand jury has indicted eight persons, including two reputed underworld figures, two union officials and two leaders of a trucking association, on charges of conspiracy and extortion in an alleged shakedown operation in the garment district.

TRENTON, Oct. 15 Gover- nor Byrne has restored his Secretary of State, G. Edward Crabiel, to a major position in his administration, ending the political exile the Governor imposed on him after Mr. Crabiel was indicted last year.

Members of The Daily News unit of the Newspaper Guild yesterday authorized officers of the union to call a strike against the paper "when and if they see fit." A vote on whether to authorize a strike is scheduled today by guild members of The New York Times.
CAIRO, Oct. 15 Syria, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization today boycotted the opening of a conference of Arab foreign ministers seeking to settle the communal strife in Lebanon.
American Tobacco apparently would rather switch than fight and has switched its Tareyton cigarette brand out of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn and into SSC

"Christy," the new Bernie Spiro-Lawrence J. Blank musical based on John Millington Synge's "The Playboy of the Western World," applauds itself as "a darlin' musical about a daring deed," but there is nothing darlin' about it.

Three men, one carrying a shotgun, beat and robbed patrons of an Upper West Side bar last night, according to the police, but were caught at the scene by police units answering a hidden alarm set off by a barmaid.

The board of the Otis Elevator Company has unanimously, decided that the offer of $42 a share for 4.5-million shares of Otis made by the United Technologies Corpora- tion "is totally in- adequate and not in the best interests of the company or its shareholders." Ralph A. Weller, chairman of Otis, said yesterday.

The Rangers picked on the slumping Atlanta Flames again last night, beating them, 3-1, for their first victory of the season at Madison Square Garden. The loss was the Flames' third in a row, two of them to New York.
Charles (Swede) Risberg, one of eight baseball players barred for life in the 1919 Chicago "Black Sox" scandal, died at a convalescent home in Red Bluff, Calif., on Monday, his 81st birthday.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it was reducing its per-copy charges by 10 per cent on its Copier II office copier machines. Minimum and maximum monthly charges will be unchanged.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 15 Somewhat to the surprise of many members of the American press, there is a growing split in their ranks over how to handle confrontations between the press and the courts.

FOOTLIGHT SALUTE That charming old comedy "The Pursuit of Happiness," a Broadway hit in 1934, won equally good reviews as a movie the same year (costarring Joan Bennett and Francis Lederer) and the property would seem to have vanished at least until tonight.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 The teams didn't squabble with the umpires or collide with the catcher or hit six home runs in the World Series game tonight. But paunchy old Luis Tiant did throw 163 pitches at the Cincinnati Reds while the Boston Red Sox scored five runs in the fourth inning and hung on for a 5-4 victory that deadlocked the Series at two games apiece.
PARIS, Oct. 15 A new work by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, "Lenin in Zurich," is to be issued here tomorrow, in Russian, by Y.M.C.A. Press.
Net income of the Eastman Kodak Company rose 14.3 per cent in the third quarter to $183.48-million, or $1.14 a share, from $160.55-million, equal to $1 a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

Frank Palmer Pendleton, president of Vac-u-Max, Inc., of Belleville, N.J., a manufacturer of cleaning and conveying equipment, died yesterday in a nursing home in Cedar Grove, N.J. He was 68 years old and lived in Verona, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The White House directed the Se- cret Service today to submit a full report explaining why President Ford's limousine was struck broadside by another vehicle last night in Hartford.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 A milestone on the road away from the unnatural disaster known as Watergate will be passed quietly this month when Earl J. Silbert puts his hand on a Bible and solemnly swears, for the second time, to uphold the Constitution as United States Attorney for the District of Columbia.
Kenneth D. McCormick, the senior consultant editor at Doubleday, hates big parties, but yesterday he went to one anyway. He had to; the party was for him.

Students entering business school these days, whether in New York City, London or Moscow, are well advised to have a good foundation in mathematics, including calculus and matrix algebra, to prepare them for the revolution in economics that has created the new field of scientific managerial decision-making.
The Treasury's auction of $3billion in two-year notes today will bring investors an average yield of slightly below 8 per cent, Wall Street analysts predicted yesterday.

BAYVILLE, N.Y. Most Northern liberals do not favor busing. Their resistance to busing is based on resistance to the culture of what Whitney Young called "the black underclass," on resistance to large-scale social engineering, and on the selection of children as the subjects of coercion. Integration is not resisted. The instrument of busing is resisted.

Financial planning at the Urban Development Corporation was so haphazard for much of its existence that the agency committed itself to spending huge sums of money that it did not know it could raise, and even lent money at a lower rate of interest than it had to pay to borrow the money, an independent accountant said yesterday.
Jacques Charon, a leading member of the Comedie Francaise and a director of the company, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home in Paris. He was 55 years old.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) A plan to merge the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the second largest commodity futures market in the world, with the International Monetary Market was approved unanimously today by the boards of both exchanges.

Four former employes of the Franklin National Bank pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges of having been involved in a $30-million misapplication of the bank's funds for speculation in foreign currency. Four other men await trial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today rules requiring 10,500 corporations to disclose publicly whether they are illegally polluting the nation's air and waterways.
ATHENS, Oct. 15 (AP) Pollution over 40 years has caused greater damage to the ancient monuments on the Acropolis than they suffered in the four centuries previous, a United Nations report said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Northrop Corporation spent $9.9-million on "questionable costs" including a yacht and a hunting lodge to lift sales to the United States and foreign governments between 1971 and 1974, according to a Pentagon report released today.

Alexander's, Inc., one of New York's largest retail chains, reported yesterday that it has been apprised of an impending offer for the company's common stock from an unidentified source. Alexander's common stock was halted on the New York Stock Exchange pending news.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15 New fighting between Christian and Moslem factions erupted early today in downtown Beirut and in outlying neighborhoods and sputtered throughout the day.

The carpenters were still at work yesterday and some of the desks and other staff facilities semed makeshift, but the chances appeared good that the First Women's Bank would open today after a series of delays lasting more than a year.
Two major drug companies Pfizer, Inc., and Merck Co. yesterday reported gains in sales and earnings for both the third quarter and first nine months of 1975.

Sales of the Japanese-made Subaru automobile were up 336 per cent in July and 290 per cent in August compared with the corresponding months in 1974. So what if that meant only 5,175 cars sold in August compared with Toyota's 28,745,290 per cent is still 290 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The Navy reprimanded two retired admirals today for their role in establishing a private bank at the Naval Air Station in Pensacola, Fla. Nine other officers who held stock in the bank were absolved.
UNIONDALE, L.I. Oct. 15 Rick Barry returned to the Nassau Coliseum tonight after a three-year absence and played as if he had never left.
Ten journalists have been awarded fellowships in business and economic reporting at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, the University announced yesterday.

Mayor Beame's showdown meeting with the state's Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday represented a moment of truth for all New Yorkers as well as for the city administration. Whether the board accepts the Mayor's plan for spending reductions or decides to impose new economies of its own, it is beyond dispute that this once-profligate city is entering a new era of rigidly enforced austerity from which there is no rational escape.

Striking teachers and nonteaching school employes returned to the job under court order yesterday in Atlanta, while striking teachers and school officials reached tentative agreement in Salt Lake City.

Following is the text of the letter from Mayor Beame to Governor Carey that accompanied the Mayor's budgetcutting plan.

Almost every mixed-pair title in New York tournaments in recent years has been captured by Alvin Roth of New York City and Barbara Rappaport of Springfield, N.J. When they failed to win, it was usually because they were not competing.

PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 16 Representatives of industrial and developing countries completed preparations early today for a 27-nation conference on world economic relationships to be held here in December.

Their jewelry making began as a lark. Less than five years ago Sylvia Agostini, Carolee Russack, Sandy Baker and Eva Graham were hobbyists designing necklaces earrings, bracelets and other baubles for themselves and their friends, just for fun. Today they are running small but solid jewelry outlets that do business in six figures...

The battle to restore funds slashed from the Public Schools Athletic League budget has begun to involve figures in professional sports. Dave DeBusschere, commis- sioner of the American Basketball Association, said yesterday he would appeal to players in his league for contributions to the Save Our Sports Committee, which is marshaling the fund-raising effort.

A Queens baking company, charging illegal harassment, filed a $7.5-million suit yesterday against the Organized Crime and Racketeering Section of the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service.

Schweiker predicted today that the Warren Commission report on President Kennedy's assassination was about to collapse and said his subcommittee on intelligence was looking into three conspiracy theories. When Sheller-Globe, an auto-parts maker, reached $7 a share on the New York Stock Exchange recently, some shareholders with losses in the stock were happy to sell out.

NEWARK, Oct. 15 United States Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of Bergen County, testified today that he heard in 1973 that "money was being passed around" in connection with private immigration bills he sponsored on behalf of several Chilean aliens.
Josephine de Gersdorff Bradlee, mother of Benjamin C. Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, died yesterday in a nursing home in Beverly, Mass. She was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 United States business added to inventories in August after six months of massive inventory liquidation, providing further strong evidence of recovery in the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.
The W.T. Grant Company yesterday urged its creditors not to force it into a courtappointed trusteeship, saying such action would complicate reorganization measures and delay payment of debts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The special Watergate prosecutor reported today that his office had failed to establish responsibility for the gap in a tape recording of a conversation between President Nixon and H.R. Haldeman, his chief of staff, shortly after the 1972 Watergate break-in.
SIAN, China Looking into the awesome excavation where a life-size pottery army was recently found is like looking back more than 2,000 years in time at an ancient battlefield.
TORONTO, Oct. 15 (UPI) Rick Kehoe scored two goals tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to an 8-4 National Hockey League triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

Governor Byrne agreed yes- terday to waive a time eligibility requirement that could have prevented Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis from applying for pardons of their triple-murder convictions.

ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 15 To stop the spread of bars featuring nude dancers into residential neighborhoods here, town officials are drawing up plans to create an "adult entertainment zone."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Senator Barry Goldwater urged President Ford today to drop plans for a visit to China and visit Taiwan instead.

Several national religious organizations acting as publicinterest advocates have called for Congressional hearings on attempts by the Federal Communications Commission to reduce its regulation of radio and television, in line with President Ford's call for less Government interference in private business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, announced today that he was mistaken when he said yesterday that President Ford had made a basic decision in July to couple a 1976 tax cut proposal with a demand for Federal spending cuts.
For the first time in 25 years the Continental Can Company has reached outside its executive ranks to fill a top post.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15 A United Nations committee seemed tonight to be inching toward adoption of an Arab-inspired resolution equating Zionism with racial discrimination.

A controversial documentary film about the radical Weather Underground organization contains footage of the violent fugitive group's top leadership and their account of the bombing of the United States Capitol on March 1, 1971, according to an interview with the filmmaker, Emile de Antonio, published by Rolling Stone magazine.

Two police officers were shot by a 16-year-old youth last night, according to the police, who said the youth had cut down the two officers with a single shotgun blast during a struggle for the weapon in a narrow hallway of a Brooklyn apartment building.
ISLIP, L.I. (Oct. 15) To stop the spread of bars featuring nude dancers into residential neighborhoods here, town officials are drawing up plans to create an "adult entertainment zone."

DETROIT, Oct. 15 The Chrysler Corporation showed off its two new luxury compacts today, the Volare and Aspen, which the company hopes will keep it strong in the compact market, a segment that has emerged as one of its strongest since the energy crisis.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 (UPI) The White House asked Federal agencies to help find jobs for defeated Congressmen and their staffs less than three months after President Ford had said he would keep politics out of the civil service, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported today. In an article from its Washington bureau, The Post-Dispatch said it had obtained a copy of a memorandum of Dec. 2, 1974, from the White House personnel office.

OTTAWA, Oct. 15 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the State Department would provide the House Intelligence Committee with a full summary of foreign-policy deliberations but without attaching the names of individual junior or middle-level officers of the department to any recommendation they may have made.

LONDON, Oct. 16 George Wallace has come and gone, cutting a swath through the British press. He was interviewed for a half-hour on B.B.C. television and got his picture on the front page of both. The Times and The Telegraph not bad play for a good old boy like Mr. Wallace, even if it all gave prominent exposure to his wheelchair.

With less than six months in office as chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, Joan K. Davidson considers her most significant achievement the promptness with which the council has set about disbursing its $33-million appropriation.

NEWARK, Oct. 16 (AP) Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey announced today that they had removed a regulation that limited enrollment in their special student program to semiannual enrollment periods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 A House subcommittee is increasing its demands for information from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to justify the way the department regulates its $22-billion in health programs.

Judge Harold Mulvey of Superior Court in Hartford has been named to investigate a Bridgeport jai alai scandal involving charges that the late John M. Bailey, former Connecticut and national Democratic party chairman, accepted a $200,000 bribe in exchange for help in granting a promoter a gaming permit in the state.

PINGHURST, N.C., Oct. 16 (AP)--Mrs. Philip Cudone won the North and South women's senior golf championship today for the fourth straight year. She shot a final 81 for a 54-hole total of 239 and won by 13 strokes.

It was probably more than mere coincidence that, after Barney Josephson put a piano in his restaurant, the Cookery, University Place at 8th Street, six years ago and Mary Lou Williams came in to play it, jazz began spreading like a grass fire through Greenwich Village and up the East Side.
Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, was reported yesterday to be apprehensive of reprisals against his family and fellow dissidents in the Soviet Union.
Gains achieved early in the session were lost in late trading and stocks closed mixed on an increased volume on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market yesterday.

E.F. Hutton Group, Inc., the holding company for E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., the nation's second largest retail securities firm, reported yesterday record revenues and earnings for the third quarter and first nine months.

In the days not long past when electric power was cheap and plentiful, a practice known as "rent inclusion" became familiar in many large apartment developments. The tenant's utility bills were included in the rent. The owner bought power directly from Consolidated Edison at lower bulk rates, and master meters gauged use.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 16 The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 1975 was awarded here today to Drs. David Baltimore, Renato Dulbecco, and Howard Martin Temin for "discoveries concerning the interaction between tumor viruses and the genetic material of the cell."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16 With Don Gullett, pitching two-hit ball for eight innings and Tony Perez supplying two home runs, the Cincinnati Reds finally cranked up their "mean machine" tonight and took a onegame lead in the World Series with a 6-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
IMPRINTS Two estimable show-business names, one an eloquent Briton and the other an exponent of local "street theater," figure in a pair of new Off Off Broadway packages.
The trustees of the City Teachers' Retirement System refused last night to furnish $150-million to the Municipal Assistance Corporation money that the city says it needs to meet bills due today.

MARRAKESH, Morocco, Oct. 16 King Hassan II announced today, that he would soon lead a march of 350,000 unarmed Moroccans, more than 30,000 of them women, into the Spanish Sahara to claim that territory for Morocco.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct., 16 (AP)--A Delta rocket thundered away from Cape Canaveral tonight carrying a satellite that will monitor weather conditions and track tornadoes and hurricanes over the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (Reuters) The Labor Department has started a new investigation into allegations of syndicated criminal infiltration into the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' pension fund in the Midwest states.

The performance of Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera" at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night left the impression that the company was in the middle of the season instead of the middle of its opening week. Housing starts declined slightly in September, according to figures released in Washington yesterday. But industry experts believe the decline will give way to renewed sluggish growth in the housing sector for the rest of this year and next.

Airtraffic congestion over this tiny Virginia resort seems improbable, but that is the captain's excuse as we circle patiently above the Blue Ridge Mountains, where the trees have turned to every shade of autumnal yellow and red. Seven more American Basketball Association teams, in a surprise move, applied yesterday for membership in the National Basketball Association, commencing with the 1976-77 season. They took the action in individual telegrams to Larry O'Brien, the N.B.A. commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The Ford Administration introduced a food-stamp reform bill today that it said would save taxpayers $1.2-billion annually by eliminating from the rolls or reducing benefits for almost half of the 18.8 million people now receiving the food coupons.

Philip F. Schneider, village attorney of Cedarhurst, L.I., and a former village trustee and a member of the board of zoning appeals, died Thursday of a heart attack in his law office in Cedarhurst. He would have been 68 years old on Oct. 31.

Paine Webber, Inc., parent of the brokerage house of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Inc. reported yesterday that profits for the fourth fiscal quarter ended in September rose to an estimated $900,000 from a loss a year earlier of $885,000.

Because one man's proposal is another man's poison in the volatile areas of housing reform and rent policy here, suggestions to revitalize New York's depressed housing picture are often more contradictory than complementary.

Venezuela is expected to raise oil prices by about 80 cents a barrel on the average, according to Government and industry sources. Such an increase would be less than the 10 per cent announced last month by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, of which Venezuela is a member. The OPEC increase amounts to $l.46 a barrel.

Harvey A. Beffa Sr., head of the Shriners Hospitals for Crippled Childen and a former board chairman of Falstaff Brewing Corporation, died yesterday in Berkeley, Mo., a St. Louis suburb. He was 75 years old.
Steel importers yesterday said they welcomed a decision by the Treasury that European rebates of value-added taxes on exported steel did not constitute a subsidy.

RICHMOND, Oct. 20 (UPI) The A.H. Robins Company said today that it had paid $1,548,000 for the settlement of litigation, legal fees and other expenses stemming from its Dalkon shield intrauterine contraceptive device.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Oct. 20 Jeanne Baum, a Blackfoot indian, pleaded not guilty in Suffolk County Family Court today to a charge that she neclected the welfare of her 13-year-old daughter by refusing to let her attend school.
Two Federal Power Commission hearings next week may determine whether the long delayed Atlantic salmon restoration project on the Connecticut River is truly underway.

Mary Whyte of Greenwich, Conn., was walking down Simpson Street in the South Bronx yesterday when two men, hanging out on the corner, intercepted her to ask what she was doing there. A well-dressed person like Mrs. Whyte naturally attracts attention in such a rundown neighborhood, known for its high crime rate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) Senator Joseph M. Montoya, the New Mexico Democrat, charged today that "overzealous persons" in the Internal Revenue Service were leaking false information to the press in retaliation against his attemps to insure fair treatment for taxpayers.

Steel production for the week ended Oct. 18 slipped by 1.4 per cent to 2,108,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This lowered the production index to 86.4 from 87.6 in the preceding week when production reached 2,138,000 tons.
Price increases of various grades of asbestos fibres were announced yesterday by several big Canadian producers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Burglars tried without success over the weekend to pry open a locked file cabinet in an office at President Ford's downtown campaign headquarters here, a campaign official said today.
PEKING, Oct. 20 (Reuters) Secretary of State Kissinger reviewed the international situation with Chinese leaders here today, but the substance of his talks remained secret.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Ron Nessen, Presidential press secretary, today decried "scare tactics" that he said were being used to enlist support for Federal legislation to aid New York City.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (UPI) Two men in custody in Santa Barbara, Calif., were indicted today by a grand jury on charges of conspiring to assassinate President Ford last Sept. 5 in Sacramento, Calif., by shooting him at the State Capitol after blowing up street sewers as a diversion.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 For the third straight time, the sixth game of the World Series was postponed today by the storm that has been soaking the Northeast since Friday. But the "go" signal was hoisted for tomorrow night, when Luis Tiant will try to keep the Cincinnati Reds from finally subduing the Boston Red Sox, "the best mudders in the American League."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 20 The physician who has cared for Karen Anne Quinlan for the six months she has been in a coma said today he would refuse to obey a court order to turn off a mechanical respirator that is supporting her breathing.

TRENTON, Oct. 20 A special legislative committee concluded today that Dr. William J. Ronan "did not use good judgment" in failing to disclose a $625,000 gift from Vice President Rockefeller at the time of his appointment as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey last year.

The State Emergency Financial Control Board's recommended cuts in city construction projects include halting work on the huge water tunnel being built under Manhattan is well as on various schools already as much as 70 per cent completed, city officials disclosed yesterday.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 21 (AP) The Elizabeth Education Association reached a tentative contract settlement with local school officials tonight, ending a 12-day strike that disrupted classes for 15,000 pupils.

For the elderly who are frail and alone in the city with just enough income to stay off relief, there aren't many options. SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 Patricia Hearst's bail hearing was continued indefinitely today because psychiatrists' reports had not been received.

MADRID, Oct. 21 Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spain's ruler since the 1936-39 Civil War, fell seriously ill with a heart ailment today, setting off rumors that a transfer of power to Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon was imminent.

SHIRKIEVILLE, Ind., Oct. 21 Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana, betting that he can bridge the gap between left and right in his party better than any of his rivals, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21 Scattered shooting and sniping and occasional rocket explosions continued to paralyze life throughout Beirut today, though large scale violence did not break out.
With the World Series going to a seventh game, it will be the 26th time that the championship of baseball has been decided in an "ultimate game": one game, with no tomorrow for either side.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The Central Intelligence Agency opened more than 215,000 pieces of mail in a New York operation that many senior agency officials knew to be illegal, it was disclosed today at a Senate committee hearing.

LISBON, Oct. 21 New governors for Lisbon and three provincial capitals will be sworn in tomorrow in an effort by the Government to strengthen its authority against a Communist and extreme left offensive.

W., a highly diversified company.

DETROIT, Oct. 21 (UPI) Government prosecutors said today that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, using an ex-convict with a transmitter, had taped conversations allegedly linking State Supreme Court Justice John B. Swainson with a $30,000 bribery conspiracy.

UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 21 The Spanish representative to the United Nations said tonight that he had spoken by telephone to the Foreign Ministry in Madrid and had been assured that General Francisco Franco, the chief of state, had been stricken with a circulatory ailment but had not had a coronary attack, as was widely reported during the day.

WOODLANDS, Tex., Oct 21 E.L. Schumacher, the British economist, decrying bigness, urged today a shift toward more utilization of small, labor-intensive and energy-saving units of production for the manufacture of basic human needs.

WASHINGTON Winston Churchill always considered Mediterranean Europe as the soft underbelly of Hitler's continental fortress during World War II. Now it would seem as if Mosow's strategy aims at outflanking NATO's central blocking positions by political exploitation of the same sort of weakness along the alliance's southern flank.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Oct. 22 The Boston Red Sox rose to dramatic heights early this morning when they defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 7-6, on a 12th-inning home run by Carlton Fisk and stretched the World Series into a seventh and deciding game.
MIAMI, Oct. 21 (UPI) An Indonesian seaman has described how he killed four German officers aboard the Panamanian freighter Mimi and then scuttled the ship.

BRIGHT BLOOM Toward midnight last Saturday at Willy's, Hod O'Brian slipped in front of the baby grand, Marshall Brown settled his guitar in his lap, and Knobby Totah began strumming the bass. Their "I Remember You," from back when, gradually filled the room of this new club at 7 West Eighth Street, a cheerful and informal place tunneling through the former premises of a Greenwich Village delicatessen-restaurant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The Interior Department's projected resumption of the leasing of federally owned coal lands in the West came under attack today on two fronts in court here and in a speech by the Ford Administration's highest environmental spokesman, Russell E. Train.

A senior business executive, with a corporate interest in journalism, believes that "business and the press have too little mutual respect and too little understanding for each other's vital role within the American system."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Pentagon said today it planned to sell South Korea 18 more F-4E fighter planes for $177.9-million.
President Anwar el-Sadat of of Egypt is expected by United States officials to ask during his visit here for $5-billion to $7-billion in arms aid over a period of at least 10 years.

LONDON, Oct. 21 The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that its 520 non-Libyan employes and their families, including 230 Americans, have been told they can leave that North African country provided that they are replaced.
PARIS French women living near the Opera may head for the nearby outdoor St. Honore market intent on buying a mutton or a roast. But these days they may come home with a dress or a coat instead.

After an extensive review of the past performance of the nation's money managers, two scholars at the University of Chicago law school have concluded that it is not only futile to attempt to beat the market averages but also unduly costly.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 21 (AP) The first convoy of Moroccan volunteers set out today for the southern border town of Tarfaia where they will wait for King Hassan II to lead 350,000 in a 60-mile "march of conquest" to Spanish Sahara.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 Ronald Reagan, in what aides billed as a "major" address, berated third-world governments here today for what he termed anti-American "hostility" and the United Nations for allowing them what he called a disproportionate role in its decisions.

The Rev. Dr. Philemon F. Sturges Jr., rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Martin-inthe-Fields, Chestnut Hill, Mass., for 22 years before his retirement in 1967, died Sunday at his home in Princeton, Mass. He was 72 years old.

Burlington Industries, Inc., the nation's largest and most diversified textile company, yesterday reported improved business from the depressed levels earlier this year, but said that earnings for the September quarter still lagged by 20.1 per cent from the yearago period. The United States Department of Agriculture's Agricultural Marketing Service has proposed establishing uniform names for U.S. grades of fresh fruits and vegetables in place of the current ones, which the department's experts recognize are "confusing the trade specialists as well as the consumer."
