Every year Winifred Cecil gives a series of public master classes called Joy in Singing, in which students are instructed by her and then perform. And each year a panel of judges selects the best of the singers, who is then presented in a formal recital. This year's winner was Eunice Hill, who appeared at Alice Tully Hall Monday night.

What was Representative Herman Badillo discussing with Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton in that smoke-filled room the other night? New York's finances? The coming election? Wrong. They were trading recipes: for rice and beans (Mr. Badillo) and fried chicken (Mr. Sutton).

With a drivers' strike threatened for midnight tonight at The Daily News and a possible shutdown by The New York Times as well, negotiations resumed yesterday between the newspaper deliverers union and the two papers. The talks were broken off by the union on Friday.

Malcolm Wilson to bail the U.D.C. out of imminent default.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange rose slightly by 7,484 shares to a total of 24,485,559 shares in the month ended on Oct. 15.
Angelo Di Leo, a retired men's-clothing tailor, died yesterday at his home in Granitville, Staten Island of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 83.

PEKING, Oct. 21 Chairman Mao Tse-tung met with Secretary of State Kissinger today, symbolically dramatizing what both sides have sought to convey; the idea that ChineseAmericn relations are getting better all the time.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 The Austrian composer of a controversial cantata won applause today from the choir that is to sing it here Friday. But the delegate of Israel said he would not attend the United Nations Day concert.

MADRID, Oct. 21-Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spain's ruler since the 1936-39 Civil War, fell seriously ill with a heart ailment today, setting off rumors that a transfer of power to Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon was imminent.
NORTH BABYLON, L.I, Oct. 21 After serving five years in Turkish prisons for possession of hashish, Billy Hayes is on his way home to Long Island.

President Ford has just renewed his anti-hunger war in which the target seems to be hungry Americans rather than hunger itself. The Administration's latest sally, though billed as food stamp reform, actually amounts to a substantial evisceration of the program.

On his penultimate push toward the North Pole, in 1906, Robert E. Peary sighted a range of peaks rising above the icecap about 400 miles west of the northern tip of Greenland. He named the distant peaks Crocker Land, and so they appeared on at least one map.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) President Ford's top labor troubleshooter stepped into the three-week-old strike at The Washington Post today.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 21 Some 3,000 people gathered on Mount Scopus this morning for the dedication of a new $40-million Hadassah University hospital designed to serve both the Arab and Jewish residents of East Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The Justice Department has decided not to bring charges against any of the individuals purportedly involved in the destruction, two days after the assassination of President Kennedy, of a threatening note previously delivered to the Dallas F.B.I. office by Lee Harvey Oswald, Mr. Kennedy's accused assassin.

WASHINGTON Oct. 21 The House Ethics Committee voted 7 to 2 today to investigate formally charges that Representative Michael J. Harrington violated House rules by discussing with unauthorized persons secret testimony on the Central Intelligence Agency's political activities in Chile.
Fred Lynn of the Boston Red Sox received the most votes in The Associated Press all-star baseball team that was announced yesterday.
OTTAWA, Oct. 21 Canadian post office employes called a strike today over wage demands and other issues, halting mail service throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) The Senate voted today to put even emergency natural gas purchases under price controls this winter to prevent a "gold rush" of higher gas rates.

A controversy over a fifthgrade social-studies course in New Jersey has led to orders for its termination in three communities Montclair, Westfield and Mahwah and a Congressional halt on the use of National Science Foundation funds for its promotion.

MIAMI, Oct. 21 (UPI) Strikebound National Airlines disclosed today that it had sent layoff notices to 100 supervisory employes, anticipated further cutbacks and planned to sell its two Boeing 747 jumbo jets.
CHERRY HILL, Oct. 21 (UPI) Teachers in Cherry Hill, who threatened to strike two weeks ago, overwhelmingly voted yesterday to approve a new oneyear contract calling for a 9.5 per cent pay increase.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Oct. 21 Starting tomorrow, the mechanized lawnmower on the grass at the edge of one of Long Island's parkways may be a radar trap set up by the Long Island State Parkway Police to help curtail an increasing number of automobile accidents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 He often sits on a leather bench just outside the House chamber, a lone figure watching the passing parade of old colleagues who once clam ored for his attention and the young ones who never knew him in his days of power.

SAIGON, South Vietnam (Agence France-Presse) The newspaper Giai Phong, in the first official comment on the departure from Guam of a ship carrying 1,600 refugees back to Vietnam, today called it a "gross farce" on the part of the Ford Administration.

HONG KONG, Oct. 21 China announced plans today to improve agriculture by trying to upgrade standards in one-third of the nation's 2,100 counties to match those of a commune noted for self-reliance, mechanization of production and the raising of grain under severe conditions.

The doorway to Room 315 in the New York Public Library's magnificent Fifth Avenue center leads to a bookish wonderland, sitting atop a literary powderkeg of 2.5 million volumes, knowledge enough to flood the world with good or evil, or at least to irrigate arid minds.

At Langley Air Force Base in Virginia, T/Sgt. Leonard Matlovich was being processed for discharge yesterday following rejection of his appeal by John L. McLucas in one of his last acts as Secretary of the Air Force. Mr. McLucas, who was sworn in late Monday as Federal Aviation Administrator, affirmed the decision by Sergeant Matlovich's commanding officer that, under Air Force regulations, the 32-year-old Vietnam veteran's publicly declared homosexuality barred him from further service.

Floyd D. Hall, chairman of Eastern Air Lines, announced yesterday that effective Dec. 16, following expiration of his 12-year employment contract, he would cease being chief executive officer but would continue as chairman.

Standard Poor's Corporation announced yesterday in London that it would begin rating Eurobonds. This is the first time that the financial services concern has extended its ratings to issues sold outside of the United States.

Creative collaboration with a computer has been coming along for some time now as one way that composers try to bring under control the bewildering variety of elements involved in much recent music. One leading figure in this development, which is as yet in the experimental stage, is Emmanuel Ghent, whose "Lustrum" was given its New York premiere on Monday night at Hunter College Playhouse.
Thomas A. Halleran, for 35 years a partner in the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine Moore, died yesterday while vacationing in Barbados. He was 69 years old and lived at 1021 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The Senate Banking Committee voted 7 to 6 today to consider legislation that would provide $6billion in loan guarantees to New York City, require the state to levy $420-million in new taxes, and place the city's fiscal management under a three-member Federal board headed by Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.
WESTPORT, Conn. Walking around the large room where a few dozen women sat at tables talking softly and sewing on quilted pillow squares, Bessie Cromer was a long way from home.

PARIS, Oct. 21 Bermuda shorts are back. Just watch. Soon another generation of college students and tourists will be turning in their blue jeans, or maybe just cutting them off above the knees.

LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 22 (AP) Gary Croteau, with two goals and an assist, paced the Kansas City Scouts to a 4-2 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight. Tommy Williams scored both Washington goals in the first period.

Stock prices rose slightly as the market opened yesterday and then drifted off most of the day. Near the close, the market made a small hop upward and the Dow-Jones indus trial average closed at 849.57 up 2.75 from its closing level Tuesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22 The Security Council sought tonight to head off a possible armed clash over the Spanish Sahara by appealing for "restraint and moderation" by the countries disputing control of the territory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) -Agriculture Secretary Earl I. Butz said today the United States could easily supply the Soviet Union an extra 7 million tons of grain this year if the Russians sought it under the new long-term agreement.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 22 (UPI)The dollar fell on European money markets today, weakened by stronger European currencies. Gold lost $1 an ounce in London, closing at $144.75 and $1.25 in Zurich to close at $144.75.

BOSTON, Oct. 22-In the final inning of the final game, the Cincinnati Reds finally subdued the rambunctious Boston Red Sox, 4-3, tonight and won the 72d World Series. It was Cincinnati's first championship since 1940.

The nation's oil refineries operated at 85.8 per cent of capacity last week compared with 87.1 per cent in the preceding week and 87.4 per cent in the comparable week a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute's weekly statistical report.

The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, announced yesterday 31.3 per cent decline in profits in the third quarter. The Shell Oil Company and the Marathon Oil Company also reported steep drops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Personal diplomacy is very fashionable these days. We have pictures of Henry Kissinger shaking hands with Chairman Mao Tse-tong in Peking, of the Emperor of Japan and President Ford on the White House lawn, and next week it will be President Sadat of Egypt and his "dear friend" Henry dominating the social and diplomatic news.

MORRISTOWN, Oct. 23 Superior Court Judge Robert Muir Jr. recessed the Karen Anne Quinlan trial today until Monday after hearing three expert medical witnesses testify that the 21-year-old coma victim was legally and medically alive, but would never recover her ability to function as a human being.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market advanced yesterday in light trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) Social Security Commissioner James B. Cardwell identified today a number of provisions of the Social Security law that he said discriminated between men and women and should be corrected.

One processor of education, who spends much of his life studying how children learn artistic skills, tells of the day he tried to discipline his son, and his son struck back. "Daddy," the boy said, "I'm not going to draw for you any more."

The agent for Anthony Davis was expected to tell the Jets today how much it would cost to add the World Football League star to their roster. The agent, a 23-yearold classmate of Davis from Southern California named Mike Trope, was also bargaining with the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian League.
Charles Brokaw, an actor who had appeared on the Broadway stage and in films, died Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived here.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 (AP) Kathy Heddy and Bobby Hackett led another sweep by United States swimmers of gold medals in the Pan-American Games tonight, and again with records in every event.

TRENTON, Oct. 23 Governor Byrne today proposed legislation that would make the state boards that regulate profession and trades more responsible to the public.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) Betty Ford, who a year ago underwent surgery for breast cancer, had a comprehensive medical examination today at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center, and her doctor reported "no indication of any cancer recurrence."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 New York City's government lined up today behind the New York and American Stock Exchanges and most of the securities industry in urging the Securities and Exchange Commissign not to abolish or essentially alter the exchanges' rules restricting off-board trading in their listed stocks.

Joseph J. Cazana, a civil engineer with Sanderson Porter, Inc., who specialized in structural-steel work and had served on projeets for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 61 years old.
RABUN GAP, Ga. The spark that started it all, as Eliot Wigginton recalls, came from Tommy Green's cigarette lighter the morning he tried to set fire to the teacher's platform.

TRENTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) Almost one-third of the hospitals in New Jersey may soon lose their medical malpractice insurance, according to officials of the New Jersey Hospitals Association.

WRIGHTSTOWN, Oct. 23 (UPI) The Borough Council here has decided to abolish its five-member Police Department to save money. In a 3-to-2 vote last night, it decided to buy police protection from the 10-member force in neighboring New Hanover Township beginning Nov. 10.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 23 Civil rights lawyers have filed suit on behalf of black citizens against six Mississippi municipalities, seeking to impound more than $4-million in Federal revenue-sharing funds until the towns equalize public services in black and white neighborhoods.
HACKENSACK, Oct. 23 (AP) A salesman who said he and his wife had gone to an early mass "to pray and for luck" won $250,000 today in the Jersey Jackpot lottery drawing.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 23-The 1975 Nobel Prize for Literature was awarded today to Eugenio Montale, a 79-year-old Italian poet, for his interpretation of human values through "an outlook on life with no illusions."

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23 (UPI) Six men, four of them former grain elevator employes, were sentenced to jail terms ranging from two to six months yesterday on charges involving theft and corruption in the grain export industry.

LISBON, Oct. 23 Portugal's Communist party and other leftist groups sent thousands of demonstrators into the streets of this capital tonight in a determined effort to demonstrate their strength and to undermine the month-old Government.

TOKYO, Oct. 23 The Dow Chemical Company's subsidiary here accepted today a demand from the Japanese Government that it withdraw its application to build a major chlorine and caustic-soda plant in Japan.

The Federal Trade Commission's new director of the Bureau of Competition wants to move more quickly on the anticompetitive merger front. Owen Johnson, who took over his new position Oct. 3, said yesterday he plans to mobilize a "strike force" to act promptly on mergers that raise competitive questions.
Every time the Nobel Prize for Literature is awarded, someone writes an article explaining why the choice was politically predictable and inevitable.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 Thomas P. Richardson, an associate of the fugitive financier Robert Vesco, and four other men were indicted by a Federal grand jury today for allegedly conducting a massive stock short-selling plan in which some of the nation's most prestigious universities, several brokerage houses, and other investors lost more than $14million.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) The Office of Consumer Affairs warned the public today to beware of crooked promoters in the budding solar home heating industry.
CEFALU, Sicily Elio Cotena, Italy, stopped Michel Lefebvre, France, 12 rounds, retaining European featherweight title.

Smith, Barney Co., Inc., and Harris, Upham Co., Inc., two privately held brokerage houses founded in the late 1800's, announced jointly here yesterday that they planned to merge by the end of the year.

NASHVILLE, Oct. 23 (UPI) Ike Everly, a Country-music entertainer and father of the Everly Brothers, died yesterday at a hospital here. The 67year-old Mr. Everly was the singer-guitar-playing father of Phil and Don Everly singers who achieved their greatest popularity in the nineteenfifties. Also surviving is his wife, Margaret.

Approximately 8,000 jobs will be lost in the construction industry in the next three years as a result of the cutting of an additional $390-million from the city's building program, Mayor Beame estimated yesterday. The additional cuts were announced last Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) A young man carrying a loaded pistol was arrested outside the White House today but the Park Police and Secret Service officials do not believe that he represented a threat to the life of President Ford.
With all of baseball's onfield confrontations settled for the year, warfare erupted off the field yesterday between the Players Association and the club owners.
The Acting Sanitation Commissioner, Martin Lang, yesterday announced cost-cutting and efficiency measure that he said would save the city about $2.7-million in the next year.

LONDON, Oct. 23 Veniamin G. Levich, the highest ranking Soviet scientist to apply for an exit visa, has been denied permission to emigrate despite a promise last year that he could do so, the scientist's son said today.

On the eve of their National Basketball Association opener against the Los Angeles Lakers last night at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks acquired Spencer Haywood, the type of power forward they had long sought, from the Seattle SuperSonics.

The tough but balanced anti-inflation program launched by Prime Minister Trudeau of Canada is long overdue. Mr. Trudeau was apparently moved to action by the resignation from his Cabinet of Finance Minister John Turner, generally regarded as the probable future leader of the Liberal party, who had long pressed for the kind of strong measures now adopted to check the deteriorating economy.

The air is thick these days with talk of "hype." Hype is the music-industry term for promotion, and it has two rough meanings. One is any sort of public enthusiasm that can be used to promote an artist's career. The other is the specific effort on the part of an artist's backers to engender that enthusiasm.
BUTTE, Mont., Oct. 23 (AP) The School Board of Trustees has ordered an immediate halt to the practice of locking retarded children in a coffinsized box as a form of punishment.

Liquidation continued in the grain and soybean markets yesterday, depressing prices further. The reasons were lack of both export and domestic demand and reports of unexpectedly high yields from farm areas.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Speaker Carl Albert, in an uncharacteristically strong state ment, called on Congress today to enact legislation to avert a New York City default.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The Federal Power Commission issued today its first approval for the transportation by interstate pipeline of natural gas purchased directly from a producer by an industrial customer.

Gabriel Hauge, chairman off the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation announced yesterday that the bank holding company would continue to have three regional banks in upper New York State after next Jan. 1, rather than a statewide branching system.

It would be difficult to think of a more ambitious, delicate and difficult subject for an exhibition than the one that is being tackled at this moment (and through Jan. 25) at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92d Street. Its title is "Jewish Experience in the Art of the Twentieth Century," and its subject is the development in the art of the last 75 years of a specifically Jewish awareness.

A political maxim has it that the two most urgent concerns of the municipal electorate are potholes in the streets and blocked sewers. If this is true, Question No. 8 of the proposed revisions of the New York City Charter will afford voters on Nov. 4 a chance to express their sentiment on an issue close to their hearts.

Twenty-six days after the season ended, America had a new national baseball champion yesterday, with 51 shopping days still left before Christmas. The World Series was wonderful and hard on the nerves, like a gifted entertainer who doesn't know how to get off stage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) President Ford has "no trepidation" about returning next week to California, where he was the target of two alleged assassination attempts last month, a White House spokesman said today.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 23 After 35 years of gloryhunger; after half a decade of painful near-misses; after a wrenching shift in mood from super-confidence to nagging doubt; after three days of rain took the edge off the World Series, and the sixth game restored it; after the Reds finally rallied in the ninth inning last night to seal their championship, after all that, Cincinnati had a crushing hangover today.

The New York Telephone Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, Empire City Subway Company, Ltd., reported yesterday third-quarter net income of $79.9-million, or 42 cents a share, a decline of 7.9 per cent from $86-million, or 45 cents a share, reported last year.

The grotesque and exotic personages of "Petrushka" appeal to us precisely because they represent clarified essences of ordinary behavior. Olin Rent-A-Car filed for reorganization yesterday under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, which would allow it to continue in business while it seeks to work out an arrangement with its creditors for the payment of its debts, United Press International reports.

In an unusual example of theater-owner and producer cooperation, the League of New York Theaters and Producers has established a fund to help three musicals that were hurt by the 25-day musicians' strike.

BOSTON There now appears to be little doubt that among the commonly used psychoactive drugs amphetamines have a formidable potential for harm psychological, physical and social. It is clear that while they may be used, particularly in small doses over limited periods of time, without creating dependency, their use imposes the risk of severe dependency on many, and outright addiction on some users.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative-Republican of New York, called on President Ford today to order a Justice Department investigation of whether New York City had violated Federal laws by overstating the amount of money available to cover its borrowings.

The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, which was kept financially afloat for months nearly $100,000 in royalties from Alex Comfort's best-seller, "The Joy of Sex," has filed suit for $3.08-million against Dr. Comfort on the ground that he cut down its income by publishing "More Joy of Sex," thus luring book buyers to purchase the sequel instead of the original.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 The Security Council today extended the mandate of the international peace-keeping force in the Sinai buffer zone by a year.

The W.T. Grant Company, financially distressed and anxious to put together a new management team, is seeking a top retailer as president but its principal creditor banks are refusing to guarantee a fiveyear contract at a high salary to attract him. The salary being offered is $150,000 per annum.

The economic recession has induced most railroads to skimp once again on basic maintenance of their roadbeds and facilities. The results not only for the bankrupt railroads of the Northeast but also for more prosperous lines in other regions are increased risks for passengers and crewmen as well as further deterioration of a transportation network that is essential to the nation's economic vitality.

MONASTEREVIN, Ireland, Oct. 24 (AP) A kidnapped Dutch industrialist appeared at a window today and pleaded with police to "save my life" by staying away from the house here where two Irish guerrillas have held him for more than three days.

WASHINGTON, Oct.24 A patent for an intrauterine contraceptive device, issued this week, is assigned to the United States Government. The device was invented under a contract granted by the Agency for International Development, which handles assistance to foreign nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Senior Federal Power Commission officials told Congress today that they did not know how many natural gas producers might be failing to meet delivery obligations to interstate pipelines or by how much deliveries could be increased.

The stock market dropped sharply yesterday amid growing concern that the Federal Government would not rescue New York City from default. The Dow-Jones industrial average declined 14.64 to 840.52, relinquishing more than half the gain it made in advancing from Monday through Thursday.

I marvel to this day at the business acumen and plain gutsiness that my parents had to have to be in the market back in the thirties. Without a high school diploma between them, and only the "hand-to-mouth" salary of a garment-center pieceworker, they managed to "invest in America" in terms that first became familiar to me when I was old enough to play Monopoly: stocks, bonds, railroads, utilities, dividends, real estate, interest, taxes, bankruptcy.

The State Emergency Control Board yesterday ordered the Health and Hospitals Corporation to reduce its spending as Mayor Beame had directed before it would meet with the corporation on its objections to the budget cuts.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 (UPI) The civil rights act, which prohibits discrimination "because of an individual's sex," does not protect those who plan to undergo a sex change, a Federal judge has ruled.

Former Governor Malcolm Wilson blamed Governor Carey yesterday for the default of the Urban Development Corporation, saying that Mr. Carey had failed to act on a plan Mr. Wilson had devised to hold the insolvent agency together.

UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 24 (Reuters) The United Nations marked its 30th anniversary today, and in a message honoring the occasion Secretary General Waldheim said that the world organization was involved in the creation of a better world for all.

The city's revenue from the two cable television channels serving Manhattan is expected to increase by 25 per cent to more than $1-million in the next 12 months as a result of increased subscriber rates that were approved Thursday by the Board of Estimate.

Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun honored around the world for her care of the poor and dying, yesterday paid tribute to a stricken woman she recently found near death in a crowded street in Calcutta.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 A consulting scientist has invented an automotive power system that he believes will greatly reduce motorists' fuel consumption and air pollution. Glenn L. Dyer of Bedford, Mass, was granted Patent 3,913,699 this week for propulsion apparatus that includes a compressor and its motor, a combustion chamber and a drive motor but no gear shift or transmission. There will also be no timing or spark plugs.
Wisdom dictates that collectors of moderate means avoid the most popular period wares on which prices have escalated and are continuing in an upward spiral.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 24 (Reuters) Women went on a one-day strike today to demonstrate their importance to the country. About 25,000 of the women flocked to a rally in the center of the city, creating the biggest traffic jam the police could recall.

WASHINGTON Detente is not a very popular word to describe a foreign policy in an impatient country like the United States. For better or worse, Americans prefer a go-go-go approach to life: Monroe or Truman Doctrines, dynamic slogans like "fiftyfour forty or fight" and "rollback."

HAMBURG, West Germany, Oct. 24 (UPI) A West German shipping concern has "pirated" two of its own ferries from Sweden and Denmark and sailed them back into this country's waters, in what it called a "fully legal" action.

Jerry Paul, the 33-year-old lawyer who gained nationwide fame for his defense of Joan Little, has stated in an interview that, given enough money, he could "buy justice" regardless of any client's guilt or innocence. With total cynicism he says: "A jury is twelve people deciding who has the best lawyer."
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 UPI) Kim Peyton won her fourth gold medal at the PanAmerican games tonight, as United States swimmers swept all four finals and concluded the competition with 27 of 29 titles.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 The State Board of Regents today required that doctors who graduate from the City College's six-year biomedical training program would have to serve for two years in areas of New York City that are short of doctors.

Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola said yesterday that he would present evidence in a robbery case to a grand jury, even though a Bronx Criminal Court judge dismissed the case Wednesday on the ground that the suspects' constitutional rights had been violated by the police.

Last spring's banners came out, of storage a couple of weeks ago when the Rangers played the Islanders in an exhibition game. "Beat the Manhattan misfits", "Long Beach Loves the Islanders" read familiar signs that had graced the stands during the heated playoff battle between New York's two hockey clubs.

This week's subscription program of the New York Philharmonic is devoted entirey to Mozart, and the newsiest item on the bill is the Concerto for Three Pianos and Orchestra in F (K. 242). The concerto itself isn't newsworthy, actually, although it's not played that often and is a pleasant enough piece. But what is unusual is that Carlos Moseley, the orchestra's former manager and now president, plays the firstpiano part.

The First National City Bank of New York, the Bank of America in San Francisco and more than a dozen other major banks around the country announced quarter-point reductions yesterday in their prime lending rates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Lou Harris, the pollster, said today that an overwhelming majority of Americans favored handgun registration and he advised politicians to campaign strongly for gun controls.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 24 (24) A tombstone with an inscription from the writings of the late Chief Justice Earl Warren will be dedicated at his grave Tuesday in Arlington National Cemetery.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Boston Celtics, sparked by Jo Jo White and a new backcourt partner, Charlie Scott, pulled away late in the first half for a 109-94 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight in a National Basketball Association opener. John Havlicek led the Boston scorers with 24 points.

SAN JUAN, P.R. Oct. 24 (UPI) A Federal district court Judge, Hernan Pesquera, forestalled today a possible renewed strike against Puerto Rico's public merchant fleet, but the question of union jurisdiction on four of the fleet's ships still remained muddled.
Juliet Blume Furman, former acting administrative assistant to the principal of Julia Richman High School, died yesterday at her home, 165 west 66th Street. She was 63 years old.

TRENTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) A spokesman for the Medical Society of New Jersey said today that the increase in malpractice suits was caused by vast improvements in livesaving technology that result in greater risks, and not by incompetent physicians.
PARIS, Oct. 24 A group of exiled Spanish leaders, representing both leftist and rightist parties, said today that they were prepared to return to Spain to help form a provisional government.
PARIS, Oct. 24 The Turkish Ambassador to France, Ismail Erez, was killed today by gunmen, two days after Turkey's Ambassador to Austria was slain in his Vienna office.

MADRID, Oct, 24 (UPI) The transfer of power from Generalissimo Francisco Franco. to his designated successor, Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon, will follow a cumbersome procedure laid down in the Spanish Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Government reported today that the productivity of American workers took its largest jump in more than four years in the three-month period ended in September.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 The State Board of Regents today required that doctors who graduate from the City College's six-year biomedical training program would have to serve for two years in areas of New York City that are short of doctors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) A former intelligence officer, John Marks, has filed a freedom of information suit against the Central Intelligence Agency seeking all files or other documents the agency has compiled on him, the Center for National Security Studies announced.

The New York office of the American Arbitration Association ruled yesterday that the Asiatic Petroleum Corporation of New York had overcharged the New England Petroleum Corporation and its Bahamian subsidiary, the Grand Bahama Petroleum Company, for fuel oil sold to the companies earlier this year.

CAMDEN, N.Y. Halloween is no fly-by-night affair at Cackle Berry Farm. For weeks now, Verda and Bob Will's front yard has been filled with 700 glowing jack-o'-lanterns and with a fat, fast- talking pumpkin, a pot-stirring witch and a motorized grave that opens and shuts to organ music.

ATLANTA, Oct. 24 The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, the top Federal court in the South, has upheld a highly controversial school desegregation plan in which Atlanta blacks gave up demands for massive crosstown busing in return for jobs within the school administration.
For a day, at least, a Saturday in New York will again he dominated by a big-time football game.
MADRID, Oct. 24 Generalissimo Francisco Franco's heart condition deteriorated again today, a team of 10 doctors reported.

Four advertisers have withdrawn from the repeat showing on NBC tonight of "Born Innocent," saying they considered the controversial film to be an inappropriate context for their commercials. Other advertisers have taken their place, NBC officials said yesterday.

General Atomic, a joint venture of the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, confirmed yesterday that it was quitting production of high-temperature nuclear gas reactors. The company was the only maker of these reactors.
Gandy Brodie, an expressionist artist and art teacher, whose paintings appear in leading museums, died here Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 51 years old and lived in West Townshend, Vt.

LONDON, Oct. 24 James D. Slater, a millionaire who had a meteoric rise in the last decade, announced tonight that he was quitting his floundering company, Slater, Walker Securities, Ltd. The resignation was reportedly forced by a scandal brewing around a company in Singapore.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 24 (UPI) State troopers and sheriff's officers patroled Oklahoma's capital today and city officials failed in a payday effort to force nearly 600 striking officers to resign in writing or go to work.

DENVER, Oct. 24 Along "Mobile Home Row" on 92d Avenue just beyond the northern city limits of Denver, empty spaces punctuate the landscape of one of the largest concentrations of trailer villages in the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Many lives and millions of dollars are being wasted by the failure to use widely a common substance called lithium carbonate in controlling recurrent attacks of severe mental depression, a scientist said here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (UPI) A motion has been filed here to prevent Micki Scott, the wife of Jack Scott, the radical sports figure, from testifying before a Federal grand jury in Harrisburg that is investigating reports that Patricia Hearst hid in Northeastern Pennsylvania last year.

MUNICH, West Germany, Madeleine de Witt, an American citizen who has spent all but five of her 25 years in West Germany and speaks German better than English, came close to panic last Sept. 5, shortly after reporting for work at a big Munich brewery where she made architectual drawings.
A Federal judge has ruled that it is sexually discriminatory for a company to discharge a male employe for wearing long hair while permitting women employes to wear long hair.
LISBON, Oct. 24 Portugal's armed forces were ordered on a nationwide alert today after six small explosions here in the early morning and new rumors of an impending coup.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The White House attacked today as "too small" the tax reduction measure approved yesterday by the House Ways and Means Committee.
RANGOON, Burma, Saturday, Oct. 25 (Reuters) More than 100 people were reported missing after a ferry capsized and sank near here yesterday, officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed the first standards to control air pollution from motorcycles, requiring a 90 per cent improvement in new cycles by 1980.

Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun honored around the world for her care of the poor and dying, yesterday paid tribute to a stricken woman she recently found near death in a crowded street in Calcutta.
LISBON, Oct. 24 Portugal's armed forces were ordered on a nationwide alert today after six small explosions here in the early morning and new rumors of an impending coup.
Billy Hayes returned home yesterday after five years in a Turkish prison from which he said he escaped by rowboat on a stormy night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The Secret Service acknowledged today that there was a second accident involving President Ford's limousine a few moments after it was struck broadside by an automobile Oct. 4 in downtown Hartford.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 24 Sharply scaling down its blueprint to turn Stewart Airport into the metropolitan area's fourth major jetport, the consulting concern that proposed a $1-billion development plan in 1973 now says it sees the airport serving a far more limited market of charter flights and local air traffic for at least another decade.

CLINTON, Oct. 24 Richard J. Hughes, Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, led a group of about 40 judges on a tour of the Correctional Institution for Women here today and then told some troubled inmates that they could expect "improvement" in the state's parole procedures.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 The one percentage point cut by the Bank of Japan in its central discount rate, which went into effect today, was part of a Government effort to get the nation's stagnant economy moving again.
Rosalie DiPaola Reisberg had an appointment to have her hair cut at a midtown beauty shop at noon on the day she was murdered in her West Side Manhattan brownstone. She never appeared.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell told a Senate committee under oath today that officials of the Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation had never told him that the agencies were secretly opening mail.
Commissioner Pete Rozelle ordered his National Football League clubs last night not to sign any players from the defunct World Football League for the rest of this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) More than 87,000 cans of Palm hearts packed in Brazil were recalled by the Food and Drug Administration because of possible bacteria contamination, the agency said yesterday.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 24 (UPI) The Indian Government today renewed an order to abolish bonded labor, a form of slavery that has been in existence for centuries in this country.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24 The Government of President Isabel Martinez de Peron called today on organized labor and business organizations to join in a "social pact" to halt runaway inflation and labor anarchy.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 24 (AP) The leaders of some of the nation's major corporations said today that they would volunteer their resources to study urban economic problems and would lobby in state and Federal Government for relief for the cities. The project would be conducted in cooperation with the United States Conference of Mayors.

Dr. Frances V. Guille-Secor, edited "The Diary of Adele Hugo," the book from which the Francois Truffaut film "The Story of Adele H.," the story of Victor Hugo's younger daughter, was made, died Wednesday at the Community Hospital in Wooster, Ohio. She was 67 years old.

A cut in gasoline prices spread further yesterday with announcements by the Mobil Oil Corporation, Standard Oil Company (Ohio) and the Getty Oil Company that they were reducing prices by 1 cent a gallon. This follows a trend established by most major oil companies over the last two weeks.
Ninety-six of the city's 120 Civil Court judges sued yesterday to retain their law secretaries, who face dismissal on Nov. 21 because of the city's budget crisis.
The Singer Company suffered a $34.7-million loss in the third quarter compared with a loss of $31.5-million a year ago, it was reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (Reuters) A Soviet newspaper today confirmed that an unmanned Russian spacecraft that landed on Venus two days ago was now dead after working nearly twice as long as scientists had hoped.

A group of Eleanor Roosevelt's longtime and intimate friends gathered yesterday, as they have for the last 10 years, to lay autumn flowers at the slab granite sculpture that fronts the Eleanor Roosevelt Bench in the United Nations Park.

When Francisco Franco designated Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon as the future King of Spain in 1969, he said this action would insure "political continuity and stability." The validity of that prognosis may shortly be put to the test whether Juan Carlos becomes chief of state by a formal transfer of power from the ailing Generalissimo or must await Franco's death.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 24 (UPI) Family friends said today that Don Juan, Count of Barcelona and pretender to the Spanish throne, has agreed to stay out of Spanish politics for the time being.

LUANDA, Angola, Oct. 24 (Reuters) The Angolan Interior Ministry ordered all foreign residents today to report to the police within three days as the liberation organization in control here began a recruiting drive to repel what it has reported as an invasion from South Africa and Zaire.

ROME, Oct. 24 Roman Catholic theologians here have begun to debate publicly the moral issues surrounding the case of Karen Anne Quinlan, the 21-year-old coma victim in New Jersey whose parents have asked the court for permission to turn off the mechanical equipment keeping her alive.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The Soviet Union has bought more than one million tons of American corn since signing a fiveyear grain agreement with the United States earlier this week, it was announced today.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24 The New York Nets' new frontcourt muscle outrebounded and outpushed the tough Spirits of St. Louis at the Arena tonight, propelling the Nets to a 109-94 victory in their American Basketball Association opener.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Defense Department said today it planned to build a headquarters complex for the Saudi Arabian National Guard at a cost of $158.7-million.

HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Oct. 24 (UPI) Chris Evert trounced Evonne Goolagong, 6-1, 6-1, today in the singles final of the World Invitation tennis tournament. It was Miss Evert's 19th straight tournament victory on a clay court.
Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., has won the $30-million Toyota advertising business in what is one of the largest account switches in history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Several members of the Senate Banking Committee said today that William Proxmire, the panel's chairman, probably had the bare minimum of votes to bring to the Senate floor a bill that would save New York City from default.

The New York Times and The Daily News met yesterday with three craft unions and The Times met separately with the Newspaper Guild, but no agreements were reached on contracts to replace those that expired last March 30.
NEWARK, Oct, 24 (UPI) Federal agents here have recaptured one of six convicted drug dealers who escaped last year from Manhattan's Federal House of Detention.

The antitrust division of the United States Department of Justice is discontinuing the practice of holding advance negotiations with companies to be named in civil antitrust suits. In a talk yesterday to the Oregon Bar Association in Portland, Thomas E. Kauper, head of the division, said "in practice the pre-filing procedure has proved disappointing."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission today ordered four West Coast travel agencies to stop promoting psychic surgery tours to the Philippines and told the agencies to warn hundreds of patients who had gone there that the hoped-for miracle cure was a "total hoax."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (UPI) Birth defects are up to three times higher than normal among babies born in three Ohio towns where polyvinyl chloride, a cancer causing chemical, is manufactured, a Federal health official said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The Soviet Union has bought more than one million tons of American corn since signing a fiveyear grain agreement with the United States earlier this week, it was announced today.

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) Over objections by some local citizens on its board and a donor's threat to withdraw support, the name of the Pasadena Art Museum has been changed to the Norton Simon Museum of Art at Pasadena.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.
Bill Fitch, coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers, has a reputation as a gagster. But yesterday he was not fooling about the Knicks' acquisition of Spencer Haywood from the Seattle SuperSonics.

The Burroughs Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase an additional 45 per cent interest in the Takachiho-Burroughs Company of Japan from the Taka chiho Koheki Company, a Japanese trading company. The revival of "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night may not have had the sparkle of champagne, but it did have the enjoyable fizz of good soda pop. A Federal judge has ruled that it is sexually discriminatory for a company to discharge a male employe for wearing long hair while permitting women employes to wear long hair. The case involves a lawsuit by Louis Longo of Jersey City, who was dismissed from his clerk's job at the New York stock brokerage house of Carlisle DeCoppet Co. He sued for reinstatement and back pay, alleging sex discrimination in the company's grooming regulations.

LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 29 Cheryl Johnston's J.C. Superstar gave a sparkling speed performance at the Washington International horse show tonight and won the international-open jumper class.

The people of Nassau County, which has a population of nearly 1.5 million, have a clear-cut choice on the ballot between literally boss rule and legislative rule. The House Ways and Means Committee has rightly rejected President Ford's $28-billion tax-cut package linked to a $28-billion cut in Federal expenditures. WASHINGTON, Monday, Nov. 3 (Reuters) President Ford had a red mark over his right eyebrow when he returned from Florida early today, the result of a minor accident when he went for a swim.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) Opponents of an Administration-backed bill aimed at increasing the picketing power of striking construction workers said today that they had enlisted the support of about 30 senators for a filibuster to block the measure.
MONTCLAIR, Nov. 2 About 150 women, many carrying babies, filled a lecture hall at Montclair State College yesterday to discuss the often conflicting problems of being a Jew and a woman.

Rabbi Chaim Stern performed the ceremony.

A festival of lights, a day of joy, a time of new beginnings, an occasion for dressing up in new clothes, a pretext for setting off fireworks and turning children loose on sweets, an event of religious significance.

The largest package of proposed state bond issues since 1968, calling for a total of $922 million in capital spending for transportation, housing, water resources and facilities for social and institutional services, will be considered by New Jersey voters tomorrow.

It is not easy to associate the seaside resort town of old people's memories where waiters' jobs were plentiful and visitors stept on the beach all night with the desolate, rubble-strewn community that much of Coney Island has become over the years.
UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 2 Kevin Loughery, the Nets' coach, spent the day off yesterday working to get some movement in his offense and today against the Utah Stars the movement appeared.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 The strike by policemen and firemen last August is the most important issue in this city's election Tuesday, but the candidates for mayor, district attorney, sheriff and supervisor would prefer to talk about almost anything else.
BOSTON, Nov. 2 The oncetepid mayoral contest in Boston has suddenly turned in its closing days into what many observers feel is the bitttrest and dirtiest political campaign here in recent memory.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 2 As far as classic confrontations go within the National Football League, today's clash between the Cincinnati Bengals and the Pittsburgh Steelers was a bit of a bust. Pittsburgh won, 30-24, but the game was not as close as one might believe. The Steelers led, 23-3, midway through the third quarter and their defense had held the Bengals to only 87 total yards before the Cincinnati machine got going.

Nurses and hospital officials at the Jersey City Medical Center signed an agreement yesterday ending a wage dispute that had resulted in a "sickout" that kept nearly 50 nurses off the job.

In a drama last night that would have embarrassed a pulp fiction writer, Ed Giacomin returned to Madison Square Garden in the uniform of the rival Detroit Red Wings. With the cheers of the crowd behind him, the 36-year-old goalie led his new team to a 6-4 beating of his old teammates, the Rangers.
Philip James, a composer and conductor who retired in 1955 as chairman of the music department at New York University, died Saturday at his home, 33 Aqua Drive, Southampton, L.I. He was 85 years old.

Tennessee Williams's "Memoirs," published this week by Doubleday company, was originally entitled "Flee, Flee. This Sad Hotel," a quotation from a poem by Anne Sexton. All this is a welcome benefit not only to Stamford, but also to theatergoers in neighboring areas and in New York.

The American Basketball Association owners will meet here today amid strong reports that the troubled San Diego franchise will fold. The Sails have drawn
Bill Kilmer, the vibrant 36year-old quarterback for the Redskins, suffered a mild separation of the right shoulder against the Giants or Sunday and he will miss one

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10--Senate Democratic leaders indicated today that they had the votes needed to break any filibuster of a New York loan-guarantee bill, after meeting with President Ford to seek a "cooperative" effort on the legislation.

TRENTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Governor Byrne said today that New Jersey and its local governments had managed to raise the annual amount of Federal aid they received by more than $400 million in the last two years.
ANCONA, Italy, Nov. 10 (Reuters) Italy and Yugoslavia signed an agreement here today ending their 30-year-old frontier dispute.
Betty Ford, often described as one of the most outspoken Presidents' wives, has become one of the most popular and is "a solid asset" to her husband, the Harris poll reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) A former Gulf Oil Corporation official has acknowledged making allegedly illegal campaign contributions to at least 15 Senators and Congressmen, incuding cash paid in a hotel men's room and behind a barn, it was learned today.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 9 After almost a decade of effort, Federal, state and local housing programs have made virtually no progress in increasing access by low-income city dwellers to American suburbia.

MADRID, Nov. 4 Many churches have been offering prayers for Generalissimo Francisco Franco and for Spain, ritual prayers that have not made a noticeable difference in the habits of the faithful. Most, if perhaps not all, will hold special services when the ailing leader dies, and the Roman Catholic Church will have the primary role at his funeral.
Jewish leaders reacted with anger throughout the debate in the General Assembly yesterday.

OTTAWA, Nov. 10 Questions in the Canadian Senate and House of Commons about a Senator's financial activities have stirred both the nation and Parliament. A petition to the House of Commons has asked for a judicial inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Most of the Justices of the Supreme Court expressed concern today that some aspects of the new Federal campaign financing laws might impinge on rights guaranteed by the First and Fifth Amendments.

The Viking Press, 50 years old this week, has been sold to Penguin Books, the giant British quality paperback house, for a price that could total $12 million. The merger of the privately held American hardcover publisher with the Penguin combine, effective this week, is the largest in a series of such takeovers that have been ascribed in the book world to rapidly rising publishing costs.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 10 (AP)--Israeli troops killed four Arab guerrillas who croseed the border from Lebanon during the night, the Israeli military command announced today. No Israeli casualties were reported.
MADRID, Nov. 10 (AP) Doctors reported today that Generalissimo Francisco Franco was "progressing without incident" in his third day after emergency surgery.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 Patricia Hearst's trial date was tentatively set today for Dec. 15. However, this may be changed as a result of a hearing next week at which her lawyers will try to reopen the question of her competency to stand trial on charges of armed bank robbery and use of a gun to commit a felony.

The American Stock Exchange, which introduced oddlot trading in Treasury bonds last January in a major effort to attract small investors, will shortly add a smiliar trading program in Government agency bonds, Wall Street bond sources disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The House voted today to authorize annual funding of $88 million to $160 million through 1980 for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10 With a mixture of national pride and reticence, Mexico has been expanding its oil production to the point where it may soon be in a position to play a role in world oil trade and politics.
The proposed closing of four police station houses in the city has been put off until at least Jan. 1, Mayor Beame's office disclosed yesterday.
BOSTON, Nov. 10 The duplication of a wad of applications has caused somewhat of a stir in liberal political circles here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Attorney General Edward H. Levi refused today to give the Federal Bureau of Investigation immediate permission to build a computerized communications network that had been criticized as possibly leading to the creation of a national police force.

The trust departments of a group of 10 leading New York banks experienced net operating losses of $40.5 million but earned money as a whole in 1974, according to a study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Farmers have almost completed a record corn harvest of 5.8 billion bushels this fall, 25 percent larger than last year's and 1 percent more than forecast in October, the Agriculture Department said today.
One defender after another in the last several years has blithely defied the Maroczy bind, a center defined by white pawns at K4 and QB4 versus a black pawn at Q3. But now the party may well be over.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 10 (AP)--Chile's military Government said today that it had arrested 14 left-wing guerrillas and uncovered a plot for the infiltration of 1,200 extremists into southern Chile for terrorist attacks.

NEWINGTON, Conn., Nov. 10 Corporation records entered into evidence at the State Gaming Commission hearings here today support charges that the late John M. Bailey accepted more than $235,000 to help a Bridgeport jai alai developer obtain a state gaming license.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 The General Electric Company conceded today that at least 65 of its employes had become ill over a 15-year period under conditions that "may have been caused by or aggravated by exposure to PCB's," or polychlorinated biphenyls.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 Leaders of the American Petroleum Institute called today for a war against efforts by some Congressmen to break up the petroleum industry.

The Coastal States Gas Corporation and one of its subsidiaries have filed an antitrust suit against the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and two of its affiliates, charging Occidental with restraint of trade in connection with an alleged boycott of Libyan oil.
As if mesmerized by the song of the sweet bird of youth. Henry Aaron will continue swinging for home runs next season when he will be 42 years old.
ROME, Nov. 10 The Food and Agricultural Organization elected a Lebanese, Edouard Saouma, today as Director General.

Unlike other plays in Yiddish, Jacob Gordin's "Gott, Mensch un Tyvel" ("God, Man and the Devil") does not require the ambiance of the Eastern European pale or the shtetl for its effect or its effectiveness. It is not a nostalgic romp through the past nor a play whose point derives from the breaking up of ancient folkways or the widening gap between generations.
Columbia University began its commemoration yesterday of a Revolution that left it with a new name, some famous alumni and enough documents to keep scholars busy for another 200 years.

Sidney B. Whipple, author, editor and journalist, who covered important events here and abroad for major newspapers early this century, died yesterday in Griesheim, West Germany, where he had lived. He was 87 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 The General Assembly tonight adopted an Arab-inspired resolution defining Zionism as "a form of racism and racial discrimination."

Hugh Auchincloss Brown Sr., an electrical engineer who devoted more than 60 years of his life to the promulgation of his theory that a vast polar ice cap would tip the earth over in this century and wipe out civilization, died Sunday night in his home at 115 Prospect Avenue, Douglaston, Queens. He was 96 years old.

Corn and soybeans dropped sharply in price early in the trading session on the Chicago Board of Trade. The immediate reason was crop-report estimates issued over the weekend by Conrad Leslie, a leading commodity analyst and private crop estimator.

The stock market, buffeted yesterday by news that Washington had been discussing an antitrust investigation of General Motors, declined moderately in the morning and then worked itself back up. The net result was a small decline from Friday.
Prince Thou Art, winner of the Florida Derby, was scheduled to undergo surgery today at the New Bolton Center near Philadelphia in an attempt to save his life.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) President Ford saluted the Marine Corps. on its 200th birthday today before a statue at Arlington National Cemetery depicting marines raising the flag on Iwo Jima.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (Reuters) William Hardcastle, radio broadcaster and former editor of The Daily Mail of London, died here today. He was 57 years old.

It looks as if there'll be less advertising around in the near future. If you're one of those consumers who resent the hawking of wares this news will make you glad. However, if you are a manufacturer who depends on advertising to move goods you will be sad.

Mayor Beame made a strong bid for a return of the film industry to New York City studios yesterday. He appeared briefly at the cavernous old Paramount Pictures studio in Long Island City, Queens, where the first major feature film is being made since before World War II.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Scientists working on environmental Standards have been under so much pressure to complete the work that they have not been able to give sufficient time and attention to the effects of low levels of pollution on cancer and heart disease, an executive for the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

WINNING "It's Impossible," sang Jimmy Spencer into his keyboard mike the other night at Gatsby's (7519191), at 873 First Avenue (two doors south of 49th Street). The restaurant's new young entertainer was in a bit of a spot last Wednesday. He was playing and singing against a preoccupied table and bar babble that was somewhat understandable, since most eyes were riveted to a corner TV set silently beaming the Knicks vs. the Houston Rockets.

TRENTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) The Appellate Division of the Superior Court ruled today that tenants in public housing projects could be awarded rent rebates if they were forced to live in uninhabitable conditions.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 10 Vice President Rockefeller, asked today if he would rule out the possibility that he might run for the Presidency next year, said, "Well, nobody knows what might happen."

Within the past few years, we as a people seem to have lost our way, to be floundering in uncertainty, to be unsure of ourselves in our relations to each other and to the world at large. The optimism and moral drive characteristic of America throughout the decades have been largely replaced by a deep-seated cynicism and disillusionment.
Two 19-year-old youths who were freed on Oct. 23 by Bronx Criminal Court Judge John Carro of charges of robbing an elderly woman, were indicted by a grand jury yesterday in the same case.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 10 (UPI) Steven Solian pleaded not guilty today to a Federal charge of participating in a $15,000 bank robbery and slaving.

NAKHODKA, U.S.S.R. A new deep-water port, designed to become the largest in the Soviet Union, is being slowly created at the southern tip of the Soviet Far East to handle a large part of the Soviet's Pacific trade.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 Governor Carey attempted today to persuade top business and labor leaders here of the severe effects that a New York City default would have on them, but there were indications the message may not have 'gotten through.
TRENTON, Nov. 10 (AP)--The Appellate Division of Superior Court upheld today a lower court ruling exempting from local taxation the state football stadium being built in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

The financially troubled Singer Company yesterday reached into the top echelon of the Xerox Corporation for a new chief executive officer. He is Joseph B. Flavin, 47, who until yesterday was president of Xerox's international operations as well as executive vice president and a director of Xerox.

The board of trustees of the State University of New York was ordered yesterday to reverse a decision not to open a school of podiatric medicine at Stony Brook, L.I., this term. It was also ordered to admit all students accepted for the current term.

Former Mayor John V. Lindsay, making his first public venture before a political forum in almost two years, last night defended his record as Mayor and rejected suggestions that his fiscal policies might have contributed to the city's current crisis.

At a luncheon for the Soviet heavyweight boxing team which will take on 10 American amateurs on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, the president of the Garden's boxing department proposed a new opponent for Muhammad Ali.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 Following is the rollcall vote in the United Nations General Assembly tonight on a resolution that classifies Zionism as "a form of racism."

Leslie E. Levi, who retired in 1964 as president of the Ivel Corporation, a leading designer and producer of industrial exhibitions, died Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and had formerly lived here.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 10 (AP)--The first offspring of the famed Secretariat to step into an auction sales ring fell $2,000 short of a world record tonight when a man signing the name C.W. Smith bought weanling filly for $200,000 dollars.

Charles J. Pilliod Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said that the company spent $30 million last year in order to comply with various state and Federal regulations.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Nov. 10 (AP) Roscoe Tanner and Dick Stockton, tired after getting here late from Sweden, were beaten today by British players in the $94,000 Dewar indoor tennis tournament. Top-seeded Arthur Ashe won his second match, beating Mike Estep of Dallas, 6-4, 6-2. Jimmy Connors downed Woitek Fibak of Poland, 6-2, 7-6, for the second time in a week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 The Chicago Police Department's rationale for its undercover surveillance of six local community groups "has all the earmarks of a police state," a Cook County grand jury said today in a report sharply criticizing the department's spying activities.
Negotiators, for The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild of New York reached agreement yesterday on a new three-year contract, averting a strike that had been threatened for yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The three most liberal Justices of the Supreme Court contended today in a strongly worded dissenting opinion that the Court was "plainly" failing in its judicial responsibility by refusing to review two wiretapping cases raising critical issues of invasion of privacy.
George Moran has this thing about eggs especially when they're fried, and sunnyside up.
SMITHTOWN, L.I. Delancey Street is coming to the suburbs, by way of the unexpected route known as business failure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Representative Otis G. Pike, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, said today that the Ford Administration had failed to comply with three of the seven subpoenas issued by the committee last week for a broad range of classified materials.

DOVER, England, Wednesday, Nov. 12 (AP) A British warship and a Panamanian tanker collided in thick fog in the English Channel early today and about 3,000 tons of crude oil spilled into the sea, the coast guard here reported.

When two zealous protectors of the community's need for a crime-free system of law-enforcement fall out, public confidence in the fairness of criminal justice suffers a rude blow one it can poorly afford in this period of shattered trust in most institutions.
LISBON, Nov. 11 (AP) Influential officers are seeking to remove Gen. Otelo Saravia de Carvalho, a leftist, as commander of military security, reliable sources reported today.

Governor Carey announced yesterday that he would appoint two additional special and extraordinary trial judges to help expedite a growing backlog of corruption cases brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor.

ELIZABETH, Nov. 11 The city of Elizabeth and the Jewish Educational Center are codefendants in a civil action on State Superior Court here that charges the center with violating zoning and other ordinances by running "noneducational activities," including a mikvah, or ritual bath.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission began an investigation today into reports that international communications companies had disclosed contents of overseas cables to the National Security Agency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Hasidic Jewish community in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn today won its bid for Supreme Court review of the 1974 redistricting that took the tightly knit group of a single election district and placed portions of it in to separate districts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Army suspended payments today to 900 contractors because of the discovery that it had overspent its procurement budget by about $165-million.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 A default by New York City "though not something to be welcomed, would not be a catastrophe," according to a new study of the city's finances made public today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (Reuters) The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Arthur F. Burns, said today that the board might allow more growth in the United States money supply than previously permitted because of a low rate of growth since July.

Deborah Jean Gilardi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor R. Gilardi Jr., of Columbus, N.J., was married yesterday to Hal Stevens Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer Rose Jr., of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Reynolds Kowalski performed the ceremony in the St. James Roman Catholic Church in Jamesburg, N.J.

ATLANTA, Nov. 11 By the time it is completed in late 1981, Atlanta's new 61-mile, $2.1 billion rapid transit system, the first modern urban transit system in the South, will be the biggest public construction project in the region since the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Marta Valle, a leader of the City's Puerto Rican community and former Commissioner of the Youth Services Agency, died of cancer Monday night at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 41 years old and lived at 42-12 196th Street in Flushing, Queens.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 1l (AP) Marty May, whose comedy and song career spanned more than half a century in vaudeville, theater, radio, television and nightclubs, died today of a heart ailment in Sunrise Hospital. He was 77 years old.
PARIS, Nov. 11 For the first time since the end of World War I 57 years ago France refrained today from celebrating its 1918 victory over the Germans.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 in his first public comment since last night's vote in the United Nations on the Zionism issue, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said tonight that "the United States will ignore this vote and pay no attention to it."

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (UPI) Guy Lafleur and Mario Tremblay scored twice each and Peter Mahovlich picked up four assists tonight as the Montreal Canadiens trounced the Minnesota North Stars, 6-0, on Ken Dryden's second shutout of the season.
TUNIS, Nov. 11 (UPI) The Tunisian bartender holding three hostages in the Belgian Embassy while demanding the return of his wife, surrendered to the police today.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 11 The chairman of the largest chain of banks in Mississippi urged President Ford today to help New York City through its financial crisis.

Physicians and nurses at St. Clare's Hospital in Denville said yesterday they would continue to give round-theclock care to Karen Anne Quinlan in the wake of the court decision Monday that said any decision to remove her from her life-sustaining respirator belonged to her physicians.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said tonight that the United States viewed the meeting this weekend of major Western nations as a forum not only for discussing specific economic issues but also for instilling confidence that democracies can still manage their own destinies.
LUANDA, Angola, Nov. 11 Two competing Governments were proclaimed today for Angola on this first day of independence from Portugal.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 11 (UPI) The International Business Machines Corporation announced today new versions of its System-370 Models 115 and 125 providing cardless disk entry and double the disk capacity of earlier models.
Scholars and other experts on the United Nations yesterday deplored the General Assembly's anti-Zionist vote as harmful to the world organization and to the cause of peace in the Middle East.
LISBON, Nov. 11 Portugal has given independence to Angola, a colony for 500 years, but never has that land seemed so close.

MARION, Ohio, Nov. 11 (AP) Larry Barnett says he holds two television sports announcers, Tony Kubek and Curt Gowdy, accountable for the threats on his family over a controversial call he made in baseball's 1975 World Series.

The Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms announced yesterday that it would not require the producers of alcohol beverages to list ingredients on labels.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 The case of Ralph G. Newman, a literary appraiser and Lincoln Scholar who is accused of lying and helping former President Richand M. Nixon to report an illegal $450,000 tax deduction, went to the jury in United States District Court here tonight.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 11--Australia was thrown into what may be the bitterest election campaign in its history today after the Governor General unexpectedly dismissed Prime Minister Gough Whitlam and dissolved both houses of Parliament.
Loomis Burrell, a retired manufacturer of dairy machinery equipment, died yesterday at his home in Little Falls, N.Y. He was 103 years old.

The Saudi Arabian Oil Minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, has given oil consumers encouraging news. He said in an interview published yesterday in The London Daily Telegraph that he expected crude oil prices, frozen until next June, to remain at present levels until the end of next year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 A judgment or $7.75 million in an unusual libel case was returned here last night by a Superior Court jury against the Pacific Gas Electric Company and in favor of a television documentary producer.

Hailed as "two great New Yorkers who have preserved the faith," Andrew and Marian Heiskell were honored by the Citizens Union here last night for their "outstanding contribution to the quality of life in New York City and the nation."

Former United States Senator Clinton P. Anderson of New Mexico, who retired in 1972 following a long career in Congress and as Secretary of Agriculture, died yesterday at his home in Albuquerque. He was 80 years old.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Nov. 11 (AP)--The infant daughter of a couple who had fought against giving her a blood transfusion that doctors say saved her life left the hospital today.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., Nov. 11 (AP) Leo J. Sheridan, founder of one of Chicago's leading real-estate concerns who was Ambassador to Ireland in 196869, died yesterday. He was 78 years old.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 11 (AP) Gunmen killed a young man at a bus stop in Belfast today in what was believed to be another incident in the feud between the rival wings of the Irish Republican. Army.

BONN, Nov. 10 (Reuters) A meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's nuclear planning group has been called off following the dismissal of the United States Defense Secretary, James R. Schlesinger, informed West German sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Retail sales rebounded after September's decline to post a 9 percent gain in October from year-earlier levels, the Commerce Department estimated today.

Five Brooklyn community planning districts containing sprawling poverty neighborhoods account for three quarters of the borough's new residential construction, according to a new summary by the City Planning Commission.

MOSCOW In one of the two cramped rooms that make up Andrei Sakharov's Moscow apartment, there stands a wooden bookcase with glass doors. Taped inside the glass are jumbles of family snapshots, and among them hangs a small piece of white paper on which Mr. Sakharov has written two columns of numbers, radio frequencies. Over one column appear the words "Voice of America," over the other, "BBC."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 World Vision, an evangelical Protestant relief organization, filed suit in a Federal court in Los Angeles on Tuesday in an effort to overturn a decision by a Superior Court judge that removed Cambodian children brought to the United States during Operation Babylift last April, from the control of a sectarian adoption agency.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) A nationwide strike by four railroad shopcraft unions scheduled for Tuesday morning "has been averted," Federal officials said early today.
Kenneth Ballard Murdock, who had been the Francis Lee Higginson Professor of English Literature at Harvard University, died yesterday at the Newton (Mass.) Convalescent Center. He was 80 years old.

An amendment to the State Constitution to permit legalized gambling under certain religious, charitable and nonprofit auspices appears to have been approved by the voters, although final results will not be certified until mid-December, and there are still enough uncounted votes to tip the scales the other way.

Johnny Rivers, who is at the Other End through tonight, is a Los Angeles-based singer with a considerable diverse, not to say confused, past.
