IOWA CITY, Nov. 18 Early this morning, a small group of scholars and librarians gathered before a walkin safe in the special collections library of the University of Iowa and paid a brief tribute to a controversial Iowan who died 10 years ago today.

In 1969, Ely Callaway, then president of Burlington Industries here, put himself into the wine business by planting a vineyard near Temecula, Calif., at a time when many people were doing the same thing. The difference in Mr. Callaway's case was that Temecula is near San Diego, more than 600 miles from what is usually considered California's premium wine country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Administration officials say that United States relations with Chile have deteriorated in recent weeks, mainly because of disputes over human-rights issues.
TRENTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) New Jersey's Pick-It lottery, the nation's first legalized numbers game designed to compete with the illegal rackets, was extended and expanded today for a year.

What happened at the Chateau de Rambouillet? For one thing, Rambouillet produced a communique not just an ordinary communique, written in bureaucratic language, but one written in resonant and cadenced prose poetry. The heads of state "came together because of shared beliefs and shared responsibilities." Their success "will strengthen, indeed is essential to, democratic societies everywhere."

The profit upswing reported by retail merchandising chains in the third fiscal quarter was further emphasized yesterday with earnings increases of 46.2 percent reported by Federated Department Stores Inc. and 41.2 percent by the May Department Stores Company.

"Philadelphia, Here I Come!" is not a homecoming, but a home-leaving play. Gar O'Donnell's destination is America, which offers him challenge and opportunity or so he convinces himself. But his place of birth, his natural habitat, Is Ireland. He can't take Ireland with him. Therefore, the night before his departure he packs his suitcase with "memories, images and impressions," all of which, he knows, will make him "miserable."

BUCHAREST, Nov. 18 (AP) Ilie Nastase of Rumania defeated his friend and doubles partner, Jimmy Connors, 7-6, 3-6, 7-5, today in an exhibition tennis match before a sellout crowd of 7,000 at the Palace of Sports and Culture.

Next year probably there will be ingredient labeling on cosmetic products. The Food and Drug Administration has already published the final regulations, and the cosmetics industry has almost, if not quite, accepted the idea.

WASHINGTON, Nov.18 The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent a note and a tape recording to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in late 1964 that the black leader came to believe was an effort to drive him to suicide, according to testimony and documents presented today to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

A 28-year-old former resident at a state narcotics rehabilitation center testified yesterday that she had been compelled to engage in sexual activity with male officers there in order to obtain minor privileges.
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 19 Terrorists threw a bomb through the window of a packed restaurant in the Chelsea district last night, killing two persons and injuring 17 others, five of them seriously.

Housing starts rose 15 percent in October from the previous month, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. But housing industry specialists expressed doubt that the one month upturn signaled the arrival of a long-awaited robust recovery in this lagging sector of the economy.

HANOVER, West Germany Michael Sobbek, a collegebound student in the Humboldt School here, has not had a course in art or music since eighth grade. For two years in a row he has had only one semester of history. On Wednesday afternoons school simply closes all for lack of teachers and money to pay them.

TRENTON, Nov. 18 Yonkers and Philadelphia, along with several Long Island communities, including Glen Cove, were banned by the State Supreme Court here from dumping any more of their garbage in New Jersey.

Old jokes, as anyone who has moved his lips in synch with an ancient punch line can attest, never die. They reappear, sometimes, it seems, with ripple effect, popping up in Topeka not long after they were heard in New York, fanning out to the nation's breadbasket through the offices of the nation's salesmen.
NEW HAVEN During the Pacific war, Americans considered all Japanese malignant, especially Hirohito. Today, thirty years after the war, Japanese by and large seem benign even the same Emperor.
Mayor Beame yesterday named Victor Marrero, a 34year-old first assistant counsel to Governor Carey, to replace John E. Zuccotti as chairman of the City Planning Commission.

"Certified Raw Milk is Here Again," says the sign in the health food store. The black carton in the store's dairy case sells for 79 cents, but the high price per quart is the least of the issues that make raw milk the focus of controversy.

A fan in the $12.50 seats fell asleep last night during the Knicks' 10l-92 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers at Madison Square Garden. There were others in the crowd of 14,994 who did some excessive yawning.

Two small packages of radioactive material that are "extremely dangerous if swallowed or handled," according to the city's Health Department, are missing and presumed to have been stolen from the Queens Hospital Center, 82-68 164th Street, Jamaica.

One, legitimate but only moderately effective, is an ABC "Afterschool Special" called "The Shaman's Last Raid." The other, questionable but completely ineffective, is "Rickles," an hour with Don Rickles in Las Vegas on CBS at 10 P.M.
Although it was rumored previously, yesterday it became official Ted Bates Company is getting back the Marx Toys account, currently valued at some $7 million in billings.

Next Tuesday's "New York rally" will be held, not surprisingly, in Times Square, still symbolically the city's heart. Theater marquees will proclaim for the day "New York Is United" instead of advertising the habits of nymphets and other characters.

VINELAND, N.J. Fresh fennel, Ralph Formisano was saying, can become a sort of addiction. Mr. Formisano, who is known in some quarters as the "fennel king of New Jersey," was standing in the middle of his 40-acre fennel crop that, caressed by a late autumn wind, resembled a vast and undulating sea of green feathers.

Governor Carey has agreed to grant municipal unions and local banks a voice in governing the city, by expanding the seven-member Emergency Financial Control Board to provide a seat for each of those groups, Felix G. Rohatyn said yesterday. Officials in the Governor's office confirmed the statement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Eula W. Weston, former chairman of the Maine State Racing Commission, died yesterday at Circle Terrace Hospital in Alexandria, Va. She was 81 years old and lived with her daughter, Emily W. Leommartson, in Alexandria.

The late Mme. H.P. Blavatsky, forefinger to chin, full face framed in kinky hair, gazed with intelligent eyes from a bulletin board in a hotel reception area here this weekend as her followers from all over the world mingled to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Theosophical Society, which she helped to found.
Stefano Cusumano, a painter and for 19 years an art teacher as Cooper Union, died yesterday in Eureka, Calif. He was 63 years old.

Egmont Sonderling, president of the Sonderling Broadcasting Corporation, said Monday that he "was doing a public service" by proposing a "reasonable concept" to keep jazz programming on radio station WRVR-FM.
As the stock market waited for news of progress toward a solution of New York City's financial problems, it became a little nervous yesterday and its early gains eroded.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 18 The way the season had gone for Jim Obradovich he could have seen more action at Giant games as a hot dog vender.

TRENTON, Nov. 18 At the fourth State Supreme Court hearing in four years on the question of exclusionary zoning in Madison Township, the Department of the Public Advocate today urged an end to delays in implementing the court's Mount Laurel decision.
MADRID, Nov. 18 Generalissimo Francisco Franco's body temperature was lowered today to 91.4 degrees in an effort to halt further internal hemorrhaging. Normal temperature is 98.6 degrees.
A younber brother of City Councilman Samuel D. Wright was found shot to death late Monday night on a Brooklyn street, the second brother of the Councilman to die by gunfire in two years.
Right on schedule but hidden at first behind a layer of haze, yesterday's lunar eclipse turned into a thing of serene beauty as the glowing, coppery moon rose above the horizon for the finale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) The National Labor Relations Board today upheld a ruling that the Ford Motor Company had illegally prohibited an employee at its Mahwah. N.J., plant from distributing union literature to fellow workers.

Bill Veeck had invested more than a year of his life in an effort to buy the Baltimore Orioles when Jerry Hoffberger, the owner, told him abruptly last June that the deal was off. "This means," Veeck said the next day, "the loss of a friend, the loss of a ball club, the loss of a year and a lot of dollars and for me at the age of 61, the loss of innocence."

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 18 Charging that exclusionary zoning practices by suburban communities aggravated New York City's fiscal problems, Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan joined a coalition of housing and civilrights groups today in instituting a lawsuit against the Town of Brookhaven.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the United States would soon propose the convening of "multilateral" talks on peace in the Middle East.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 18 (Agence France-Presse) The electoral system in South Vietnam will be set up like North Vietnam's for the election of a constituent assembly for the whole of Vietnam.

A 27-year-old man with reputed underworld connections was gunned down on a heavily traveled Brooklyn street yesterday morning by a man who the police believe was a professional "hit man" as the victim was driving to court to face a murder charge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Representative Al Ullman of Oregon, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that he would insist that the House get a chance to vote on the "reform" provisions of the pending tax bill, even if that meant a stalemate that permitted the 1975 reductions to expire at the end of this year.

The New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union has accused the Passaic County Proscutor's office of suppressing evidence and relying upon prejured testimony to convict Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis of a triple murder.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18 Sniping and other shooting incidents erupted throughout today in several quarters of Beirut, but in some neighborhoods a bustling commercial life continued.
Several thousand demonstrators protested slashes in the city's antipoverty programs yesterday by blocking traffic at major intersections and by holding marches and rallies throughout the city.
The title of "Bridge Man of the Year" has been awarded, by an overwhelming vote of bridge writers throughout the world, to Julius Rosenblum, president of the World Bridge Federation.

The barricade of hazards in the way of getting things done is growing higher. In the third grade or so, it was a relatively routine steeplechase: You asked the teacher how to spell "curb" and she put up the usual barrier by saving, "Look it up in the dictionary."
After decades as pre-eminent decorator to the rich and famous, and two years of semi-retirement, Billy Baldwin has designed his first line of furniture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The Ford Administration has refused to comply with a mandate of Congress that it specify which nations receiving American military assistance engage in repeated "gross violations" of human rights.
Madame Maigret's Recipes, presented by Robert J. Courtine (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $8.95).

FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI) Asserting that there had been a wholesale raid on the staff of its Fresno, Calif., office, Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., a Los Angeles-based brokerage house, filed a $5 million lawsuit today against one of Wall Street's largest concerns.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The State Department said today that it had received reports indicating that the Soviet Union was stepping up the supply of weapons to the Luanda Goverment in Angola.
LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The militant left in the British trade union movement suffered a sharp setback today when it lost control of the powerful engineering union.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The Federal Election Commission cleared the way today for corporations to invest millions of dollars in contributions from their stockholders

Dr. John H. Janney, for many years a member of the Rockefeller Foundation medical field staff in Rumania, Spain, Portugal and Chile, died Thursday in Catonsville, Md. From his retirement in 1959 to 1974, he had been an epidemiologist with the Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. He was 82 years old.
Evangelos D. Stamatiou, founder and president of Atlantic Steamers Supply Company, ship chandlers, of Hoboken, N.J., died yesterday of cancer at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 63 years old.
Lester L. McDowell, a manufacturers' representative, died Monday at the National Naval Medical Center, Bethesda, Md. He was 60 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

GROTON, Conn., Nov. 18 Adm. James Fife Jr., who commanded all submarines in the Southwest Pacific in World War II, died yesterday in the Submarine Medical Center Hospital at the submarine base here. He was 78 years old and lived in Stonington.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 18 The Buffalo Sabres, showcasing a new and more defensive style, continued their old habit of beating the New York Islanders tonight, this time by a score of 3-1. In their four seasons, covering 16 games, the Islanders have never beaten Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The Labor Department has returned "for more specific charges" a formal complaint against the leadership of Arnold R. Miller, the reformist president of the United Mine Workers of America. The complaint, filed by a faction that controls the union's international executive board has been demanding Mr. Miller's ouster.

The two most famous dancers in the world they are not even named on the front of the playbill, which shows a certain class are back together and back in New York. Last night they opened a twoweek, completely sold-out season a particularly taxing season at the Uris Theater. They are, incidentally, for anyone still in the dark, Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev.

CANBERRA, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 19 (AP) A package bomb addressed to Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser was discovered and defused in Canberra today shortly after a letter bomb addressed to the Permier of Queensland state injured two people in Brisbane.

The George Gershwin-Cole Porter evening has some rarely presented music and a cast that includes Mabel Mercer, Peter...
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18 President Isabel Martinez de Peron has initiated a new political strategy designed to keep her in power for the remainder of her term.

Bench Dan Devine and his Notre Dame players branded as "a lie" a published report that the Fighting Irish voted not to play in the Cotton Bowl because the players were upset with Devine's leadership, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
TORONTO, Nov. 18 Pomme D'Api, who spent both the Washington International and National horse shows as an also-ran, won his second class of the Royal Winter Fair horse show tonight.

A controversial proposal by 12 utilities in the state to place a monthly surcharge on customers' bills to raise funds for financing exploration for natural gas was rejected yesterday by the New York State Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Senate approved a $90.7 billion defense appropriations bill today after rejecting a proposed additional cut of $564 million to drop the total to the level approved by the House.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 Even as they looked to Washington for long-term assistance, New York City and state officials acknowledged today that they still did not have the cash to pay municipal employees and contractors next week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Congressional and Administration aides said today that the rollback of crude oil prices in the compromise energy bill that is expected to reach President Ford next month would lead to price reductions for consumers of only about a penny a gallon not 3.5 cents mentioned by lawmakers last week.
PARIS Sonia Rykiel sits comfortably in a quasi-lotus position on the windowsill of the studio above her boutique on the Rue de Grenelle.

A trial examiner has recommended the suspension of a 64-year-old Queens elementary school teacher who allegedly "banged a student against a concrete wall and pulled hair from another students scalp in an attempt to keep order," a school official said last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The House Agriculture Committee reversed itself today and approved a provision of a grainreform bill calling for Federal inspection and grading of export shipments.
DETROIT, Nov. 18 The General Motors Corporation announced today that because of stronger car sales it was planning to increase the production of four cars and two light trucks early next year.

The bottom fell out of the soybean and grain futures markets yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as those holding long positions found it difficult to maintain their positions in such futures in the face of predictions of record crops.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 A lawyer involved in the crossexamination of firearms experts in the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy asked a state judge today for permission to call witnesses whose testimony he said would show that further ballistics tests were needed to prove or disprove the so-called "second-gun theory."

ATLANTA, Nov. 18 (AP) Third-period goals by Garry Monahan and Gerry O'Flaherty enabled the Vancouver Canucks to salvage a 2-2 National Hockey League tie with the Atlanta Flames tonight.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 18 (AP) A group of black businessmen rescued the financially troubled Virginia Squires at the 11th hour today, saving the American Basketball Association team from collapse and promising to help rejuvenate support for the club across the state.

The National Steel Corporation said yesterday it would increase prices on Jan. 15 on the steel that is used primarily for beverage cans.

HARTFORD Dr. Thomas Andrew Grasso has been many things in his 60 years. He has run a movie house, a lumber business and a machine shop. He taught and became a high school principal in East Hartford. He is a painter of some merit. But he has never been a Governor and, until Ella T. Grasso's inauguration in Connecticut last January, he was never a Governor's husband. He is the only one in the country.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 18 The Livingston College community here appears equally divided over the proposal to rename the school Paul Robeson College in honor of the singer and actor, who is a 1919 alumnus of Rutgers University. A vote on the matter will be taken by the college faculty chamber tomorrow.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 18 (UPI) The dollar, after some profit taking following yesterday's sharp upturn, settled at lower levels in quiet trading on most European money markets today. The price of gold fell sharply.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) Only 20 percent of the Scots and 10 percent of the Welsh want complete independence from Britain, according to a poll taken on proposals to grant more autonomy to Scotland and Wales.

Arthur Bisguier is accident prone. His colleagues also drop games to much lower opponents from time to time, but none falter as colorfully or as frequently as the Rock Hill, N.Y., grandmaster.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 19 (AP)-- Copper-exporting nations, setting their sights on raising export prices, approved today a continuation of 15 percent pro duction cutbacks and voted to consider setting up a buffer stock to combat inflation in the metal.

While Governor Carey was in the midst of state and city fiscal crises, a Carey-for-President boomlet took shape yesterday in Cortland County as the Democratic organization there endorsed his candidacy.

The biggest bridge game ever played, the charity game of the American Contract Bridge League, will take place next Tuesday evening at 506 sites. Most of the games are in the continental United States, but there will also be games in Alaska, Puerto Rico, Canada, Mexico, Germany, Hong Kong, Cuba, Indonesa, the Bahamas, Greece, Australia, Singapore, the Philippines, Iran, Korea, Japan and the Marshall Islands.

BOSTON, Nov. 19--Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana began this week to accelerate the pace of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and today won the endorsement of Lieut. Gov. Thomas P. O'Neill 3d of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) --The House Rules Committee cleared the way today for House votes on the multibilliondollar tax-cut-extension and tax-revision bill, but refused to allow the full House to vote on President Ford's proposal to tie a Federal spending ceiling to the tax bill.

The Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus is scheduled to meet with Governor Carey today and intends to press for minority representation on the two state agencies monitoring the city's budget, the Emergency Financial Control Board and the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

Charles G. Rodman, chairman of the Grand Union Company, was appointed yesterday the standby trustee of the W. T. Grant Company in the event the financially distressed Grant cannot reach an agreement with its creditors and is compelled to shift from Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings to Chapter X.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- President Ford said today that he would not now support Federal financial aid to prevent a New York City default, but would reconsider his position next week if the city and state took "further concrete actions."

ALBANY, Nov. 19--Governor Carey and the Legislature's leaders were meeting here tonight to try to break the partisan deadlock ovar a $200 million revenue package for New York City that all sides agree is a prerequisite to President Ford's approval of any direct Federal aid to the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--Industry executives told Senators today that two antitrust bills to break up the largest oil companies and to prohibit ownership by one company of oil, coal and other fuels would create shortages of capital and drive energy prices up.
ELWOOD, Ill., Nov. 19 (AP)-- Four cars of a high-speed Amtrak turbotrain derailed today when it collided with a sixwheeled truck, injuring 39 persons.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 19-- Friends of Gov. Marvin Mandel obtained a $54,000 loan from a Roman Catholic order to help pay the cost of the Governor's divorce settlement in 1974, it was reported today.
TOKYO, Nov. 19--Prime Miister Takeo Miki today openly admitted that his handling of his nation's political, diplomatic, economic, and military affairs had been inadequate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--A top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that there was no "statutory basis or justification" for some 25 separate incidents of bureau harassment of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. during a six-year campaign to discredit the civil rights leader.
FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP) --Employees who switched suddenly from one stock-brokerage firm here to another have been barred temporarily from using any accounts from their previous employment.
MADRID, Thursday, Nov. 20 --Generalissimo Francisco Franco died early today after 36 years of dictatorial rule over Spain. He was 82 years old.

A State Supreme Court Justice yesterday upheld the City Board of Education's right to shorten the school day of pupils, the most controversial element of the settlement that ended last September's teachers' strike.

The Photoengravers Union warned yesterday of a possible strike against The New York Times at 5 P.M. today if it did not agree to continue a contract clause giving the union jurisdiction for platemaking for offset presses.

TRENTON, Nov. 19 (AP)--A state appeals court rebuked a Superior Court judge yesterday because he apparently assumed that a woman defendant had an illicit relationship with a man who had been accused of the crime to which she pleaded guilty.
WOODLYNNE, Nov. 18--The Rev. John H. Brent was rebuffed tonight in a second effort to get a zoning grant that borough officials say he needs 'to move his congregation to a vacant church here.

The state's Emergency Financial Control Board took three steps yesterday toward bolstering the soundness of the city's five pension systems at a time when the systems are being viewed as a source of heavy borrowing for the city.

ARCOSANTI COMMUNITY, Ariz.--The desert is a traditional breeding ground of visions. Simple mirages or the ecstasies of holy men, they take ethereal shape in the heat and cruelty of the sunblasted earth. Arcosanti Community is a palpable vision, rising dustily from a balsaltic mass overlooking the Agua Fria River about 70 miles north of Phoenix.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--A West Coast regional employee of the department of Health, Education and Welfare invoked his constitutional right against being required to incriminate himself today at Senate hearings into alleged fraud in the Federal student loan program.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, which recently reported a 52 percent decline in its thirdquarter earnings, purchased last month $85.8 million worth of property that was earning its owners no income at the time of the sale, according to reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission.

A 21-year-old paroled mugger who in 1972 kept a diary listing 30 victims, the weapon used and the amount of money taken was arrested again yesterday in the Bronx and charged with robbing two elderly women of 45 cents while menacing them with a heavy steel chain, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--The Federal Reserve Board approved today a set of organizational changes involving the Marine Midland Bank and the Bank of New York that will enable them to start statewide branching at the beginning of next year as allowed by New York State law.
Leonard Bernstein, who had been scheduled to conduct a series of performances of Beethoven's "Fidelio" at the Metropolitan Opera beginning Jan. 2 has withdrawn from the assignment.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 19--Federal District Judge Thomas J. MacBride, in a decision that he himself said might be "wrong," refused today to dismiss the charges or grant a mistrial in the case of Lynette Alice Fromme.

In his best work these abrupt shifts of attention create an atmosphere of liveliness and at other timas provoke a sense of repeated anticlimax. ALBANY, Nov. 19--New York City's last hope to avoid failure to pay its bills next week rests with the successful enactment by the Legislature of new city taxes and a favorable word from President Ford on longterm loan guarantees, fiscal officials said today.

Marine Midland Banks Inc., the nation's 12th-largest banking organization, disclosed plans yesterday to write off $25 million in bad loans and said it would report a loss for the fourth quarter of this year.

LONDON, Nov. 19--Britain's major literary prize, the Booker Award, was given today to Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, the German-born novelist who has spent more than 25 years in India.

Federal District Judge John Pratt yesterday ordered two New Jersey trucking companies to name new chief executives and special legal counsel to investigate alleged illegal use of pension funds and to refrain from further alleged violations of securities laws.

LONDON, Nov. 20 The reaction to the death of Generalissimo Francisco Franco was muted in most West European capitals. Officials went no further than routine diplomatic courtesies, and the press seemed less critical than usual of Spain and the dictator.

The union representing 217,000 elementary, secondary and college teachers in New York State is on the verge of ending its affiliation with the National Education Association, an action that would be a bitter setback to the cause of teacher unity throughout the country.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (Reuters) A top Soviet space official indicated today that the automatic docking yesterday of an unmanned Soyuz spaceship with the Salyut 4 orbital laboratory was a test run of a combined ferry and safety service for future manned missions.

On fall Sundays in New York, the avenues are alive with families searching for Something to Do.

Their noses quivering, the pop-music-business mavens sniff continually for trends. If you can spot a trend, the thinking seems to run, you can make hits. Trend-searching is common in any big-money popular-art industry, of course; witness the deluge of disaster epics, black exploitation vehicles and the like.

Stock prices drifted lower yesterday in moderate trading, with the market showing little response to mixed economic reports and continued uncertainty over the unresolved New York City financial crisis.
Teachers belonging to the United Federation of Teachers have ratified by a margin of better than 3 to 1 the new twoyear contract that emerged from the five-day school strike in September.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 William E. Colby, the Director of Cental Intelligence, has surprised Israel's supporters on Capitol Hill by asserting that Israel's military superiority over the Arabs was increasing but that in another Middle East war Israel would probably suffer 8,000 dead, more than three times the 2,500 fatalities in the October 1973 war.
EAST BERLIN, Nov. 20 As a result of continuing differences over political strategies, Europe's Communists have put off until next year their plan to hold a European Communist Party conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 United States officials said today that Cuba had sent 3,000 fighting men and advisers to Angola, to which the Soviet Union has shipped large quantities of arms in recent weeks in support of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) Television stations that broadcast old Ronald Reagan movies will be liable for equal time demands by other Republican Presidential candidates, a Federal Communications Commission spokesman said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 The Northeastern United States and Ontario appear to be "hot spots" for concentrations of potentially harmful polychlorinated biphenyls in people, wildlife and fish, but scientists presenting research papers here today made it clear that no geographical area can be considered safe from this group of chemicals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 The House Commerce subcommittee on energy and power approved today by a vote of 12 to 4, an emergency bill that would let interstate pipelines short of natural gas pay more than the Federal ceiling price for extra supplies this winter.

The Federal Government yesterday won a $1 million settle ment of a Medicare overpayment claim against Charles E. Sigety, owner of the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home on the Upper East Side. It was the largest such recovery known to officials here.

Ella Harrell is 52 years old and has eight children. For the last 11 years, she has worked as a janitor in a Harlem Head Start program, using her earnings from this and jobs like it in the past to send six of her children to college.
Fog that enveloped the metropolitan area forced the closing of all 118 miles of the New Jersey Turnpike for five hours early yesterday, causing extensive traffic jams for morning rush-hour commuters.
ALBANY, Nov. 20 The Dairylea Milk Cooperative Inc. and three of its former officers have been indicted by a grand jury here on charges of selling adulterated milk to state institutions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 The Roman Caholic bishops of the United States significantly stepped up today the church's fight against abortion by approving a plan to create nonsectarian "pro-life" groups in every Congressional district.
MIAMI, Nov. 20 Mr. Carvin was being held here on provisional bail of $500,000, pending arraignment tomorrow before a United States magistrate.
Harness horses who spend their winters racing in deep-freeze weather may soon be suffering less and traveling faster.
Photoengravers at The New York Times called off a strike threatened for yesterday and agreed to continue negotiations on a new contract.

WASHINGTON Since the retirement of William O. Douglas from the Supreme Court, there has been much speculation that President Ford would nominate a replacement who would join the four Nixon appointees in a solid conservative majority. For a number of reasons, the greater likelihood is that Mr. Ford will strengthen the moderate center of the Court, possibly with a nominee of real distinction.

The ninth-inning run that won the World Series for the Cincinnati Reds proved to be worth $5,734.59 a man yesterday when the top teams in baseball sliced up their shares of the postseason prize money.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 The State Board of Education today approved, by a vote of 10 to 2, a series of controversial new regulations for New Jersey's 607 local school districts, requiring them to provide a "thorough and efficient" education, as mandated by the State Supreme Court, for all public school children.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 President Ford announced today a series of measures designed to protect American citizens and businesses against discrimination because of foreign boycotts.

Prices improved slightly yesterday in the Government and corporate bond markets, but new offerings met with varying degrees of success especially in the tax-exempt sector. After the Federal Reserve released figures late in the day showing another substantial increase in the money supply, small price declines appeared in some Treasury and corporate bonds.
CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 20 (AP) Haroon Rahim of Pakistan and two Americans, Alex Mayer and Tom Gorman, advanced today to the singles quarterfinals of India's Grand Prix lawn tennis championships.

WEST BERLIN In 1971, when France, Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union signed a treaty formally recognizing the status quo in this divided city, predictions abounded that West Berlin would quickly become a "turntable" for the Western world's trade with Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 Corporate profits, both before and after tax, showed in the third quarter the largest percentage increase in 25 years but remained below earnings of a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported today.

LONDON, Nov. 20 A few weeks ago, William Wolfe, dressed in a red plaid kilt of his own making, sat in a small car on a narrow road in the shadow of Edinburgh Castle and spoke with optimism about the day when Scotland would be rid of the English yoke, set free to pursue its course as an independent nation.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 20 (AP) Governor Byrne hinted strongly today that there was one aspect of the prison record of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter that would weigh favorably in the inmate's bid for executive clemency.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 20 They call it The Big Game, the annual football match between Stanford and California, the equivalent of The Game between Yale and Harvard on the opposite side of the continent. But yesterday's installment here has special elements, and is part of a larger picture in West Coast college athletics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) A House subcommittee refused today to ban so-called Saturday night special pistols, and then approved handgun control legislation stripped of the most controversial proposals.
Four youths snatched a woman's pocketbook containing $39,000 in cash in the Morningside Heights area of Manhattan last evening, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of New Jersey, who is under investigation by a Federal grand jury in Newark, introduced a resolution in the House of Representatives today calling for the impeachment of Jonathan L. Goldstein, United States Attorney for New Jersey, and his executive assistant, Bruce I. Goldstein.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) President Ford issued a message of sympathy today on the death of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, assuring the Spanish Government and people of continued cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating a report by two airline pilots that they saw missiles near their passenger jet as it flew over southern irginia, an official of the agency said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 (AP) The entire coaching staff of the San Francisco Giants, including Manager Wes Westrum, has been officially dismissed in preparation for selling the club, a Giants executive said today.
TRENTON, Nov. 20 (AP) The New Jersey Division of Motor Vehicles has warned motorists not to put unauthorized Bicentennial license plates on their vehicles.

The Crane Company announced late Wednesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had approved its prospectus describing its exchange offer of 8 percent sub ordinated debentures for 5 million shares of common stock of the Anaconda Company. Crane said it was proceeding with the offer, which will expire Dec. 11, 1975, unless extended. If more than 5 million shares are tendered, Crane will purchase shares on a prorated basis. Those not bought will be returned.
MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (Reuters) Dolores Ibarruri, the exiled Spanish Communist leader, called today for widespread action by the people of Spain after the death of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) The House Select Committee on Intelligence voted today to move ahead with at least one contempt citation against Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger despite President Ford's protest that the action "involves grave matters affecting our conduct of foreign policy."

MADRID, Nov. 20 Nothing has been made easy for Juan Carlos de Borbon, the 37-yearold Prince who will become King of Spain Saturday as the designated successor of Fran cisco Franco. Chance and cir cumstance have combined to make the start of his reign an inauspi cious one, whether he contemplates the domestic or the international scene.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 A bipartisan, select committee of the Senate reported today that officials of the United States Government instigated assassination plots against two foreign leaders and became embroiled in plotting that led to the deaths of three others.
"The Legend of Valentino" might easily be dismissed as seductive trash. Then again, it could be defended as a sophisticated distillation and reflection of seductive trash.

Contrary to Yale lore, when Capt. John Smoot and his Yale teammates appear in the Bowl tomorrow to play Harvard for the 100th time, it won't be the most important thing in their lives. But it is important: the Ivy League Championship will be at stake.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 20 (AP) A report that the Norfolk Investment Company would directly invest $200,000 into the financially ailing Virginia Squires was a "misunderstanding," the general manager of the company reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 In a world of travel guides, restaurant guides and even sportsviewing guides, there is a place for a guide to economic statistics.

Caught in a quandary, officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation are considering a proposal to make their massive intended public exchange of city notes for M.A.C. bonds contingent on some form of Federal assistance.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market declined in light trading yesterday as investors continued to show disappointment over President Ford's refusal to give the word that he was willing to help New York City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 The Senate Democratic leadership, fearing too narrow a margin of support, prevented a floor vote today on making public the report on political assassinations, according to Senate sources.
TEL AVIV, Friday, Nov. 21 Arab guerrillas infiltrating from Syria on the Golan Heights last night killed at least three Israelis who resisted their attempt to take them hostage.

Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, who last week announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President, plans to enter primaries in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania in his quest for delegates to next year's national convention.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 Superior Court Judge Thomas W. Le Sage ruled today that Rancho La Costa, a southern California hotel and real estate development with alleged links to organized crime, and its four principal owners were "public figures" and therefore valid subjects for probing scrutiny by the press.

Investigators on the trail of Puerto Rican terrorists who set off bombs elsewhere in New York have been focusing on a group of fugitives who were accused of plotting five 1969 hotel and nightclub bombings in the San Juan area.

In a significant interpretation of the new campaign finance law, the Federal Election Commission has now put corporations on virtually the same basis as labor unions in helping fund political candidates and in paying the expenses of the committees through which the contributions pass.
Dr. Helen Zagat, pastor of the Church of Divine Unity here, died yesterday at her home at 123 West 57th Street. She was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) The chairman of the Senate intelligence committee said today that the contention of William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence, that the panel was endangering the lives of agents named in its report was "absurd."

A Federal judge has dismissed most of the claims in a civil rights suit that Bernard Bergman, the nursing-home operator, filed early this year against a state official, an Assemblyman and a New York Times reporter.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 The Republican and Democratic leadership here tentatively agreed tonight on a $200 million New York City tax package that does not include an increase in the city sales tax, but includes increases of possibly 25 per cent in the resident income tax.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 20 (UPI) Lynette Alice Fromme briefly appeared in court today to end her nine-day exile and listened quietly to legal arguments in her trial on a charge of attempting to assassinate President Ford.

MIAMI, Nov. 20 (AP) "I thought someone was just falling down, and I was persuaded by the Secret Service to leave," said Ronald Reagan, who was shaken but smiling today after a youth with a toy pistol was wrestled down by Secret Service agents protecting Mr. Reagan near the Miami International Airport.

The state's Welfare Inspector General has portrayed one of the largest methadone programs here as a spendthrift agency with little incentive to curb staff extravagances, asserting about half the $1.1 million in a year's expenditures it submitted for Medicaid reimbursement were "ineligible, unsubstantiated or questionable."
Four Democratic aspirants for the Presidency are campaigning intensively in New York, even down to the clubhouse level, in preparation for their first test of strength in the state in two weeks.

OTTAWA, Nov. 20 Canada announced today that it would cut oil exports to the United States to 510,000 barrels a day Jan. 1, a reduction of one-third from the present allotment and that it expected to end the flow entirely by 1981, two years earlier than previously forecast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 The last of the Maine-built clipper schooners, used this summer as a seagoing classroom for disadvantaged city school children in the New York-New Jersey area, will become part of a nationwide program created by an agreement signed today.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 20 With support for a general strike in New Haven gathering, the school board and striking teachers resumed negotiations today, principally through timeconsuming telephone calls to teachers being held in jails in three places in the state.

SEOUL, South Korea American and other foreign bankers have been cocking an increasingly skeptical eye on big new loans to South Korea because of Seoul's rapidly mounting external debt and their own already sizable commitments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 With President Ford standing at his side, Donald H. Rumsfeld who has been serving as White House chief of staff, was sworn in today as the 13th Secretary of Defense in a ceremony on the parade grounds of the Pentagon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 The Federal Election Commission ruled today that money spent to finance President Ford's political travel as an announced candidate in 1975 should not be charged against his 1976 campaign spending ceiling except in special cases.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 20 (AP) Horace C. Stoneham, 72-year-old owner of the San Francisco Giants, entered Stanford University Medical Center today. He will undergo surgery tomorrow, officials of the team announced.

GUTTENBERG, N.J. As long ago as 1966 it would have been possible to put up two 50-story residential buildings here on the heights overlooking Manhattan opposite the West 70's, says Norman Belfer, a builder.
Higher prices for food and new cars and higher rents pushed the Consumer Price Index in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area for October up by five-tenths of 1 percent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 Consumer prices rose a little more in October than in September, with most of the problem in the volatile sector of food prices, the Labor Department reported today. Higher prices for food and new cars and higher rents pushed the Consumer Price Index in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area for October up by five-tenths of 1 percent.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 20 (AP) Topseeded Arthur Ashe and seventh-seeded Brian Gottfried scored straight-set victories today in second-round play of the South African, 6-4, 6-3, his championships.

A Columbia University scientist has announced the successful separation of two forms, or isotopes, of chlorine gas by a "simple" laser method that he says could be adapted for economical, continuous processes on a large scale.

"Our Bach Concerts," a series of midnight events that has become a nocturnal institution here in the last few years, has ventured into new territory. Wednesday night at Tully Hall it gave an 8 o'clock concert. Henry Schuman, oboist and director of the Liquid Music Society, which presents the concerts, assured midnighters they were not being forgotten. "We just wanted to give the 8 o'clock people a break," he said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Ford Administration health officials tried today to convince a Senate subcommittee that they were actively implementing a Federal program that would set up a network of prepaid group medical practices, called health maintenance organizations, around the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The Government Printing Office, which is printing for the public 20,000 copies of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said today that they would sell for $3.25 each.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Senator Frank Church said today that he believed the Senate would pass "before Easter" legislation providing for strong Congressional oversight of the intelligence agencies.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 21 (AP) Arthur Ashe, Adriano Panatta of Italy and Eddie Dibbs, the top three seeded, were the victims of upsets today in the third round of the South African open tennis championships.

People Christmas shopping for dolls this year will find such stand-bys as Raggedy Ann and Andy, such contemporary favorites as Barbie, and something else that seems to have become an institution: higher prices.

Bernard L. Avcollie, a 43year-old lawyer and former Connecticut state legislator, was indicted yesterday on a charge of murdering his wife. Wanda, whose body was found in the family swimming pool in Naugatuck last Oct. 30, the local police said.

Pierre Boulez put the New York Philharmonic's wind sections on parade at Thursday night's subscription concert and demonstrated both their communal virtuosity and his own keen ear for balancing and adjusting orchestral choirs.

Tatiana Koyen, a fashion consultant who was a chief buyer for Elizabeth Arden's fashion salons in the late 1960's, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital, following a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 50 years old and lived at 219 East 69th Street.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 21 Chicago Mayor Richard J. Daley, in his most bitter political fight yet with Gov. Daniel Walker, failed today to persuade the Illinois Senate to restore $116.7 million in state aid to education vetoed by the Governor.
An indoor 400-foot ski touring layout from Norway was the most popular exhibit yesterday in the second of four days at the annual New York Coliseum ski show.
Dr. Joseph T. Rowbottom 3d says that he may have to go back to collecting garbage. He does not look forward to it.

Annie Delphine Evans Primm, a music and elementary-school teacher in the Mamaroneck (N. Y.) public school system, died Wednesday of cancer at the New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospi tal Center. She was 45 years old and lived in New Rochelle.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 The expected passage of a $200 million tax package for New York City became stalled shortly before midnight and the Legislature recessed until 10 A.M. tomorrow morning.
The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 962,674 shares during the month ended Nov. 14 to 23,522,885 shares, it has been announced by the exchange.

A survey of public attitudes on human organ and tissue donations indicates that most persons favor donation of their kidneys, eyes, hearts and other organs for medical transplantation or scientific research after death, the National Kidney Foundation said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) The Government reported today that business orders for durable, goods rebounded in October, providing evidence that industry was providing the economy with the spending lift that analysts say is necessary to sustain the recovery.

Managers of money-market funds will be among those heaving sighs of relief if President Ford accepts the Albany tax package as a basis for supporting Federal aid to New York City. SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 Eldridge Cleaver, the one-time Black Panther leader who has since been expelled from the party, has asked to remain in Federal custody because he fears for his safety in a California state prison.

Dr. Samuel White Patterson, writer of biographies and, since 1952, professor emeritus of education at Hunter College, died Thursday at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in Paramus, N.J.

Smallpox workers in Bangladesh have discovered new cases of the viral disease, forcing the World Health Organization and the Bangladesh Government to retract a Nov. 13 announcement that smallpox had been wiped out in Asia.

LONDON, Nov. 21 The seven countries that manufacture and export most of the world's nuclear technology were said today to have general agreement on ways to prevent importing countries from using the technology to make nuclear weapons.

News reports yesterday that Mark Rudd, the radical activist of the late 1960's, was a prisoner in a Cuban homosexual rehabilitation camp apparently were based on a hoax published in the October issue of National Lampoon, the humor magazine.
